Summary: US bond yields are expected to rise in the near term due to a divergence between Fed projections for one rate cut in 2026 and market expectations for three cuts, posing a risk of a rebound in yields.
Investors are advised to take profit on long maturity bonds and rebalance towards a preferred 5-7 year maturity profile.
Fed rate cuts support a soft-landing scenario for the US economy, which is positive for corporate bonds, with yield premiums expected to remain well-anchored.
Investors are advised to add to Asia ex-Japan equities to reduce excessive exposure to US markets, supported by a weak USD environment.
Investors are advised to add to US technology sector stocks on any modest pullback.
EUR/USD is expected to test resistance at 1.20, supported by improving sentiment and economic stabilization in Germany.
India is seen as a core holding within an Overweight allocation to Asia ex-Japan equities, with a preference for consumer discretionary and financials sectors benefiting from stimulative policy.
Remain Overweight on China equities over the next 6-12 months, with a preference for growth sectors such as technology, supported by technological innovation and government policies.

Fade the bounce in USD: The US dollar index (DXY) rose for a third straight session as markets pared back some post-FOMC dovish bets. However, the wide dispersion in the 2026 forecasts underscores policy uncertainty, and softer data in the months ahead should push the Fed further dovish, diverging from other G10 central banks.

High hurdle for SNB to return to negative rates: The SNB is expected to hold its policy rate at 0% this week. While deflation concerns remain, recent inflation has printed above the SNB’s June forecast. Chair Schlegel has stressed that the bar for reintroducing negative rates is high. We see scope for USD/CHF to test 0.80 (50-DMA) in the near term.

BoJ’s hawkish hold to support JPY: The BoJ kept rates unchanged, but two dissents and a move to scale back risky asset holdings highlight growing hawkish pressure. The 4 Oct LDP leadership election will be key, though the next PM is likely to prioritize cost-of-living concerns, reinforcing a bias toward tighter policy and a stronger JPY. We expect further USD/JPY downside, with a BoJ hike likely before year-end. Near-term support stands at 146.3 (100-DMA).
The US bull market may sustain its momentum with the Fed's easing cycle providing a favorable backdrop for equities, despite some signs of labor market cooling.

The Fed's renewed easing cycle is expected to push more investors to put excess cash into quality investment grade bonds, which offer attractive income and potential for capital gains if growth slows further.

Within US equities, sectors benefiting from transformational innovation such as AI are favored, with tech, health care, utilities, and financials expected to gain from lower rates, solid earnings, and innovation tailwinds.
The S&P 500 is expected to reach 6,800 by June 2026, with EPS growth of 8% in 2025 and 7.5% in 2026, though current valuations are elevated with a forward P/E at 22.6x.

The USD has an unfavorable risk-reward profile due to a cyclical slowdown, persistent structural imbalances, and rich valuation, with Attractive views on the euro, Australian dollar, Norwegian krone, and select emerging market currencies.
Gold is expected to trade at USD 3,900 per ounce by June 2026, supported by more Fed easing, falling real yields, and robust investor and central bank demand.
Valuations point to a lower probability of equity outperformance over fixed income in part because the outlook for high quality fixed income is as good as it has been in a long time.
We see EM countries building upon their demonstrated resilience, with global diversification offering superior volatility-adjusted returns.
U.S. Treasuries have provided a hedging role for portfolios in every recession dating back to World War II, given the historical inverse correlation between stocks and bonds.

A core PIMCO thesis remains that yield curves will re-steepen over our secular horizon, as investors continue to demand more compensation to hold longer-term bonds relative to cash and short-term bills.
Look to flexible bond strategies that provide attractive income potential while managing risk.
Unlocking durable income through discipline, active value creation, and local insight in real estate.

Attractive opportunities in high quality areas including consumer, residential mortgage, real estate, and hard assets, where starting conditions and valuations appear favorable relative to corporate credit.
Yielding about 5%–7% by capitalizing on attractive yields available in high grade investments.
Active management, with the agility to exploit country-specific nuances and relative value differences, is crucial to navigating inevitable volatility.
The opportunity to generate alpha – returns exceeding market benchmarks – is as rich as it has ever been across global markets.
Forecasting fixed income returns is relatively straightforward: Over a secular horizon, the starting yield on a bond portfolio can be a good guide to expected returns.

After steep post-pandemic rate hikes, bond markets have made it to the other side: Investors can now benefit from higher yields plus potential price appreciation given central banks have ample room to cut rates.
Chinese equities are attractive due to a 1.7% yield on 10-year government bonds compared to a 1% one-year deposit rate.
US equity market strength is related to optimism about generative AI, with a tech company's share price rising 36% following optimistic revenue forecasts.
Chinese property investment declined sharply by 12.9% in the first eight months of 2025, contributing to the slowest overall fixed asset investment growth since the pandemic.
The yield on China’s 10-year government bond is currently about 1.7%.
Investors are increasingly confident that the Federal Reserve will soon start to cut interest rates, contributing to optimism in US equities.
Chinese industrial production increased 5.2% in August from a year earlier, with strong growth in automotive (8.4%), computers and communication (9.9%), and railway and shipbuilding (12%).
Energy companies are influenced by the positive spillover effect from AI-related optimism, as they must generate electricity to power AI.

Advance estimates of U.S. retail and food services sales for August 2025 were $732.0 billion, up 0.6% from the previous month and up 5.0% from August 2024. Total sales for the June 2025 through August 2025 period were up 4.5% from the same period a year ago.
Retail trade sales were up 0.6% from July 2025 and up 4.8% from last year. Nonstore retailers were up 10.1% from last year, while food service and drinking places were up 6.5% from August 2024.
US industrial production increased by 0.1% in August 2025 after a 0.4% decrease in July 2025.
Manufacturing output in the US rose 0.2% in August 2025 after a 0.1% decline in July 2025.
The index of consumer nondurables in the US rose 0.3% in August 2025 with gains in nearly all categories.
The index of consumer durables in the US gained 0.6% in August 2025, driven by a 1.3% increase in automotive products.
The production of motor vehicles and parts in the US increased by 2.6% in August 2025.
Mining output in the US grew 0.9% in August 2025 after falling 1.5% in July 2025.
The index for utilities in the US decreased 2.0% in August 2025, with a 2.3% decline in electric utilities output.

The US Federal Reserve restarted its cycle of interest rate cuts, with a 25bp cut on 17 September 2025, and signalled additional easing at its two remaining 2025 meetings. Market pricing suggests further rate cuts in March and June 2026.
Several Asian central banks have started cutting interest rates, driving down bond yields in Asia.
The dollar weakened significantly in the first half of the year despite support from the interest rate differentials, as the Fed restarts its easing cycle.
The ECB kept its benchmark rate unchanged at 2% on 11 September 2025, signalling that this cycle of interest rate cuts has ended, barring any major shocks.

The Fed is prepared to tolerate inflation running significantly above its target, with expectations of rate cuts by 25bp in both October and December 2025, and by at least 75bp more in 2026 to take the terminal fed funds rate to 2.75-3.00% or below.
The US dollar softened slightly versus the euro, with expectations for this trend to continue as diversification out of US assets is likely to continue.
The ECB sees the inflation 'undershoot' as temporary, with potential further rate cuts not expected until 2026 when it will be clearer whether below-target inflation in the eurozone is transitory.

Several Asian central banks, including Bank of Thailand, Bank of Korea, Banko Sentral ng Pilipinas (BSP), and Bank Indonesia, have cut rates, sustaining the downtrend in Asian government bond yields since early this year.
The 10-year US Treasury yield has been trapped in a 4%-5% range for over a year, with recent moves toward the lower end of the range.
The US Federal Reserve is caught between slowing growth and higher inflation, with the 10-year US Treasury yield affected by inflation-growth dynamics.
Beijing has eased monetary conditions and property market restrictions, boosting consumption-related fiscal spending to improve the outlook for China's asset market.
Uncertainty over the impact of import tariffs on inflation and growth is likely to last, adding downward pressures on short-term Treasury yields as the Fed begins a rate cut cycle.

The disappointing US private non-farm payrolls figure (38,000 seasonally adjusted for August versus a consensus estimate of 78,000 and 77,000 in July) has renewed worries of an impending recession in the US.

The odds that the US Federal Reserve will cut the fed funds rate at least 25bp at its next meeting have risen significantly, with either a 50bp cut, or additional 25bp cuts between now and the end of the year also somewhat more likely.
For more sustainable gains, we look to the Chinese technology sector, which enjoys fundamental support from AI developments, similar to the sector in the US.

Chinese purchasing managers’ indices data released recently do not fundamentally change the picture of an economy struggling with a moribund property market, weak consumer confidence and demand, and US tariffs.
The NASDAQ 100 index has underperformed the non-tech parts of the market despite fundamental support from AI developments.

Long-term interest rates are rising around the world, both for systemic and idiosyncratic reasons, with concern in the US centred on wavering faith in the credibility of the US government driving a rise in term premium.
Powell's speech at Jackson Hole was seen as dovish by some, justifying a rebound in equities with the Dow Jones index hitting a new record high.
Powell's speech led to a decline in US bond yields, indicating a positive sentiment for US Treasuries.
Powell confirmed that US monetary policy is moderately restrictive and that an adjustment could be considered given the baseline outlook and the shifting balance of risks.
Powell suggested that downside risks to employment are rising, which could lead to sharply higher layoffs and rising unemployment, impacting fixed income negatively.
The ECB and the Fed's September monetary policy decisions should be in line with financial markets' expectations, but this may change if there are any surprises from upcoming events and reports.
Investing in emerging markets may carry greater risk due to higher-than-average volatility, less information availability, and greater sensitivity to market conditions.
The BofA Global Real Estate conference in New York reported positive sentiment with capital flowing, rates falling, fundamentals healthy, and supply declining.
Healthcare is seeing a pickup in investment opportunities suggesting '25 acquisition guidance is entering a new phase with disruptive potential.
Communication Infrastructure and Comm Software sectors are driven by committed capital, rapid tech evolution, a ~$200 billion TAM, and regulatory support.
Tail risks in 2026 skew positive with robust AI/reshoring capex and rising productivity supporting earnings. Revenue per worker has hit record highs.
There are revenue timing and margin risks with AI servers having shorter lifespans of 3-5 years, and depreciation and amortization ramping in 2026-27 before AI revenues fully materialize.
A weaker USD in 2026 is expected to add ~3ppt to EPS for each 10% drop.
Tariff costs and risks to Fed independence could keep inflation above target, potentially feeding into inflation expectations.

The Fed's Summary of Economic Projections indicated that most policymakers expect to lower the central bank's policy rate by an additional 50 basis points by the end of the year, with expectations for rate cuts in 2026 and 2027 also increased.

Major U.S. stock indexes rose to record highs during the week, with the Russell 2000 Index gaining 2.16%, the Nasdaq Composite advancing 2.21%, and the S&P 500 Index and Dow Jones Industrial Average adding 1.22% and 1.05%, respectively.
Short-term yields were little changed following the Fed's rate cut announcement and post-meeting comments from Fed Chair Jerome Powell.
Recent interest rate cuts in the U.S. and the UK, a weaker U.S. dollar, higher commodity prices, and 'contained' oil prices have been supportive for emerging markets like South Africa.
Mainland Chinese stock markets declined as investors pocketed gains after a recent rally, with the CSI 300 Index shedding 0.44% and the Shanghai Composite Index falling 1.30%.
The pan-European STOXX Europe 600 Index ended the week slightly lower, with France's CAC 40 Index gaining 0.36%, Germany's DAX losing 0.25%, and Italy's FTSE MIB pulling back.
Japan's stock markets registered mixed performance over the week, with the Nikkei 225 Index gaining 0.62% and the broader TOPIX Index falling 0.41%.
The Bank of Japan surprised investors by announcing plans to begin selling its holdings of exchange-traded funds and Japanese real estate investment trusts much earlier than markets had anticipated.

China's August retail sales rose 3.4% and industrial output gained 5.2% year on year, marking the worst monthly performance for both gauges this year, with fixed asset investment growth slowing to 0.5%.

Global investment is flowing into nuclear technology companies and the broader nuclear supply chain, with countries mastering advanced nuclear technologies gaining energy security and commercial relationships.
Japan has restarted 14 reactors since Fukushima and committed to increasing the share of nuclear energy in the country’s energy mix.
The nuclear energy renaissance is underway, driven by technological breakthroughs, geopolitical competition, and the need for clean, reliable power.
President Trump’s promise to quadruple nuclear power generation by 2050 aims to reassert American leadership in nuclear power.
China is pursuing projects like the world’s first hybrid fusion-fission power plant, aiming to produce 100MW of continuous electricity by 2030.
The US has a strong private fusion sector with 25 of the world’s 45 private fusion companies and 80% of over $6 billion in equity investments into private fusion companies.
Concerns about the quality of economic data and its vulnerability to political influences are discussed, with revisions not notably increased, suggesting moderate data deterioration globally.

The US Bureau of Labor Statistics (BLS) is noted for producing the most watched and market-moving economic indicators, including employment and inflation measures, despite concerns about data politicization.
Joseph Briggs from Goldman Sachs Research notes that while there is some evidence of data quality deterioration globally, it is not a broad-based phenomenon.
Statistical agency funding in the US has been stagnant over the last 10 to 20 years, limiting the ability to keep up with changing economic dynamics.
The US healthcare sector has been underperforming, with its weight in the S&P 500 dropping to its lowest point in decades due to policy overhangs and fundamental issues.
Policy uncertainty, including changes in drug pricing and sector tariffs, is a significant headwind for the US healthcare sector, contributing to multiple contraction and keeping generalists away.
Earnings revisions for the US healthcare sector have been tracking negatively for about three years, contributing to its underperformance.
Valuations in the US healthcare sector are cheap, reflecting uncertainty, but an inflection in fundamentals or a macro shift is needed for a turnaround.

AI is being used by large US healthcare companies to streamline R&D processes and cut costs, with one company saving about $250 million, but it's tough to invest in healthcare as an AI play without real evidence of impact.
There is a resurgence in the biotech index (XPI) and smaller biotech names in the US, driven by recognition of innovation and potential revenue growth.
Family offices' total allocation across alternative asset classes has slightly decreased to 42% in 2025 from 44% in 2023.
44% of family offices primarily choose to invest in private real estate directly.
Family offices expect to increase their allocation to public equities.
The largest change since 2023 is the reduction in private equity exposure, with family offices in the Americas having the largest allocation at 25% versus 22% in EMEA and 15% in APAC.
Staying invested in US equities has continued to pay off for long-term investors including family offices.
75% of family offices in APAC reported geopolitical conflict as a top-three investment risk.
86% of family offices have some form of investment in AI, with 52% invested via public equities and 38% through AI-empowered companies.
Allocation to hedge funds has remained unchanged at 6% since 2021, with interest in multi-manager/multi-strategy funds and systematic quantitative funds.
61% of family offices globally consider geopolitical conflict to be a top risk.
AI is accelerating software development by up to six times and enhancing enterprise support functions, with one tech firm reporting AI handles up to 50% of workloads.
Several European companies are crucial in enabling technological advances in semiconductors and other hardware to address AI industry challenges.
AI models are getting cheaper and more capable, leading to increased adoption across industries such as healthcare, retail, manufacturing, and education to cut costs and improve productivity.
Technological advances such as hybrid bonding and semiconductors made of silicon, silicon carbide, and gallium nitride are improving power efficiency.
Generative AI adoption is surging, with one hyperscaler reporting a fivefold increase in token usage over the last 12 months.
AI adoption remains low among midsized and small enterprises in the US, with only 9.3% of companies using generative AI in production recently.
Goldman Sachs Research indicates that AI adoption is limiting labor-market impacts, with no significant correlation between AI exposure and economic measures like job growth and unemployment rates.
Goldman Sachs Research estimates that AI could displace 6-7% of the US workforce if widely adopted, with occupations like computer programmers and customer service representatives at higher risk.
Goldman Sachs Research suggests that AI adoption could lead to a half-percentage-point rise in the unemployment rate during the transition period.
Executives from the technology and finance sectors report efficiency gains from generative AI, leading to slowed hiring, especially in operational and back-office capacities.
Agentic AI is driving a monumental, generational shift poised to revolutionize industries, with a focus on investing in AI natives who will redefine industries.
The outlook for AI adoption is positive as advancements in technology accelerate, with new markets for AI data emerging.
The Autonomous Vehicle Market is forecast to grow and boost ridesharing presence, indicating a positive trend in AI-driven sectors.

In the US, spending on the construction of data center infrastructure has tripled over the last three years, with occupancy rates remaining near record highs for third-party leased data-centers across most US markets.
Global power demand from data centers is forecast by Goldman Sachs Research to rise 165% by 2030 from 2023 levels.
Goldman Sachs Research forecasts data center demand to grow by about 50% to 92 GW by 2027, with a compound annual growth rate of 17% between 2025 and 2028.

In a downside scenario where demand for AI turns out to be lower than expected, the growth rate for data center demand could be closer to 14%. In a more bullish scenario, the compound annual growth rate could reach 20%.
The US has a strong private fusion sector with 25 of the world's 45 private fusion companies and around 80% of the over $6 billion in equity investments into private fusion companies.
President Trump’s promise to quadruple nuclear power generation by 2050 may initiate a race to reassert American leadership in nuclear power.
Goldman Sachs Research suggests diversifying portfolios with gold to protect against unexpected tail risks in financial markets.
Goldman Sachs Research recommends diversifying through a range of commodities to protect equity-bond portfolios against stagnant economic growth and elevated inflation.
Commodities can protect portfolios against trade volatility, with their supplies becoming more concentrated and used as geopolitical leverage.
Commodities were among the few assets to rise in inflation-adjusted terms when Russia cut its gas flows to Europe in 2022.
Energy meets the criteria for hedging portfolios as disruptions can rapidly impact economies and financial markets.
Industrial metals and rare earth minerals are gaining influence as the energy mix shifts from fossil fuels to renewables.
China controls more than 90% of the refining capacity for rare earth minerals, essential in developing artificial intelligence.
When the Fed is cutting into a cyclical upswing, typically the outcomes are favorable, and markets tend to go up in the absence of recession.
The Fed is expected to cut rates five times over the next couple of years, with three cuts this year, one next year, and one in 2027, which is consistent with the GS view.
AI has captivated the market's imagination for almost three years, and tech stocks, including the Magnificent Seven, are performing better.
Japan offers exposure to AI, semiconductors, and defense sectors, and there could be a political catalyst with shareholder reform.
Investors should focus on diversification both within the technology sector and across industries due to higher concentration risks.
AI demands upgraded digital and physical infrastructure, leading to new investment opportunities and improved productivity across services and manufacturing sectors.
Investors may need to be more open to undervalued opportunities globally to diversify away from concentrated positions in the US.
Investors can employ a 'barbell' approach with investments in fast-growing technology companies and those facilitating growth.
Equity markets face headwinds such as elevated valuations, higher interest rates, and inflation, leading to lower absolute market returns.
US equity valuations are elevated, reflecting strong fundamentals, but investors should expect more moderate annual returns.
Yields are rising in Japan after decades of deflationary pressures, increasing the return demanded by investors.
Interest rates are rising in Germany due to a shift in fiscal spending.
Reduced globalization and higher tariffs are slowing world trade growth, impacting financial markets.
China remains a formidable competitor with large economies of scale and cost advantages in manufacturing.
Investment opportunities exist in domestic-focused companies with dominant market positions due to higher tariffs and a weaker dollar.
Europe is expected to increase investment in technology to substitute for labor, boosting margins and returns.
The US healthcare sector has been underperforming, with its weight in the S&P 500 index dropping to its lowest point in decades due to macroeconomic factors and policy uncertainties.
Policy uncertainties, including changes in drug pricing and sector tariffs, are driving multiple contractions across the US healthcare sector and keeping generalists away.

Despite underperformance, there are areas of innovation in the US healthcare sector, particularly in biotechnology and life sciences, focusing on lifespan and severe diseases like cancer, Alzheimer's, and Parkinson's.
AI is a tailwind for the global life sciences sector, enabling more effective and efficient innovation processes.
Cuts to NIH funding are impacting innovation in the US healthcare sector, particularly affecting life sciences tools companies exposed to academic funding.
Private equity is entering the US biotech space, providing more stable funding and allowing management teams to focus on execution.
Tech optimism remains very high, particularly around AI, with trends in advertising, e-commerce, and public cloud growth accelerating over the summer.
Investors feel that tech trends are broadly sustainable into the final third of the year, with a focus on AI's integration into consumer applications and changing go-to-market strategies.
Current market sentiment is bullish, with elevated but not extreme valuations, and a focus on green shoots of opportunity for growth in tech.
Goldman Sachs Research forecasts significant growth across the electricity value chain in Europe due to rising investments and higher margins.

Europe's power demand is expected to grow 1.5-2% per year from 2026, driven by electrification of vehicles, homes, and factories, as well as increased construction of data centers and use of air conditioning.
European power markets could move into a deficit with reserve margins falling to zero by 2029 due to rising demand and changes in the power supply industry.
Goldman Sachs Research expects Europe to need €2-3 trillion in power sector investments over the next 10 years, a 60-100% increase compared to the past decade.
Capex on transmission and distribution infrastructure in Europe could double to €1.2-1.4 trillion over 2026-35.
By the end of the decade, around 75% of Europe's installed power generation base will be from renewables, boosting self-sufficiency and lowering carbon emissions.
The shift to renewables in Europe will make the power system more volatile and reliant on weather-dependent supplies.
Investment in the European power sector offers value for investors, with electrification compounders potentially growing profits at 9-11% per annum over 2025-30.
Goldman Sachs Research projects global battery-electric vehicle penetration rates to decline, with EVs expected to be 25% of global sales in 2030, down from a prior prediction of 28%.
Hybrid vehicles are gaining favor among US drivers, with market share projected to increase as North American sales of electric vehicles (EVs) are forecast to decelerate.

Margins for North American operations may be 2 to 3 percentage points higher than previously assumed as traditional automakers maximize profits with an optimized balance of internal combustion and hybrid vehicles.
Goldman Sachs Research raised its forecasts for hybrid electric vehicle (HEV) sales weightings to 12% of the global market in 2030 (up from 10% previously) and 9% in 2040 (from 5%).
Plug-in hybrid electric vehicles (PHEVs) are projected to get 14% of the market in 2030 and 17% in 2040, up from a previous forecast of 9% in 2040.
The shift in the direction of US environmental regulations is expected to have a major positive earnings impact on traditional automakers.
Goldman Sachs Research cut their projection for 2040 EV sales share to 52% from a previous forecast of 59%.
Global EV sales rose 21% to 1.16 million vehicles in June, with sales volume in China increasing 37% year over year.
Growth investing crosses multiple asset classes and strategies, including venture funds, private equity funds, and hedge funds building crossover funds.
The asymmetry achievable in growth investing is unique, with a focus on building and scaling companies.
Investing in hypergrowth fintech and enterprise software companies was part of a strategic approach to accelerate digital transformation.
There are investible themes in core SaaS, with fintech being a key area of focus.

The US equity market faces structural risks due to active retail investor demand and disappointing payroll reports, with underemployment rates and negative revisions in June contributing to a downside risk for growth.
The Fed is expected to implement a 25-basis point cut in September, with the possibility of sequential cuts rather than a single 50-basis point cut, depending on upcoming CPI data.
There is a strong demand for gold across the franchise, indicating a positive sentiment towards this commodity.
Market favorites like AI have recently begun to underperform, indicating a negative sentiment in the tech sector.

Emerging markets are seen as structural winners in the current environment, benefiting from a lower dollar and Fed accommodation, with a strategy of being selective in emerging markets while owning quality.
Quality equities are considered interesting due to their defensive characteristics and potential stability in longer-dated rates, supported by a weaker dollar.
The Fed cut rates by 25bps, impacting the bond market and influencing the 2Y interest rate differential.
The Bank of Canada cut rates by 25bps, affecting the bond market and currency valuations.
European equities have posted nearly identical gains in local currency terms compared to the US, but in dollar terms, Europe is up more than twice as much due to a roughly 10% decline in the dollar.
The dollar index has declined significantly this year, with over a third of the decline attributed to the narrowing 2Y interest rate differential.
Year-to-date, U.S. equities have posted nearly identical gains in local currency terms compared to European equities.
The swaps market suggests the 2Y differential will compress further, with the Fed expected to continue easing, supporting a weaker dollar outlook.
Improving fundamentals overseas reinforce the strong case for international diversification as portfolios remain heavily tilted toward the U.S.
US equities are overweight due to AI supporting corporate earnings and stronger profitability compared to other developed markets.
We are neutral on long U.S. Treasuries as yields could fall further with a softening labor market, despite pressures pushing up yields.
European financials benefit from healthy balance sheets, a stronger fee business, and improving profitability.
European industrials are boosted by Europe's focus on defense, contributing to sector outperformance.
European utilities have outperformed with a 19% return, showing strong sector performance.
We prefer euro area credit over U.S. credit due to better compensation for risk and tighter spreads in Europe.
We are neutral on global inflation-linked bonds, expecting higher medium-term inflation but cooling near-term inflation and growth.
Gold surged to new highs, with a 40% gain for the year, driven by Federal Reserve rate cuts.
US tech shares led gains, with the S&P 500 up 13% for the year, driven by AI optimism.
We are underweight on emerging hard currency debt as spreads to U.S. Treasuries are near historical averages.
US technology companies have reported strong earnings and robust forward guidance, underlining their resilience despite tariff headwinds. AI adoption is expected to sustain earnings momentum.
Asia ex-Japan equities are expected to benefit from fund inflows due to a near-30% valuation discount and attractive valuation amid light positioning among investors.
Global growth is expected to slow due to tariff policy uncertainties, impacting the outlook for commodities in the coming quarter.
Investment-grade credit remains attractive amid rate cut prospects, with opportunities in short-duration (2-3Y) and high-quality (A/BBB) bonds.
Gold is supported by healthy central bank buying, robust gold ETF flows, and expectations of rate cuts and a weaker dollar.
Bond investors face challenges with rate cuts, mounting deficits, and a steeper curve, making neither cash nor ultra-long bonds suitable in a defensive fixed income portfolio.
Global growth is expected to slow on tariff policy uncertainties, but Fed's rate cuts, fiscal stimulus, and AI-related capex will stave off recession in the US.
US technology stocks have been leading gains on the S&P 500, with forecasted earnings for AI-related stocks revised up by 34 percentage points.
Asia ex-Japan equities are positioned for a turning point with compelling upside driven by steep valuation discounts, resilient earnings, and structural themes.

Expectations of subdued growth remain due to tariffs, with selective commodity outperformance driven by strategic importance or supply constraints, particularly in precious metals and rare earth elements.
AI-driven capex spending is expected to buoy corporate fundamentals and underpin risk assets, mirroring the 1995 Fed easing cycle.
The TikTok framework de-escalates US-China tech tensions, creating a potential governance framework and boosting near-term market sentiments.
Rhetoric surrounding US strategic uranium reserves to strengthen energy security buoys uranium and nuclear stocks overnight.
Interest in China Tech and AI related stocks is expected to remain strong, supported by robust growth outlooks and significant capex plans.
Aluminium prices surge on China production curb and dwindling global warehouse stocks; further increases possible if demand remains robust.
Our preference remains with Internet and Technology stocks poised to benefit from AI advancements, substantial capex plans, and supportive policies.
Financials rerated on the back of a steeper 2–10Y yield spread, with banks benefiting from borrowing short and lending long, and insurers gaining from higher yields.
Gold is a key beneficiary of the emerging world order; heightened uncertainty will drive demand in the short-term while de-dollarisation and fiat currency debasement bolster its long-term appeal.

Humanoids are a long-term panacea for the cost and labour-related challenges from the reshoring movement driven by Trump's 'America First' stance. The global humanoid market is projected to grow from USD2bn in 2024 to USD28.1bn by 2033, potentially replacing over 62.7mn workers by 2050.

The US national debt pile has grown significantly to USD36tn, driven by decades of deficit spending. A major contributor is trade; a country that spends more on foreign goods and services than it is earning will have to pay for the difference by either borrowing from foreigners, selling assets to foreigners, or attracting foreign investment. For the US, a big part of this difference is made up through borrowing, particularly through the issuance of US Treasuries.

As humanoids become increasingly advanced, their practical applications in real-world settings grow, creating compelling investment opportunities across their value chain. Automotive firms, especially those in autonomous vehicles, are well-placed to benefit from the humanoid theme due to shared core technologies such as AI models, LiDAR, cameras, and battery systems.

Rising geopolitical tensions and the cessation of US security guarantees are pushing nations to rethink defence and increase spending to bolster their military capabilities. Defence spending is prioritized to ensure deterrence and security should diplomacy fail.

The high octane rebound in US equities since early-April suggests swift pricing-in of tariff de-escalation and a 'no recession' scenario for the US economy. Expect binary outcomes for the negotiation between US and China, with 'favourable' trade deals leading to indiscriminate rally in risk assets and conversely, a re-escalation translating to acute market selloffs.

The US cyclicals vs defensive ratio suggests that investors are positioning themselves more conservatively as the Trump 2.0 agenda takes hold. Expect this trend to persist until clarity emerges on the tariff front. The failure to reach a 'beautiful trade deal' with China will mean that the 'no recession' scenario is off the table and until then, portfolios are expected to be defensively positioned.

For the coming quarter, a cautious stance is maintained on the S&P 500 amid policy uncertainties and ongoing paring down of US exposure as de-dollarisation and fiscal sustainability concerns take hold. Global fund managers are currently underweight on US equities, likely to persist given the broadening concerns on Section 899 of Trump’s budget bill.

Downside risks to US earnings forecast; defensive portfolio tilt amid uncertainties. Valuation for the S&P 500 has rebounded to 23x and above its five-year average, based on forward earnings growth of 11%, which is considered unrealistic.
Fed policy easing is expected, with the central bank likely to cut the Fed Fund rate twice by end-2025, providing a tailwind for US equities, particularly growth plays.

AI investments remain a significant tailwind for US macro and earnings growth outlook. Big Tech companies like Alphabet, Microsoft, and Amazon will be investing a combined USD250bn in 2025 on AI-related infrastructure.
The Middle East will be investing approximately USD100bn in AI-driven investments within this decade.
Fund managers are most underweight on consumer discretionary, downgraded in 2Q25 amid concerns around new immigration policies, aggressive job cuts by DOGE, sticky inflation, and weak affordability.
Stay overweight on technology, financials, and communication services, and underweight on consumer discretionary.

US RevPAR growth projections for 2025 have been reduced from c.1.8% - 2.0% to c.1% with weak operations expected from economic to upscale chain hotels. Midscale to upscale chain hotels see a double whammy impact, while luxury chain scale hotels remain relatively unscathed.
Global hoteliers with large exposure to international markets are expected to perform well as they continue to benefit from rising leisure travellers and a bottoming China market.

Marriott and Hilton registered a RevPAR growth range of +c.5% to +c.9%/+c.6-7% for APAC and EMEA markets, respectively. Marriott guided for +8% international group bookings in the coming year FY26. Hilton is looking to expand lifestyle brands into international markets where they see more traction.

US hoteliers posted a surprisingly strong quarter in 2Q25 with both Marriott and Hilton reporting earnings beat amid macroeconomic uncertainty and corporate travel budget cuts in the US. Marriott reported an adjusted EPS of USD2.65, while Hilton reported an adjusted EPS of USD1.95, beating estimates by 1.1% and 3.2% respectively.

Low to midscale hotels reported a close to double-digit y/y drop in RevPAR, reflecting softer leisure consumer sentiment and lower y/y revenue from corporate related travel, a trend similar across US government travel and small businesses with lower budgets and layoffs.

Hilton is currently trading at 21.0x EV/EBITDA and is on the second largest global hotel chain, operating over 7,000 properties and 1.1mn rooms. Hilton is more geared towards corporate travel, where business travel makes up c.50% of its room demand.

Marriott is the largest global operator and franchisor of hotels with a total of 1.6mn rooms within its system. Their targeted brand positioning lies within the luxury segment where they command the largest market share, a sizeable c.17%. Its strong membership program, Marriott Bonvoy, and competitive suite of brands have historically led to deep entrenchment among existing users, with c.61% of room bookings made through the membership program.
Hilton Worldwide has a DBS Rating of BUY with a target price of 296.0 LCY, a market cap of 65.4 USDbn, a Fwd. P/E of 34.7x, a dividend yield of 0.9%, and a 1Y Fwd EPS Growth of 23.7%.
Marriott International has a DBS Rating of BUY with a target price of 303.0 LCY, a market cap of 72.7 USDbn, a Fwd. P/E of 26.5x, a dividend yield of 0.3%, and a 1Y Fwd EPS Growth of 25.0%.
CapitaLand Ascott Trust has a DBS Rating of BUY with a target price of 12.0 LCY, a market cap of 2.7 USDbn, a Fwd. P/E of 18.7x, a dividend yield of 7.3%, and a 1Y Fwd EPS Growth of -18.2%.
CDL Hospitality Trusts has a DBS Rating of BUY with a target price of 12.0 LCY, a market cap of 0.8 USDbn, a Fwd. P/E of 34.4x, a dividend yield of 6.5%, and a 1Y Fwd EPS Growth of 108.7%.
There was an aggressive flight from US assets, exemplified by the rapid selloff in UST yields following 'Liberation Day'.
Trump's tariffs resulted in a weaker dollar, yield spikes, and increased stagflation risks.
Investors should consider stagflation-resistant bonds such as TIPS, capital securities, and short duration credit as stagflation risks rise.
Investors in HY should exercise caution and remain up in quality in the BB bucket to mitigate risks of credit events and defaults.
TIPS are recommended for fixed income investors to protect against inflationary headwinds, as they excel under conditions of lower growth and higher inflation.
A duration barbell approach with 7-10Y IG credit remains sensible, and short-duration high quality credit is a viable alternative for cash.
Ultra-long duration TIPS look attractive due to the steep TIPS curve, providing adequate compensation for going long.
Investors are advised to consider 'government+' allocations like MBS, which provide a spread cushion over treasuries and diversification.
US debt levels are over 100% of GDP, causing concerns and resulting in higher long to ultra-long yields. 30Y US yields briefly exceeded 5%, nearing this cycle's high of 5.17%.
Japan's debt load exceeds 200% of GDP, leading to a relentless shift higher in ultra-long end JGB yields.
Germany maintains a benign government debt load at 60% of GDP, with Bund yields buoyant due to an optimistic economic outlook.
Debt levels across developed markets are rising along with interest rates, leading to concerns over US and Japan's debt loads and higher long to ultra-long yields.
Rate cuts are expected across much of Asia due to steady exchange rates, with further easing anticipated in China, including a 20 bps cut in the 1Y LPR and a 50 bps reduction in the RRR.
CGB yields are expected to stay steady after promising trade talks, with additional rate cuts anticipated to maintain stability.
SGD rates are likely to maintain a sizable discount to USD rates, driven by USD weakness rather than the slope of the SGD NEER.
The KTB curve steepened due to monetary easing and expectations of increased long-end KTB supply post elections, with optimism about Korea's economic outlook.
Rising global risks from escalating trade tensions are negative for Malaysia's export-oriented sectors, with the economy set to miss its 2025 growth projection of 4.5-5.5%.
A strategic combination of private assets and hedge funds can cushion against drawdowns related to rate shocks, outperforming a traditional 60/40 portfolio.
The endowment-style hybrid portfolio, using a fund of open-ended funds approach, is more capable of hedging against drawdowns and lifting returns compared to a conventional 60/40 portfolio.
Private secondaries, private credit, and private infrastructure present timely opportunities for investors to capture vintage-year premia amid high volatility and inflationary regimes.

A hybrid portfolio approach employing a fund of open-ended funds format can deliver diversification benefits and outperform both a pure equity play and the conventional 60/40 portfolio over a 10-year horizon.
Private credit, with a floating structure and tailwinds from refinancing opportunities as Basel III endgame hits, can hedge against stagflation risks.
Private infrastructure assets, with long-term contracted cash flows and inflation-linked revenue structures, can generate inflation-protected distributions for investors.
Private credit's floating rate structure should keep yields high at approximately 10.5%, adjusting with monetary policy and rising with inflation.
Private infrastructure vintages during inflation shocks tend to outperform, highlighting the vintage-year premium.
Private income generators such as private credit, infrastructure, and real estate displayed greater resilience over bonds under inflationary regimes.

Gold is expected to reach USD3,765/oz. by 4Q25, driven by strong central bank and investor demand amid macroeconomic and geopolitical uncertainty, recession/stagflation risk, and ongoing monetary debasement concerns.
Central bank and investor demand are key to gold's continued rise, providing steady structural demand and maintaining a price floor during times of broad de-risking.
A linear regression analysis shows that approximately 600 tonnes of quarterly demand can produce a 6.4% quarterly increase in gold prices, supporting the revised target price of USD3,765/oz. by 4Q25.
Gold has been in a consistent bull market for the past three years, with geopolitical uncertainty, a widening US fiscal deficit, dedollarisation, and fiat currency debasement as key tailwinds.
Continued central bank reserve diversification and robust investor demand are expected to buoy gold in a new era of heightened risk and uncertainty.
Tariffs are driving macroeconomic weakness and prospects of Fed rate cuts, adding to gold's appeal.
US fiscal worries, a softer dollar, and elevated geopolitical risk have contributed to a sharp YTD rebound in gold ETF flows.
Gold is considered one of the best hedges against recession/stagflation risk, fiat currency debasement, de-dollarisation, and other US policy-related risks.
The US recession probability remains at a substantial 30.5% as of April 2025, supporting increased investment demand for gold.
Gold as a percentage of international reserves remains at roughly 21% as of February 2025, well below the historical 54-year average of 29%, indicating room for reserve diversification.
Downside price risk for industrial metals is expected when front-loaded demand tapers off and demand destruction sets in.

Despite a bullish demand outlook for corn, uncertainty over tariffs and expectations for a record year for US corn production are expected to put downward pressure on corn prices in the second half of the year.
Falling alumina prices have reduced aluminium production costs, increasing downside price risks. Aluminium markets face significant downside risk later in the year due to front-loaded demand.
Cocoa market is expected to enter a surplus for the first time since 2021, with demand destruction settling in as cocoa prices have tripled since the start of 2023.
Gold is buoyed by safe haven demand and de-dollarisation tailwinds, significantly outperforming with a YTD performance of +22.2%.

Commodities are facing challenges under Trump 2.0, with tariff-related growth risks and policy uncertainty likely to keep sentiment and fund flows cautious for all commodity sub-sectors other than precious metals.
The US government has signed a proclamation imposing a USD100,000 fee on new H-1B visa petitions, signaling a shift in US policy that may affect skilled foreign workers.
Indian IT companies have reduced reliance on H-1B visas, increasing offshoring and revisiting business delivery models due to US policy changes.
The Bank of Japan (BOJ) maintained its policy rate at 0.50% and announced plans to gradually sell its holdings of ETFs and J-REITs, with a possibility of a 25 bps rate hike in 4Q25.
Indonesia concluded a free trade agreement with the European Union, effectively lowering tariffs to nil on over 90% of its product lines, offering economic uplift.

Southbound investor participation in the Hong Kong market has grown significantly, accounting for 28% of total market turnover in Jul-Aug 25, up from 23% in 2Q25, driven by a rally in tech stocks and an active IPO market.

HKEx aims to become China’s go-to offshore risk management hub, with potential inclusion of HKD-RMB Dual Counters and REITs into Stock Connect to expand RMB access, and has extended its reach to the Middle East and the US.

Maintain BUY with unchanged TP of HKD540 for HKEx, expecting trading activity to accelerate in the medium to long term, supported by growing Southbound investor participation, continued re-rating of the tech sector, potential policy stimulus from the Chinese government, and expectation of interest rate cuts by the Fed.
Investor confidence boosted by AI breakthroughs, with the rise of DeepSeek lifting investor interest in tech stocks and pushing YTD ADT to HKD244bn (+100% y/y).
Risks include insufficient policy support from the Chinese government and slower-than-expected economic recovery.
Key exposure to the data centre and PC market, which are highly correlated with economic conditions and investment demand. Any economic headwind could slow down demand.
AMD faces direct competition with Intel and NVIDIA in the microprocessor and graphics markets, respectively. Material share gains/losses could result in upside/downside to its earnings outlook.

AMD is supported by sustained AI capex from hyperscalers and infrastructure AI spenders. Ongoing multi-billion dollar investments from Microsoft, Amazon, Google, and Meta continue to drive demand for AI GPUs, benefiting vendors like AMD.

AMD has a strong track record of innovation, design agility, and proven execution, gaining market share from Intel in the server and client segment due to the growing demand for its 4th Gen EPYC processors and Ryzen 8000 series.
AMD sees a USD 400bn data centre accelerator TAM due to increasing adoption of AI and the pervasiveness of AI across industries, necessitating significant investment in new infrastructure.
AMD's share price could remain constrained given the impacts of the export ban and upcoming semiconductor tariffs.

AMD's hardware capabilities have advanced significantly, yet it continues to face a relative disadvantage in software and ecosystem depth, where Nvidia’s CUDA platform remains the industry standard for AI development.
DBS maintains a HOLD rating on AMD with a 12-month target price of USD 155.0, based on a forward P/B of 3.9x, close to -0.5SD of the historical mean.

Fed funds futures last priced 40bps of cuts for the rest of this year, and 61bps of cuts in 2026. Our base-case remains for 50bps of cuts for the rest of this year and a 25bp cut in 2026, with the risk that rate cuts may be paced out.
USD continued to trade higher overnight, with DXY last seen at 98.40 levels. Daily momentum is mild bullish but rise in RSI moderated.
USDSGD continued to inch higher amid anticipated US data. USDSGD last seen at 1.2930 levels. Daily momentum is mild bullish while rise in RSI moderated.
Trump’s latest tariff measures further undermined sentiments, putting pressure on high-beta Asian FX.
Overnight’s 7Y coupon bond auction cut off at 3.953%, which was similar to WI level (with a tiny tail); bid/cover ratio was a tad lower at 2.40x versus 2.49x prior. The outcome was fair.
US equities closed lower on the day with S&P down 0.5%, NASDAQ down 0.5%, and Dow down 0.38%.
The DXY index gained.
UST yields closed below intra-day highs.
The third estimate of US 2Q25 GDP growth beat estimates, coming in at 3.8% QoQ annualised from a previous estimate of 3.3%.
Crude oil benchmarks were broadly stable with Brent edging up 0.2% to USD69.4/bbl.
Corn futures increased by 0.4% and soybean futures by 0.3%.
Copper futures decreased by 0.74% and nickel futures by 0.90%.
Gold futures increased by 0.4% and silver futures by 2.9%.
Heating oil futures increased by 2.07% and natural gas futures by 1.61%.
Crude palm oil futures increased by 0.5%.

Green SGS (Infra) 2072 was last quoted at 2.133/2.079%, at a spread of 17/18bps over Green SGS (Infra) 2054 at 1.960/1.898%. The yield was around 30bps above 20Y SGD OIS and 39bps above 10Y SGD OIS. Asset swap pick-up was last at around SOFR+74bps on 10Y hedge.

The 50Y Green SGS (Infra) auction on 26 September has been announced at SGD1.0bn. The bond sales are expected to be smoothly absorbed given the relatively small size and the steepness of the SGS curve, despite the low absolute yield level.

Year-to-date gross SGS issuances amounted to SGD21.2bn; after the upcoming auction, the amount will be SGD22.2bn. The annual rate of increase in outstanding SGS is likely to come in at around/below 3%, depending on the size of the 10Y SGS and whether the mini auction will go ahead.

The Green SGS (Infra) 2072 was first issued via syndication in 2022 at a size of 2.4bn, reopened in 2023 at a size of SGD2.8bn, and in 2024, SGD1.5bn of the bond was auctioned. The outstanding amount is at SGD6.7bn, with a remaining maturity of approximately 46 years and 10 months.

The SGS curve has steepened alongside the UST curve lows attained on 16 September, with FX swaps facing some bidding interests. At the latest MAS bills auction on 23 September, the 4W and 12W bills cut off at 1.45% and 1.42% respectively, both 3bps higher than cut-offs at the previous auction on 16 September.

New home sales in the US rose by 20.5% MoM to 800k units (15.4% YoY) in August, with the median price rising to USD413.5k, while building permits were down 2.3% MoM (-9.9% YoY from -5.2% in July) to 1.3mn, signaling potential headwinds for future supply.

Crude oil benchmarks extended gains for the second consecutive trading session, with WTI and Brent rising by 2.5% to USD65.0/bbl and USD69.3/bbl, respectively, due to a surprise decline in US crude oil and fuel inventories.

US crude oil inventories declined by 0.6mn bbls to 414.8mn bbls, reaching their lowest levels since January, while gasoline and distillate inventories fell by 1.1mn bbls and 1.7mn bbls, respectively, supporting higher oil prices.

Thailand's August customs export growth underperformed against expectations, easing to 5.8% YoY from 11.0% in July, while customs import growth accelerated to 15.8% YoY from 5.1% in July, resulting in a customs trade deficit of USD2.0bn, down from a surplus of USD0.3bn in July.
Bloomberg Asia USD Investment Grade spreads tightened by 1bps to 61bps and Bloomberg Asia USD High Yield spreads tightened by 2bps to 317bps.
Nissan Motor Acceptance Co LLC priced USD2b of debt in two tranches: a USD1.25bn 5Y Fixed Bond at T+241.80bps (Yield: 6.125%) and a USD750mn 3Y Fixed Bond at T+202.90bps (Yield: 5.625%).
Nickel Industries Ltd priced a USD800mn 5NC2 Fixed Bond at 9.00%.
Baiterek National Managing Holding JSC priced a USD500mn 5Y Fixed Bond at T+114.20bps.
US equities fell on Tuesday, with the broad indexes of S&P500, Dow, Nasdaq declining between 0.2% and 1.0% (S&P500: 0.6%; Dow: 0.2%; NASDAQ: 1.0%).
New Zealand Local Government Funding Agency Bond priced a USD500mn 5Y Fixed Bond at SOFR MS+53bps (Reoffer price 99.459 to yield 3.87%).
Clifford Capital Holdings Pte. Ltd. priced a USD500mn 3Y Fixed Bond at T+40bps (Reoffer price to yield 3.97%).
Bloomberg Asia USD High Yield spreads widened by 5bps to 319bps.
Bloomberg Asia USD Investment Grade spreads widened by 1bps to 62bps.

MY: Headline CPI rose by 1.3% YoY in August 2025, up from 1.2% in July. The main drivers were Insurance & Financial Services (5.6% YoY in August, up from 5.5% in July), Personal Care & Miscellaneous (4.0% from 3.9%), Restaurants & Accommodation (3.5% from 3.1%), Education (2.4% from 2.2%), and Food & Beverages (2.0% from 1.9%).
Fed Chair Jerome Powell reiterated that 'increased downside risks to employment have shifted the balance of risks,' which led to the FOMC’s decision to lower its policy rate.

OECD warned of significant risks to the economic outlook and highlighted several downside risks to its growth forecast, including 'further increases in bilateral tariff rates, a resurgence of inflationary pressures, increased concern about fiscal risks, or substantial risk repricing in financial markets.'
Major US stock indexes reached new highs, driven by the ongoing AI capex frenzy. Nvidia committed to invest up to USD100bn in OpenAI to support data centres and other AI infrastructure.
US treasuries saw a modest selloff with yields 2-3bp higher across the curve.
The US dollar index failed to build on the upside momentum and declined broadly.
Spot gold reached another all-time high at USD3748.97/oz.
Crude oil benchmarks were broadly stable, with WTI and Brent edging down by 0.1% and 0.2%, respectively, to USD62.6/bbl and USD66.6/bbl.
China Minsheng Banking Corp Ltd/Hong Kong priced a USD300mn 3Y Sustainability FRN at SOFRIX+51bps.
Commonwealth Bank of Australia/New York NY priced USD1.5bn of debt in two tranches: a USD750mn 5Y Fixed Bond at T+45bps and a USD750mn 5Y FRN at SOFR+78bps.
Korea National Oil Corp priced USD1.3bn of debt in three tranches: a USD500mn 3Y Fixed Bond at T+50bps, a USD500mn 3Y FRN at SOFR+67bps, and a USD300mn 5Y Fixed Bond at T+50bps.
Silver prices increased by 2.3% to USD44.06/oz.
Palladium prices increased by 2.5% to USD1184/oz.
Copper prices decreased by 0.2% to USD9973/mt.
After the Fed's widely anticipated 25bps rate cut last week, market optimism drove Wall Street higher on Friday - the S&P500 closed up 0.49%.
The 10-year bond yield added 25bps to 4.13% following the Fed's rate cut.
The BOJ kept its policy rate static at 0.5% with 2 dissenters calling for a hike and will begin sales of its ETF holdings at a pace of ~JPY620bn per year.
The trade surplus widened to MYR16.1bn from MYR14.6bn due to import growth collapsing to -5.9% YoY in August from 0.6% in July.
Export growth averaged 4.2% YoY in July and August compared to 3.3% in 2Q25, suggesting a more accretive contribution of net exports to GDP for 3Q25.
WTI and Brent crude oil prices fell by 1.40% and 1.13% respectively.
Corn prices increased by 0.1%, while soybean and wheat prices decreased by 1.2% and 0.3% respectively.
Natural gas prices fell by 1.74%.
Rubber prices increased by 2.8%.
USTs are likely to stay in ranges before the next catalyst. Near-term range for 2Y UST yield remains at 3.55-3.65% and for 10Y UST yield at 4.00-4.20%.
42% of respondents anticipated MAS to ease policy in Oct, an increase from about 17% in the Jun survey. USDSGD last seen at 1.2880 levels with daily momentum mild bullish while rise in RSI moderated.
Fed funds futures last priced 43bps of cuts for the rest of the year and 65bps of cuts for 2026. Fed commentaries remain split, with Mary Daly suggesting further policy adjustments will be needed.
Cautious remarks from Fed officials dampened bearish bets on USD. Fed’s Goolsbee expressed reluctance to support 'overly frontloading a lot of rate cuts'.
Softer core CPI print for Singapore at 0.3% y/y for Aug may have led to expectations that MAS may ease policy again at its upcoming MPC in Oct.
USDCHF traded firmer amid broad USD rebound. SNB MPC meeting likely a hold as inflation moved to 0.2% y/y, faster than SNB’s forecast for 0.1% for 3Q.
Near-term range for 2Y UST yield is seen at 3.55-3.65% and for 10Y UST yield at 4.00-4.20%, consistent with breakeven in the range of 2.3-2.4% and real yield in the range of 1.7-1.8%.

At Tuesday’s MAS bills auctions, the 4W and 12W bills cut off at 1.45% and 1.42% respectively, which were both 3bps higher than cut-offs at the previous auctions. SGS7.7bn of 6M T-bills are auctioned, with expected cut-off in the range of 1.40-1.44%.

Short-end IndoGBs are likely to be supported given the favourable monetary policy backdrop while SRBI rates and implied IDR rates have fallen. However, IndoGB-UST yield differentials may not be particularly appealing to foreign investors at this juncture.
Demand at overnight’s 2Y coupon bond auction was fair, with bid/cover ratio at 2.51x versus 2.69x prior, and indirect accepted steady at 57.7% versus 57.1%.

Fed funds futures pricings were little changed, at 44bps of cuts for the rest of the year and 68bps of cuts for 2026. Powell’s comments erred on the cautious side regarding the future path of the policy rate.

UST yields edged higher overnight, with Fed officials seeing the 10Y yield range of 4.00-4.20% as fair, breakeven at 2.3-2.4%, and real yield at 1.7-1.8%. Auctions of 2Y FRN, 2Y, 5Y, and 7Y Notes are scheduled, with a coupon bond settlement of USD28bn on Friday and USD93bn next week.

The upcoming reopening of 50Y Green SGS Infra to be auctioned on 26 September is announced at SGD1.0bn, smaller than last year's SGD1.5bn. Gross issuances this year will amount to SGD22.2bn, on the low side of the expected range. Demand is expected to be fair due to the small size and steepened SGS curve alongside the UST curve.

Implied SGD rates have risen from lows on 16 September, with 1M implied SGD rate at 1.39% and 3M at 1.33%, around 10bps and 6bps higher than a week ago. This points to potentially higher MAS bills cut-offs.

CNH rates traded higher on Monday due to anticipated market closure in Hong Kong with the looming typhoon. The gap between offshore and onshore rates is closed, limiting downside to offshore CNH rates.
Investor demand at overnight's T-bills auctions was solid, with a 3M bills bid/cover ratio of 3.33x versus 3.11x prior. The cut-off of 3.860% was slightly below WI level.
SGS7.7bn of 6M T-bills are auctioned on Thursday, with expected cut-off in the range of 1.40-1.44% as the 6M implied SGD rate has edged higher from two weeks ago.

The 2Y UST yield at 3.55% remains roughly consistent with market-priced Fed funds rate trajectory, with expectations of additional 50bps of cuts for the rest of the year. The 2Y UST may garner support with yield in the range of 3.55-3.65%, while the year-end forecast is 3.60%.
The 10Y UST yield is expected to be in the range of 4.00-4.20%, with a year-end forecast of 4.10%.
USD/JPY traded lower before rebounding, with support near 147.80 and resistance at 148.70 (200 DMA).

The Bank of Japan kept its policy rate unchanged at 0.5% by a 7-2 majority vote. Two members voted for a 25bp hike, citing a shift away from the deflationary norm and price stability target achievement. A 25bp hike is expected in Q4-2025.

Our bullish view on USTs up to 10Y tenor panned out well. We expect 2Y UST yield to trade in a range of 3.55-3.65%, while maintaining our year-end forecast of 3.60%. We continue to see 10Y yield in the range of 4.00-4.20% as fair, and we maintain our year-end forecast of 10Y UST yield at 4.10%.

Fed funds futures last priced additional 44bps of cuts for the rest of the year, and 72bps of cuts for 2026. The FOMC decided to lower the target range for the Fed funds rate by 25bps to 4.00-4.25%, in line with expectations. We continue to expect one 25bp Fed funds rate cut each at the October and at the December meeting this year, followed by one 25bp cut in Q1-2026, which will then bring the target range for the Fed funds rate to 3.25-3.50%.

The 2025 and 2026 median dots point to additional 50bps of cuts for the rest of this year, and one 25bp cut in 2026, in line with our long-held call. For the rest of 2025, while the median dot is for additional 50bps of cuts, the distribution of individual dots is skewed to the upside.

Fed funds futures fully price a 25bp cut at the September FOMC meeting, with a total of 70bps of cuts for this year. The base-case is for a total of 75bps of cuts this year and one 25bp cut in Q1-2026.
UST yields slid post payrolls. The forecast for 10Y UST is 4.20% in 3Q25, 4.10% in 4Q25, 4.05% in 1Q26, and 4.05% in 2Q26.
The 10Y UST downward move since the recent high on 18 August was explained around 95% by a lower real (TIPS) yield.
Bank reserves are expected to stay above USD3trn when US Treasury replenishes cash to target. Reserve repos stood at USD369bn and bank reserves at USD3.18trn as of 3 September.
SOFR has been gradually increasing, last fixed at 4.41% compared to IORB at 4.40%.
Further upside for equities is expected due to AI-led innovation and the Fed's rate cut cycle, supported by M&A, dividends, and share buybacks.
Overweight on US stocks, Tech, and Communications benefiting from AI-led innovation and Fed's rate cut cycle.
Chinese stocks show strong performance due to high US valuation multiples and weakening USD, with reduced trade frictions with the US easing concerns.
Singapore stocks show strong performance due to high US valuation multiples and weakening USD.
Quality bonds are favored as they would perform well if disappointing growth hurts equities or if there are concerns about equity valuation bubbles.
The Fed delivered a 25bps cut at its September meeting, aligning with expectations for further easing and supporting asset prices.
EM Local currency bonds benefit from rate cuts, attractive carry, and USD depreciation.
Asian equities are supported by policy tailwinds and structural growth trends, including AI innovation and corporate governance reforms.
Singapore is a defensive market with high dividend income, attractive in the current environment.
Portfolios are diversified by including gold, hedge funds, private credit, private equity, and infrastructure.

The Nasdaq rose 2.3% last week, bringing its year-to-date gains to over 20%, amid concerns over valuations. The index trades at around 29 times 12-month forward earnings, a third more expensive than the median over the past 30 years. Investors are looking for reassurance on AI capital spending and monetization in upcoming third-quarter results from major tech companies like Alphabet, Apple, Amazon, Meta, Microsoft, and NVIDIA.

Current tech valuations, though elevated by historical standards, are justified given the transformational nature of AI and rapid profit growth of AI leaders. AI investment in the US over the past 12 months remains below 1% of GDP, compared to levels of 2-5% for other capital spending surges.

The expected rate cut from the Fed will lower the opportunity cost of holding gold. With sticky inflation, the real US interest rate could fall below zero, encouraging investment flows into gold exchange-traded funds, which hit a record USD 17 billion last month. Central banks remain enthusiastic buyers, and geopolitical concerns continue to support gold as a portfolio diversifier.
Gold is trading around USD 4,065/oz, with potential gains toward USD 4,700/oz possible should adverse macro and political developments emerge.
The post-pandemic inflation shock and rate-hiking cycle produced a generational reset higher in bond yields, supporting a strong multiyear outlook for global fixed income.
U.S. Treasuries have provided a hedging role for portfolios in every recession dating back to World War II, given the historical inverse correlation between stocks and bonds.
The Trump 2.0 fiscal package is likely to widen U.S. deficits and debt beyond prior policy projections, with overall fiscal space remaining constrained.
Valuations point to a lower probability of equity outperformance over fixed income, in part because the outlook for high quality fixed income is as good as it has been in a long time.
Currency rates may fluctuate significantly over short periods of time and may reduce the returns of a portfolio, with heightened risk in emerging markets.
Investors can now benefit from higher yields plus potential price appreciation given central banks have ample room to cut rates.
Active management can enhance bonds’ role as a hedge through yield curve positioning, with a bias to run more overweight duration positions in portfolios.
The opportunity to generate alpha – returns exceeding market benchmarks – is as rich as it has ever been, with attractive yields available in high grade investments.
The US economy is experiencing a significant AI-related, tech-related investment surge, boosting equity valuations and fueling strong household spending.

The current surge in AI investment and equity market valuations is not yet at the levels of the dot-com boom, but there are similarities, with much investment going to small companies with no profits.
If the weakness of multiple companies becomes apparent, equity prices could decline, similar to the 2000 dot-com bubble.
Investment in commercial real estate and other nonresidential structures is being examined in the June 2023 Economics Spotlight.
Prices of AI-related equities have soared, playing a significant role in the increase in US and Chinese equity prices.
The US economy has decelerated sharply from 2024, and this is expected to continue, especially if importers pass on more of the cost of tariffs to their customers.
A continuation of the current immigration policy could lead to a sharp slowdown in the size of the labor force, slowing employment growth and economic growth.
If there is net-zero immigration going forward, the under 18 population will shrink by 14% by 2035, leading to a decline in the number of workers and potential fiscal challenges.
Weak investment likely reflects weak consumer demand, uncertainty about trade relations, and existing excess capacity in some industries.
The IMF predicts that the US economy will grow 2% this year, stronger than other G7 countries, driven by a significant AI-related investment surge.
The 2025 US tariffs led to a 5.4% increase in prices for imported goods, including those made of steel and aluminum, relative to pre-tariff trends.
Domestic goods in import-intensive categories experienced a 3% price increase due to the 2025 US tariffs, highlighting indirect effects on domestic markets.
Goods imported from China faced higher tariffs, resulting in larger and more sustained price increases compared to other trading partners.
The 2025 tariffs contributed about 0.7 percentage points to the all-items Consumer Price Index in six months, indicating a significant impact on inflation.
Tariff pass-through rates reached up to 20% six months after implementation, reflecting gradual transmission and continuing uncertainty about policy persistence.

In August 2025, US personal income increased by $95.7 billion (0.4 percent), disposable personal income increased by $86.1 billion (0.4 percent), and personal consumption expenditures increased by $129.2 billion (0.6 percent), according to the U.S. Bureau of Economic Analysis.
The $129.2 billion increase in current-dollar PCE in August 2025 reflected increases of $77.2 billion in spending on services and $52.0 billion in spending on goods.
Personal outlays in the US increased by $132.9 billion in August 2025, with personal saving at $1.06 trillion and the personal saving rate at 4.6 percent.

AI adoption across industries in Europe is surging, with sectors such as healthcare, retail, manufacturing, and education adopting AI to cut costs and improve productivity, according to Alexander Duval, head of Europe Tech Hardware & Semiconductors in Goldman Sachs Research.
AI models are becoming cheaper and more capable, leading to increased adoption across various industries globally.
In healthcare, AI is being used by surgeons to solve complex problems more efficiently using AI trained on 25 years of video data.
In the industrial sector, companies are leveraging thousands of autonomous robot agents equipped with AI, operating 24/7 in facilities, leading to clear cost benefits.

In retail, generative AI is powering robots that perform stock-taking and predictive analysis to prevent stock-outs and promote product uptake, driving a three-to-four-times return on investment within a three- to four-month period.
In the entertainment industry, a streaming company has integrated generative AI into its visual effects pipeline, accelerating production by 10x.

AI adoption remains low among midsized and small enterprises in the US, with only 9.3% of companies using generative AI in production recently. This low adoption is limiting labor-market impacts, according to Goldman Sachs Research.
Goldman Sachs Research estimates that AI adoption could displace 6-7% of the US workforce if widely adopted, but the impact is likely to be transitory.
Goldman Sachs Research estimates that AI adoption could lead to a half-percentage-point rise in the unemployment rate above its trend during the transition period.
Executives from the technology and finance sectors report efficiency gains from generative AI, slowing hiring in operational and back-office capacities.
Goldman Sachs leaders at the Communacopia + Technology conference highlighted that AI has begun to affect the business landscape and its impact is expected to widen significantly in the years ahead.

Jung Min from Goldman Sachs Investment Banking stated that AI has dramatically changed processes like computer coding and customer service, with hundreds of verifiable use cases similar to software development.
Goldman Sachs Research Chief Economist Jan Hatzius predicts that AI could boost annual productivity growth by 1.5pp per year by replacing low- and mid-value-added white-collar tasks.

Jan Hatzius from Goldman Sachs suggests that over the decade, 6-7% of total employment might be displaced by AI, but the impact on unemployment will be smaller as people are absorbed into other industries.

In the US, spending on the construction of data center infrastructure has tripled over the last three years, with occupancy rates near record highs for third-party leased data-centers across most US markets.
Global power demand from data centers is forecast by Goldman Sachs Research to rise 165% by 2030 from 2023 levels.
Goldman Sachs Research forecasts data center demand to grow by about 50% to 92 GW by 2027, with a compound annual growth rate of 17% between 2025 and 2028.

In a downside scenario where demand for AI turns out to be lower than expected, the growth rate for data center demand could be closer to 14%. In a more bullish scenario, the compound annual growth rate could reach 20%.

UK public debt is at 101% of GDP, with a deficit of 5.7% of GDP in 2024, the third-highest in Europe. High borrowing costs and inflation make it difficult for the Bank of England to reduce rates.

The UK has a large share of inflation-linked debt, which is unfavorable given high inflation. The ownership structure of gilts has shifted, with a decline in domestic pension and insurance company holdings and an increase in foreign investor holdings.

To stabilize debt, the UK needs a primary surplus of around 1% of GDP, requiring a fiscal consolidation of around 3% of GDP. The UK has strong fiscal institutions, monetary sovereignty, and a track record of fiscal consolidation.
The UK term premium has risen sharply, with an unexplained part accounting for almost 100 basis points, indicating markets may be over-penalizing gilt yields.
A contractionary budget in November and expected improvement in inflation could lead to more Bank of England rate cuts, potentially causing long-term gilt yields to decline.

European stock markets have transformed over the last decade due to increased competition among trading venues and a shift in market participants. There is a perception of a lack of liquidity due to the fragmentation of trading activity.

A report by the New Financial think tank, in partnership with Goldman Sachs, suggests that European markets are stronger than they might seem, with the total level of addressable liquidity more than twice the volume available on primary exchanges.
European policymakers have been successful in bringing down the cost of trading in the region.
Regulators are working on consolidated tapes in both the EU and UK to improve the perception of liquidity in European markets.
There is likely to be some level of reform around retail investing to increase the currently low levels of retail participation in European equity markets.

Chinese policymakers are confident about achieving around 5% GDP growth this year despite trade war concerns. The official house view calls for a 30% upside in Chinese equities over the next two years.
Chinese tech stocks are about 12% of the market cap in Chinese indices, compared to 35% in US indices, indicating more upside potential.
Emerging markets ex-China are interesting, driven by dollar and rates. A weaker dollar is expected to remain pervasive into the next year.

US housing affordability has declined sharply in the last decade, with the trend accelerating since the pandemic. The costs of mortgage payments and rent have climbed as a share of potential home buyers’ income, rising from below 20% prior to the pandemic to over 30% since 2022.

The US housing market faces a shortage of 3-4 million housing units, equal to about 2% to 2.6% of the current housing stock. Restrictive land use regulations are the biggest constraint on the growth of housing supply.
US rental and homeowner vacancy rates are below those seen in the two decades preceding the crisis, indicating a growing gap between supply and demand.
The home price-to-income ratio in the US has surpassed the peak reached in the 2000s housing boom. Mortgage rates surged to a 20-year high in 2022 and have stayed elevated since.

Asia ex-Japan equities are expected to benefit from fund inflows from richer markets like the US, with a near-30% valuation discount and attractive valuation amid light positioning among investors.
Healthy central bank buying, robust gold ETF flows, and expectations of rate cuts and a weaker dollar underscore a supportive backdrop for gold.
Investment-grade credit remains attractive amid rate cut prospects. Opportunities lie in short-duration (2-3Y) and high-quality (A/BBB) credit.
High yield credit is currently near historical tights due to expectations of impending rate cuts and the perception of a 'Fed put' compressing premiums.

Expectations of subdued growth remain due to tariffs, with selective commodity outperformance driven by strategic importance or supply constraints, particularly in precious metals, rare earth elements, and certain agricultural products like coffee.
Despite US trade deals, Japan faces external headwinds from slowing exports. Resilient domestic consumption, supported by solid wage growth, offers a buffer.
Hedge funds have historically outperformed during policy uncertainty and rate shocks, offering returns uncorrelated to equities and bonds.
The S&P 500, on average, gained 2.3% one month after the start of a shutdown and 6.8% over a three-month period.
Global IG bonds gained 1.2% on average one month after the start of a shutdown and 1.8% over a three-month period.
Gold gained 0.5% on average one month after the start of a shutdown and 0.6% over a three-month period. Given lingering fiscal concerns in the US, gold prices are expected to be well supported.
On a one-month basis, oil prices fell on four occasions during the last six episodes of government shutdowns.
The impact on the US Dollar (DXY) is muted, with the index registering a slight average decline of 0.3% one month after the start of a shutdown and an average gain of 0.4% over a three-month period.
Gold is a key beneficiary of the emerging world order; heightened uncertainty will drive demand in the short-term while de-dollarisation and fiat currency debasement bolster its long-term appeal.
Companies specializing in artillery and 'dumb' munition production stand to benefit as militaries expand jam-resistant weapon systems.

The critical role of space assets points to promising prospects for satellite communication companies, while the drone revolution benefits both drone manufacturers along with air defense system producers.
Humanoids and automation are essential to make reshoring viable, serving as a linchpin for economic resilience and sovereignty in the next era of industrial policy.
