As humanoids become increasingly advanced, their practical applications in real-world settings grow, creating compelling investment opportunities across their value chain.

Gold is an ideal portfolio hedge in the current environment, addressing key risks such as US policy uncertainty, tariff-induced recession/stagflation risk, a widening US fiscal deficit, and heightened geopolitical tensions globally.
Central bank gold purchases skyrocketed to over 1,000 tonnes each year for 2022, 2023, and 2024, more than twice the historical average of 473 tonnes from 2010 to 2021.
Countries are creating 'Strategic Uranium Reserves' for future nuclear power plans, highlighting uranium's importance as a high EROI, non-fossil fuel alternative.
Focus on securing stable uranium supply primarily serving nuclear power plants in China.
Development of the Honeymoon Uranium Project in South Australia is underway.
A US-based uranium mining and exploration company is working on ISR projects in Texas and development assets in Wyoming, Arizona, and Paraguay.
Acquired ISR project Rio Tinto in Wyoming in 2024 for USD175mn.
An Australian-based uranium producer is operating the Langer Heinrich Mine in Namibia.
The world's largest uranium mines are not confined to Kazakhstan, with significant production in Canada and Namibia.
The emergence of small modular reactors (SMRs) offers access to nuclear energy at lower startup costs, with Rolls Royce and NuScale Power developing proprietary designs.
Opportunities span uranium, miners, utilities, and manufacturers, with the greatest potential in early-stage private firms innovating Generation IV reactors and SMRs.
The US is reasserting leadership in nuclear energy by investing in advanced reactors, strengthening supply chains, and reducing reliance on rivals.

Despite the positive outlook for nuclear fission energy, there are concerns about technological breakthroughs in energy production and computing efficiency that could impact nuclear fission technology's growth trajectory.
Nuclear energy is seen as a feasible substitute to mitigate the inflationary consequences of rising energy demand due to AI and digitalization.
There are significant opportunities in private equity with companies working on Generation IV reactor designs and SMR development, which could lead to breakthroughs in safety and scalability.
The US is expected to witness a significant rise in electricity demand over the next decade, with nuclear energy potentially growing to cater for this demand.
Uranium demand is expected to rise by 28% by 2030 and 98% by 2040, mirroring nuclear energy demand.
Industrials recorded the highest inflows this quarter due to re-shoring, increased infrastructure, and defense spending, along with structural tailwinds from energy transition and automation.
Financials experienced significant inflows, supported by high investment visibility, robust dividend policies, and regulatory support for decarbonization and energy security.
Tech experienced significant inflows, with robust performance in AI semiconductors driving double-digit y/y revenue growth between 2024 and 2026.
Favorable grid and renewable proxies like E.ON, Enel, and Iberdrola have performed well, with more potential for Veolia and ENGIE.
Companies with US-based facilities, such as TSMC, Globalfoundries, and UMC, benefit from recent tariff policies favoring domestic production.
Healthcare reported the highest earnings surprises in 2Q earnings, with forward P/E now below the 10Y mean.
Consumer staples reported the highest earnings surprises in 2Q earnings, with S&P 500 expected to deliver strong earnings growth of c.13% in 2025.
Aerospace & defence offer earnings visibility through capital discipline, dividend support, and structural demand, positioning them as key defensive growth plays amid macro uncertainty.
AI infrastructure and content monetization lead growth, with companies like Apple, Lenovo, Dell, and Sony posting strong earnings and profit guidance.
AI agents transform ERP and CRM operations, with Salesforce, SAP, and Alibaba having the highest exposure to these segments.
The global aerospace and defence industry generated USD922bn revenue in 2024, with passenger traffic projected to grow at a 3-4% CAGR over the next two decades.
The semiconductor foundry market remains on a strong growth path, fueled by booming AI demand and advanced node adoption, benefiting industry leaders such as TSMC.
Chinese data centre operators are poised for a re-rating as C-REIT launches unlock value, AI chip supply improves, and hyperscaler demand rises.
The US effective tariff rate has reached a historical high since the 1930s, posing detrimental implications for corporate profitability and domestic consumption.
The street is expecting a 12% US earnings growth for 2026, supported by a 6.2% revenue growth and EBITDA margin expansion of 1.6 %pts to 23.4%.

Global equities currently trade at c.16% above their 10Y average (on a forward P/E basis), with premium valuations driven by developed markets, notably in the US. Markets are vulnerable to acute profit-taking should jobs or inflation data disappoint.

Despite tariff headwinds, the US economy continues to display broad-based resilience, evident from recent ISM and retail sales numbers. The Atlanta Fed GDPNow is forecasting growth of c.3%, in-line with the growth trend seen since 2022.

Earnings growth momentum for the S&P 500 ex-technology is showing signs of tapering after a strong rebound from the Jul 2023 trough. Within the tech space, unprofitable companies are expected to remain in the red through 2026.
The surge in technology investments is expected to sustain earnings momentum, which augers well for the outlook of the sector.
Expectations of impending rate cuts have compelled corporates to delay bond issuance in hopes of lower financing costs further down the road, resulting in a demand-supply mismatch.
The start of a new rate-cutting cycle by the US Federal Reserve will underpin further upside for global equities in the final months of 2025.

Overweight gold, hedge funds, and private assets. Gold has recently broken out decisively above the USD3,400/troy ounce mark as dollar weakness and expectations of Fed rate cut gather pace. Gold prices are expected to hit USD4,450/troy ounce in 1H26.

Add positions to Asia ex-Japan equities amid dollar weakness and light positioning. The region trades at a 28% discount to developed markets, offering a margin of safety for investors during episodes of market sell-offs.

Maintain cautious view on ultra-long bonds; prefer IG credit over govvies. Rising long-term yields and a steepening yield curve are clear signs that investors are losing confidence on the Fed’s ability to control inflation further down the road.
Bonds offer attractive yields at this juncture, notwithstanding its defensive qualities that will help cushion portfolio downside during periods of market drawdowns.

Overweight real assets as US embarks on twin easing (fiscal and monetary); favour private infrastructure and gold. Private infrastructure assets possess inflation-linked revenue structures and contracted long-term cash flows.
Our overweight view on Asia ex-Japan is reaping dividends: on a YTD basis, the region has outperformed developed markets, with robust performance in China, Hong Kong, and Korea.
Gold's gains stand at approximately 57% YTD as central banks and institutional investors increased holdings due to rising de-dollarisation and geopolitical fears.
US equities are rallying in tandem with gold this year, driven by liquidity resurgence and the potential end of quantitative tightening as signaled by Fed Chair Powell.
Asia ex-Japan equities are favored due to a 33% discount to US equities and stronger growth momentum, with earnings poised to grow 17.5% in 2026.
China equities are expected to rally further due to policy stimulus, AI-related capex resurgence, and the 'anti-involution' campaign supporting potential profit reflation.
Investors are advised to stay in quality by favoring A/BBB-rated public credit amid wide performance dispersion and rising distress rates.
Private credit is expected to become a dominant financing model, offering opportunities for investors providing scalable capital solutions.
The Fed is expected to deliver a 25 bps rate cut, reflecting softness in the labor market and supporting further easing by year-end.
Given strong AI-related capex in the current market, today's environment mirrors that of 1995, which augurs well for the resilience of risk assets, particularly US Tech equities.

Historically, a Fed easing cycle usually preceded major recessions with the S&P 500 registering average declines of 3% in subsequent 12 months. However, the Fed easing cycle in 1995 was an exception, with the S&P 500 rallying c.13.9% in subsequent 12 months.
Hedge policy uncertainties with alternatives like gold, hedge funds, and private assets.
Adopt a two-pronged approach in portfolio construction: ride the Fed policy easing wave with cyclicals like US Tech and EM assets like North Asia equities.
The S&P 500 is expected to navigate stable macro conditions and rising policy uncertainties in 4Q25.
Valuations for S&P 500 look rich at a time when tariffs may lead to margin compression for US importers.
Oil prices are expected to stay subdued given OPEC+ plans to unwind supply cuts; downgrade US energy to underweight.
Maintain conviction view on tech companies that are well positioned to ride the new normal of heightened geopolitical and policy tensions.
Macro momentum remains upbeat, with the US economic surprise indicator trending north since end-June, and ISM and retail sales numbers showing no signs of an extreme slowdown.
The Atlanta Fed GDPNow is forecasting growth of c.3% for 2025, in-line with growth trend since 2022, translating into an optimistic earnings outlook with analysts forecasting 12% growth for 2026.
Rising concerns over US fiscal largesse and policy chaos may keep long-term yields elevated despite Fed easing.
The potential erosion of the Fed’s independence, with Trump’s attempt to remove Fed Governor Lisa Cook, threatens the dollar’s status as the world’s reserve currency.
Tariffs are driving up costs and squeezing profit margins for US retailers, with Walmart indicating that US tariffs are impacting earnings.
Investors are advised to position their sector allocation for the Fed easing cycle as the S&P 500 is edging close to the +2 SD expensive mark.
Earnings momentum is showing signs of tapering off, particularly in the S&P 500 ex-technology space, with unprofitable companies expected to remain in the red through 2026.
Rising concerns over US fiscal largesse and policy chaos have kept long-term yields elevated, dampening the effectiveness of Fed monetary easing.
The robust performance for the underweight basket is attributed to the consumer discretionary sector, as US consumers proved to be more resilient than expected.
Technology companies are better positioned to ride the new normal of heightened geopolitical and policy tensions, and investors are advised to increase exposure to US technology.

The USD55bn leveraged buyout of EA, the largest in gaming history, signals confidence in AI’s transformative potential across the sector. The deal, led by Saudi Arabia’s Public Investment Fund, is financed through USD36bn in equity and USD20bn in debt, underscoring long-term strategic commitment to interactive entertainment.

Tencent outperformed peers with 2Q25 games revenue +22% y/y, driven by strong domestic hits and 35% growth in international games. Chinese mobile-first publishers with large-model AI see faster monetisation growth, aided by rising game approvals in Jan-Jul 2025, 19.3% y/y.

AI is accelerating growth and expanding margins in the gaming sector, compressing build times and lowering unit content costs. Approximately 87% of video game developers are using AI to streamline and automate tasks.
AI-powered marketing improves targeting, creatives, and conversion, lowering CPI and lifting ROAS for mobile game acquisition and reactivation.

China has been strategically orienting its economic structure since the onset of the US-China trade tensions, with a focus on technological innovation to develop domestic AI ecosystems and raise self-sufficiency.

Despite a strong rally in 3Q25, the valuation discount between China equities and their Developed Markets counterparts remains significant at 30%-35%, offering downside protection and an attractive proposition for geographical diversification.

A barbell approach is advocated, overweighting high-quality growth names in technology, platform firms, new energy, advanced manufacturing, and beneficiaries of policy pivot such as new retail; and resilient income in Singapore REITs and large China state banks with attractive dividend yields.
Recent US threats appear significant at first, but the actual impact on China is limited due to its gradual decoupling from the US on exports and tech since the start of tariffs.
Asia ex-Japan markets delivered stellar YTD growth of over 15% in 2025, despite global disruptions.
Asia ex-Japan offers a compelling investment proposition with strategic positioning focusing on beneficiaries of structural tailwinds and domestic policy buoyancy.
Indonesia offers attractive macro fundamentals like fiscal prudence and a resource-rich economy, making it a strong candidate to weather global volatility.
Multinationals are increasingly investing in India, establishing local production to cater to the large and expanding domestic market.
China stands to benefit from a rebound in sentiment, led by advances in artificial intelligence and digital infrastructure.
Asia ex-Japan equities trade at deep valuation discounts to global peers, offering a meaningful margin of safety.
The Singaporean government’s SGD5bn Equity Market Development Program has injected a renewed sense of optimism into the region’s capital markets.
We maintain a positive outlook on Japan equities due to Takaichi’s expansionary fiscal stance and commitment to corporate governance reform, evidenced by record share buybacks and M&A activity.

Sector: Information Technology (IT), Defence, Healthcare, Financial Services, Communication Services
Summary: We favour sectors driven by domestic demand and robust earnings, such as technology, defence, healthcare, financials, and communication services, as well as firms advancing corporate reform initiatives.
Sanae Takaichi’s policy agenda, reminiscent of Abenomics, favours fiscal expansion and monetary easing, stimulating Japan equities and boosting growth prospects.
Takaichi’s accommodative monetary policy may weaken the Yen, leading to potential currency volatility.
Apollo Go is expected to enter a phase of accelerated expansion in mainland China and globally, with a 27%/20% y/y expansion in its cloud business in FY25/26F driven by strong AI demand.
Kunlun chip business supports different scenarios for internal use and has won sizable orders from China Merchants Bank and China Mobile, demonstrating strong R&D investment results.
Thailand’s ageing population will support demand for medical services in the long run, with a positive outlook on the healthcare sector.
Trump's Liberation Day tariffs resulted in a weaker dollar, yield spikes, and increased stagflation risks, which the administration did not expect.
Investors should consider stagflation-resistant bonds such as TIPS, capital securities, and short duration credit as stagflation risks rise.
Investors in high yield should exercise caution and remain up in quality in the BB bucket to mitigate risks of credit events and defaults.
TIPS are recommended for fixed income investors to protect against inflationary headwinds, as they excel under conditions of lower growth and higher inflation.
A duration barbell approach with 2-3Y and 7-10Y IG credit is recommended, staying nimble to capture opportunities while navigating an uncertain rates and inflation outlook.
Ultra-long duration TIPS look attractive due to the steep TIPS curve, providing adequate compensation for going long.
Investors are advised to consider 'government+' allocations like MBS, which provide a spread cushion over treasuries and diversification.
Debt levels across DM are rising along with interest rates; concerns over US and Japan’s debt load have resulted in higher long to ultra-long yields.
US spending on interest has reached an annualized 3.2% of GDP as of Apr 2025, with worries about the US debt load (>100% of GDP) causing higher yields.
Japan's debt load (>200% of GDP) has caused a relentless shift higher in ultra-long end JGB yields.
Germany has a benign government debt load at 60% of GDP.
Rate cuts expected across much of Asia, thanks to steady exchange rates.
CGB yields expected to stay steady after promising trade talks; an additional 20 bps cut in the 1Y LPR and a 50 bps reduction in the RRR are expected in 2H.
SGD rates are likely to maintain a sizable discount to USD rates with USD weakness being a more important driver.
Rising global risks from escalating trade tensions are negative for Malaysia’s export-oriented sectors, and the economy is set to miss its current official 2025 growth projection of 4.5-5.5%.
The KTB curve steepened on the back of monetary easing and expectations of increased long-end KTB supply post elections, with more optimism about Korea.

Recent high-profile episodes of bankruptcies and restructuring are masked by an otherwise sanguine credit spread environment in HY bonds. With spreads at all-time tights, and risks on the horizon, the years of HY outperformance may be reaching its limits.

The historical regression of current spreads against 12M forward excess returns paints a daunting picture, potentially producing no excess returns in the coming one-year period, meaning investors would likely see little difference between investing in HY credit and risk-free treasuries.

A recent spate of high-profile collapses has jolted an otherwise sanguine High Yield market with fresh doubt, including Saks Global restructuring bonds, New Fortress Energy, Tricolor Holdings filing for bankruptcy, and the collapse of First Brands.
We see benefits in including diversified strategies in private markets such as distressed debt or opportunistic credit strategies that have the toolkit to capitalize on dislocations.

For public credit, we continue to favour an up in quality stance with IG credit in the A/BBB bucket. We like 'government+' allocations like agency MBS (for additional spread premium) and TIPS (for inflation protection) over nominal treasuries.

For private credit, we turn more neutral on direct lending strategies, preferring to add when spread valuations offer better premiums. Investors should remain with the best-in-class managers who have financial flexibility to navigate more opaque lending strategies.

US Treasuries experienced a jolt as Fed Chair Powell delivered a hawkish cut, reducing the FFR by 25 bps and concluding QT by 1 December. The market recalibrated towards a slower, data-driven policy path.
The Fed outlook has not materially changed, with expectations of two more cuts in the easing cycle. There are high odds of a December cut, but Powell indicated it is not a 'forgone conclusion.'
Asia IG spreads tightened on strong demand from HK and China, while SGD credits remained firm despite pressure on European financials.
Korea SOEs show tightened spreads amid a rate easing cycle, with spreads moving from 100-130 bps to 80-100 bps, resulting in capital gains.
Global bond funds rebounded with net inflows led by US and Europe, while Asia ex-Japan and China continued to see outflows.
The bond market had swung too dovish, pricing in a terminal rate of 3% by end-2026. The market has since removed one cut from the terminal rate pricing and now sees 67% odds of a cut in December.
European financials faced pressure, with French names like BNP, ACAFP, and BPCEGP trading lower due to litigation news, although retail dip buyers later lifted prices.
A strategic combination of private assets and hedge funds can cushion against drawdowns related to rate shocks.
The endowment-styled hybrid model using a fund of open-ended funds approach is more capable of hedging against drawdowns and lifting returns compared to a traditional 60/40 portfolio.
Private and hedge fund markets recover faster from volatility-triggered drawdowns compared to public markets, which can take more than two years to recover from an interest rate volatility shock.
Private credit's floating rate structure should continue to keep yields high at approximately 10.5% as it adjusts with monetary policy and rises in tandem with inflation.
Private infrastructure assets with long-term contracted cash flows and inflation-linked revenue structures can generate inflation-protected distributions for investors.
Private income generators such as private credit, infrastructure, and real estate displayed greater resilience over bonds under inflationary regimes.
Private credit displayed low default rates despite rate stress, aided by low leverage ratios amongst borrowers.
Infrastructure is a balm for stagflation, with contracted cash flows and inflation-linked revenue structures.

Gold target price revised to USD3,765/oz. by 4Q25 due to strong central bank and investor demand amid macroeconomic and geopolitical uncertainty, recession/stagflation risk, and ongoing monetary debasement concerns.
Central bank and investor demand are key to gold's continued rise, providing steady structural demand and maintaining a price floor during times of broad de-risking.
A linear regression analysis found that approximately 600 tonnes of quarterly demand is needed to produce a quarterly increase of 6.4% in gold prices.
The average quarterly central bank and investment demand for gold was roughly 500 tonnes from 2017 to 1Q25, with an assumption of demand increasing to 600 tonnes per quarter being justified.
Gold has been in a consistent bull market for the last three years, driven by geopolitical uncertainty, a widening US fiscal deficit, dedollarisation, and fiat currency debasement.
Continued central bank reserve diversification and robust investor demand are expected to buoy gold in a new era of heightened risk and uncertainty.
Tariffs are driving macroeconomic weakness and prospects of Fed rate cuts, adding to gold's appeal.
US fiscal worries, a softer dollar, and elevated geopolitical risk have contributed to a sharp YTD rebound in gold ETF flows.
Recession and stagflation risk justify increased investment demand for gold, with the US recession probability at 30.5% as of April 2025.
Gold is considered one of the best hedges against recession/stagflation risk, fiat currency debasement, de-dollarisation, and other US policy-related risks.
Gold trading volumes boomed in April by 48% on a m/m basis for both OTC (LMBA) and exchange-traded (COMEX and Shanghai Futures Exchange) activities.

Labour market weakness in the US has revived rate cuts as a catalyst for gold, with futures markets predicting a total of three cuts this year. Gold is trading at USD3,960/oz. and looks set for further gains, driven by the anticipation of further rate cuts by the Federal Reserve.

Fears of 'fiscal dominance' and geopolitical and macroeconomic uncertainty continue to drive investment demand for gold, both physical and ETF. Record gold prices have slowed central bank buying, but buying intention remains strong as fluid geopolitics encourage continued reserve diversification.

Central banks are still strongly in favor of increasing gold allocations, with a record 95% of respondents believing that official global gold reserves will increase over the next 12 months. Central banks have been accumulating gold as a means of reserve diversification since the Russia-Ukraine conflict of 2022.

Gold has gained over 50% YTD, with investment demand likely to remain robust against a backdrop of persistent geopolitical and macroeconomic uncertainty. ETF flows have picked up substantially, although total gold ETF holdings remain approximately 12% below their November 2020 peak.

Signs of labor market weakness and stable inflation in the US saw the Fed implement a 25 bps rate cut in September. Fed funds futures are pricing a 94.6% probability of another 25 bps cut in October and an 87.4% probability of another one in December.

Special opportunities funds display the best risk-return profile under 'rate shock' scenarios, thriving in complex, time-sensitive situations and often stepping in where traditional lenders are constrained. These funds operate across the capital structure and consistently deliver superior distribution profiles due to attractive entry pricing when capital is scarce.

Interest rate volatility and policy uncertainty have driven term premia higher, making private credit an attractive option as borrowers seek flexible financing and investors pursue high yields with floating-rate protection.
A looming liquidity squeeze from Treasury's TGA rebuild and Basel III reforms will tighten bank lending capacity, accelerating demand for alternative lending solutions like private credit.

Private credit has emerged as a natural choice amid structural shifts, offering flexible and bespoke financing solutions that traditional channels can no longer provide. Current yields average c.10–11% with stable spreads of c.200 bps across different rate cycles.

Special opportunities strategy stands out for its ability to capture excess returns during rate shocks, focusing on pricing risk dynamically and negotiating bespoke terms in liquidity-challenged scenarios.

Bitcoin is described as having 'digital scarcity', with a supply cap of 21 million units and a declining rate of production hard-coded in its protocol, simulating finite supply similar to commodity-based money like gold.
Bitcoin's decentralization shifts the burden of policy and design to the users of money instead of the issuers, who would always vote for the preservation of its value.
Bitcoin's proof-of-work mechanism, despite high energy usage, secures the network, making it peerless in terms of scale and track record.
Cryptocurrency trading is highly risky and prices can be very volatile. All investments come with risks and you can lose your entire investment.
Downside price risk for industrial metals is expected when front-loaded demand tapers off and demand destruction sets in.

Despite a bullish demand outlook for corn, uncertainty over tariffs and expectations for a record year for US corn production are expected to put downward pressure on corn prices in the second half of the year.
Gold has significantly outperformed with a YTD performance of +22.2%, buoyed by safe haven demand and de-dollarisation tailwinds.
Cocoa market is expected to enter a surplus for the first time since 2021, with demand destruction settling in and supply forecasted to grow almost 8% in 2024/2025.
Aluminium markets face significant downside risk later in the year due to front-loaded demand and a projected -1.7% decrease in full year 2025 global automobile production.
Commodities are in limbo with tariff-related growth risks and policy uncertainty likely to keep sentiment and fund flows cautious for all commodity sub-sectors other than precious metals.
The Fed cut terminal rates by 25 bps to 4% and will conclude quantitative tightening on 1 Dec, with principal payments from mortgage-backed securities directed into bills.
Despite Powell's comment that December's cut is not a 'forgone conclusion', the market sees c.70% odds of a December rate cut, down from nearly 100%.
The Bank of Japan kept its benchmark rate unchanged at its recent monetary policy meeting, aligning with market expectations despite two dissenting votes.
China-US trade tensions eased following the APEC summit, and South Korea's economy outperformed due to strong domestic consumption and exports.
The IMF expressed concern about the stretched valuation of many equity markets, contributing to a subdued medium-term outlook.
Despite trade tensions and restrictions, capital flows have been dynamic, and investors have reaped strong returns across asset classes.
Expect a 10 bps cut in the 1Y LPR in 4Q25, followed by a 25 bps reduction in 2026, alongside continued liquidity injections from the PBoC.
Taiwan's AI-driven growth remains strong, with information and electronics manufacturing contributing 6.1 percentage points to the economy's 6.7% y/y growth in the first half of 2025.
Outside the AI sector, Taiwan's broader economy is experiencing a slowdown, with non-ICT exports contracting due to US reciprocal tariffs and weak demand from China.
US-China trade conflict reignites with Trump's decision to impose additional 100% tariffs on China, following China's export controls on rare earths and other critical minerals.
China leverages its control over supply chains, particularly rare earths and critical minerals, in response to US tariffs.

Fed Chair Jerome Powell indicated a dovish stance, looking past recent inflation rise and considering halting balance sheet shrinking, with futures market pricing in 25 bps cuts at the final two FOMC meetings this year.
Hopes for a US-India trade deal have revived, with India offering concessions on farm products and increased energy purchases from the US, aiming to finalize the deal by mid-November.
US retail sales are growing at high single-digit annualized rates, indicating continued consumer strength despite weak consumer sentiment.
A historic rise in AI-related spending is offsetting waning public sector growth, contributing to increased economic momentum.
The US economy is expected to grow 1.5-2% in the coming years, driven by private sector capital expenditures.
The US economy presents mixed signals with a softening labor market but robust retail sales.
France's political deadlock, exacerbated by the resignation of Prime Minister Lecornu, may lead to emergency measures to prevent a government shutdown.
Sanae Takaichi was elected president of the Liberal Democratic Party, positioning her to become Japan’s first female Prime Minister.
Thai goods exports are expected to cool in 2H25 and contract in 2026 due to US tariff headwinds.
Vietnamese goods exports, including electronics shipments to the US, proved resilient in September, accelerating to 24.7% y/y due to US tariff exemptions.

Charles Schwab is expected to have resilient performance due to 75% of its revenue being durable in nature, such as net interest revenue and asset management fees. The company has also hired more wealth advisors to meet increased demand amidst market volatility.

Charles Schwab's acquisition of TD Ameritrade has strengthened its position, broadening its reach and enhancing services for retail investors. The acquisition brought scale and best-in-class trading capabilities to the platform.

Charles Schwab is the largest retail broker by client assets, focusing on direct and registered investment advisors. It is well-positioned to expand its 12% market share in the US due to its low-cost and comprehensive offerings and outstanding service culture.
DBS Group has a BUY rating for Charles Schwab with a target price of USD 115, based on a 21x FY26F PE, reflecting improved balance sheet strength and strong investor sentiment led by AI hype.
Risks for Charles Schwab include a global economic slowdown, prolonged high market interest rates, noticeable contraction in market liquidity, and a substantial correction in global asset valuation.

AptarGroup's Pharma segment sales increased by 7% year-over-year, driven by a 9% growth in injectables and an 11% growth in active material science, supported by high-value elastomeric components for biologics, GLP-1, and Annex 1 compliant systems.
AptarGroup's Beauty segment grew modestly at 4% year-over-year, aided by personal care tooling, though full-pack demand remained weak amid tariff-related delays.
AptarGroup's Closures business performed strongly, contributing to overall company performance.

AptarGroup issued 3Q25 adjusted EPS guidance of USD1.53–USD1.61, effectively flat versus prior year EPS of USD1.54, with continued strength in Pharma, particularly injectables underpinned by GLP-1 and biologics trends, along with Annex 1 demand.
Elevated cough-and-cold inventories in Europe are expected to weigh on AptarGroup's Beauty and Closures segments.
AptarGroup has a BUY rating with a target price of USD170, based on 26.9x 25F PE, driven by growing demand for GLP-1 packaging and its pipeline of nasal sprays.
Low consumer spending may drag AptarGroup's Beauty segment, which makes up 34% of total sales, if consumer spending sentiments continue to stay low.

Biological drugs are on the uptrend, contributing to 27.6% of the global pharmaceutical market in 2024 and expected to grow to 37.5% by 2030. AptarGroup has increased its US and France manufacturing capacity to produce more higher value elastomers for biologics injectables packaging, with an expected investment of USD280mn for CAPEX into its pharma segment in FY25.

AptarGroup's 2Q25 earnings beat was driven by demand for high-value pharma components and packaging, with 2Q25 EPS growing 25% year-over-year to USD1.67, surpassing consensus of USD1.60, while revenue climbed 6% year-over-year to USD966mn. Adjusted EBITDA rose 13% year-over-year to USD218mn, lifting the adjusted EBITDA margin by 1.4 percentage points to 22.6%.
Concerns over weaker demand for consumer healthcare drove down AptarGroup's share prices in late July, affecting near-term visibility.

Tsingtao Brewery Company Limited is the second largest brewer in China with around 18% market share in 2024 and a sales volume of 7.5mn KL. The company has a production capacity of 14.19mn KL with 57 breweries across 20 provinces/municipalities in China.
Tsingtao Brewery products are sold in 120 countries and regions worldwide, indicating a strong global presence.
Tsingtao Brewery's main brand 'Tsingtao' and mid- to high-end beer volumes increased by 6.8% and 4.2% year-over-year in 3Q25, outperforming total sales volume growth of 0.3%.
Tsingtao Brewery is expanding its premium lineup with products like Light Dry, Sakura White Beer, Hazy IPA, and wheat series to capture wider demand.
Tsingtao Brewery is leveraging the shift to in-home consumption, with nearly 60% of volume from in-home channels, supporting low-single-digit volume growth in 2026.
Tsingtao Brewery's price discounts partly offset premiumisation gains as consumers remained value-driven.

Tsingtao Brewery has a 12-month target price of HKD 75.00, a market cap of USD 10.20 billion, a dividend yield of 4.32%, a forward P/E of 14.7, a P/Book of 2.39, and an ROE of 15.38% as of 27 Oct 2025.
CMB's retail assets under management (AUM) reached Rmb16tn at the end of 1H25, rising 7.4% y/y, with fee income from wealth management reaching Rmb12.8bn, an 11.9% y/y increase.
CMB is expected to continue steady growth in wealth management fee income in 2H25, but total fee income might be dragged down by weaker-than-expected bank card fees.

CMB's share price performance is more sensitive to China's economic growth and policy support expectations, with potential to outperform peers contingent on a stronger China/HK capital market or supportive stimulus policies.
Risks for CMB include worse-than-expected asset quality deterioration, weaker-than-expected growth in retail loans, and weaker-than-expected capital market and fee income.

Procter & Gamble delivered flat net sales growth and 4% Core EPS growth in FY 2025, with a 1% price increase offset by unfavorable FX across key categories. The performance was supported by targeted marketing investments, product launches, pricing/mix optimization, and expanded use of data analytics and automation in its supply chain.

P&G began FY2026 with 1Q26 organic sales up 2% and Core EPS of USD 1.99 beating consensus by 3%. Net sales grew 3% y/y to USD 22.4 bn, aided by balanced contributions from pricing and mix while volumes remained flat. Segment performance was led by Beauty (+6%) and Grooming (+3%). Free cash flow generation remained robust at USD 4.9 bn, translating into 102% cash conversion, supporting USD 3.8 bn of shareholder returns through dividends and buybacks.

Risks for Procter & Gamble include volatility in input costs, fluctuations in foreign exchange, weak macro and consumption environment, and increased competition or private-label penetration leading to market share losses.
DBS maintains a BUY rating for Procter & Gamble with a 12-month target price of USD 164.0, based on a forward P/E of 23.5x FY26F June PE, reflecting its five-year historical mean 12M forward PE.

Fade the bounce in USD: The US dollar index (DXY) rose for a third straight session as markets pared back some post-FOMC dovish bets. However, the wide dispersion in the 2026 forecasts underscores policy uncertainty, and softer data in the months ahead should push the Fed further dovish, diverging from other G10 central banks. A downside surprise in this week’s PCE data could send DXY back toward 96.3 (Sep low), while resistance near 98.1 (50-DMA) should cap rallies.

High hurdle for SNB to return to negative rates: The SNB is expected to hold its policy rate at 0% this week. While deflation concerns remain, given the CHF’s 14% appreciation against the USD this year, recent inflation has printed above the SNB’s June forecast. Chair Schlegel has also stressed that the bar for reintroducing negative rates is high. We see scope for USD/CHF to test 0.80 (50-DMA) in the near term.

BoJ’s hawkish hold to support JPY: The BoJ kept rates unchanged on Friday, but two dissents and a move to scale back risky asset holdings highlight growing hawkish pressure. The 4 Oct LDP leadership election will be key, though the next PM is likely to prioritize cost-of-living concerns, reinforcing a bias toward tighter policy and a stronger JPY. We expect further USD/JPY downside, with a BoJ hike likely before year-end. Near-term support stands at 146.3 (100-DMA).
US bond yields are expected to rise in the near term due to market expectations adjusting to Fed rate cuts, posing a risk of a rebound in yields.
The gap between Fed projections for one rate cut in 2026 and market expectations for three cuts poses the risk that the fall in 10- and 30-year US bond yields in recent weeks will reverse.
Fed's decision to deliver 'risk management cuts' supports a soft-landing scenario for the US economy, which is positive for corporate bonds, with yield premiums expected to remain well-anchored.
Rotate excessive US equity exposure into Asia ex-Japan equities, adding to positions on any consolidation or pullback.
Add to US technology sector stocks on any modest pullback.
India is seen as a core holding within an Overweight allocation to Asia ex-Japan equities, with a preference for consumer discretionary and financials sectors benefiting from stimulative policy.

Remain Overweight on China equities over the next 6-12 months, with a preference for growth sectors such as technology, communication, and discretionary, supported by technological innovation and government policies.
Fed cuts and ECB pause mean EUR/USD is expected to test 1.20, with improving sentiment and economic stabilization in Germany adding to bullish momentum.
The US dollar index (DXY) is expected to stay range-bound ahead of the September payrolls, with the index likely to trade sideways amid low conviction until the jobs report on 3 October.
USD/CHF is likely to see upside as resistance at 0.801 (50-DMA) looks vulnerable, with potential movement toward 0.807 (4 Sept high) due to broad USD strength after resilient US data.
EUR/USD risks are skewed lower toward 1.16 support, with the pair falling 0.6% and closing below its 50-DMA. The broad USD trend and geopolitical tensions add downside pressure.

The Fed cut rates by 25bps to 4.25% and signaled two more rate cuts in 2025 and another in 2026, meeting market expectations of a September rate cut but falling short of expectations for over 5 cuts by end-2026.
The USD initially moved lower before rebounding higher following the Fed's rate cut and cautious outlook.
The S&P500 fell following the Fed's rate cut announcement.
Within the US, adding to technology sector equities on pullbacks is recommended, as they continue to drive the bulk of earnings growth.
Preference is to add to Asia ex-Japan equities, which should benefit from renewed downward pressure on the USD.

US bond yields had recently fallen in anticipation of significant Fed rate cuts through 2025 and 2026, but the Fed's forecasts cast doubt over meeting dovish 2026 expectations, risking a rebound higher in the short term.
Still-rangebound market inflation expectations make it attractive to add to inflation-protected bonds, helping protect against a more inflationary risk scenario.
Use any USD rebound to add to Emerging Market local currency bonds, adding a source of diversification away from USD bonds alone.
The USD index (DXY) rose 0.3% after US President Trump and China President Xi reached a trade truce. The DXY is likely to test its resistance at 100.
USD/CNH rose 0.2% and is expected to stabilize around 7.12 as trade tensions ease.
USD/JPY rose 0.9% after BoJ Governor Ueda's dovish comments, but faces strong resistance around 156.
EUR/USD fell 0.3% after the ECB left interest rates unchanged at 2% for a third meeting.
Overweight view on Asia ex-Japan equities, supported by de-escalating trade tensions and a weak USD, with a preference for China and Korea equities.
Bullish on Chinese equities due to a positive Q2 earnings season, US-China trade truce extension, and relaxation of US semiconductor export curbs.
Preference for Korea equities within Asia ex-Japan due to favorable policy support and compelling valuations.
India equities remain a core holding with a preference for mid-cap equities due to strong earnings trends.
Japan equities are a core holding, but overexposure should be allocated to other Asia markets due to tariff impacts on earnings growth.
Europe ex-UK equities are a core holding with rising fiscal spending plans offset by a negative earnings revision index.
US equities remain a core allocation, but elevated valuations may limit near-term upside.
Overweight view on EM local currency government bonds due to benign inflation, strong fiscal positions, and a weak USD.
Bullish on short-dated US High Yield bonds due to attractive absolute yields and low expected default rates.
Bullish on equities over the next 6-12 months, supported by fundamentals and quantitative models, despite short-term risks.

The USD rally stalled due to weaker manufacturing data, with the ISM manufacturing index contracting for the 8th consecutive month in October at 48.7. The market implied odds of a quarter-point rate cut in December held steady at approximately 65%.
USD/CNH ticked higher after China’s RatingDog manufacturing PMI slightly missed expectations at 50.6 in October.
The AUD slipped ahead of the RBA meeting, with money markets projecting an unchanged policy rate at 3.6%.
USD/CHF climbed 0.4% after Swiss consumer inflation undershot forecasts, rising 0.1% y/y in October. The pair may trade rangebound near-term, with focus on the Swiss unemployment report.
Another 100bps of expected Fed rate cuts by end-2026 should help offset the impact of tariffs.
US tax incentives in the new fiscal year from 1 October should fuel AI-related investment and revive investment in strategic sectors and growth in 2026.
We expect a 25bps Fed rate cut to 3.75% in December and further 75bps of cuts to 3.0% by end-2026 to support a slowing US job market.
We continue to prefer Asia ex-Japan and US equities and EM local currency bonds.
The recent pullback in gold prices reopens the window to add. We remain Overweight, given long-term diversification demand remains robust.

We maintain an Overweight view on Emerging Market (EM) local currency government bonds, driven by benign local inflation, dovish monetary policy outlook, improvements in fiscal positions and our expectation of a weak USD.
US tech shares are preferred due to earnings growth and AI uptrend.

We prefer China equities within the region, supported by the government’s Fourth Plenum commitments to achieve high-quality growth by increasing services consumption and strengthening its science and technology sector.
We upgrade Europe ex-UK to a Core holding. Favourable economic conditions boost market sentiment, given the strong exposures of the region to cyclical stocks.

We are raising our 3-month and 12-month gold forecasts to USD 4,300/oz and USD 4,500/oz, respectively. We remain structurally bullish on gold, given geopolitical uncertainty and concerns about fiscal policy, the Fed’s independence and de-dollarisation. The latest pullback is seen as an overdue, healthy correction after a record-breaking rally.

Gold’s rally for nine consecutive weeks, which saw prices surge over 30% since mid-August to a record USD 4,381.52/oz on 20 Oct., reflects heightened global economic uncertainty. The freezing of Russian assets by the US and EU after the Ukraine war started in early 2022 was the main structural trigger for gold’s rally. Persistently strong gold demand from EM central banks since that decision provides strong foundations for the rally.

We retain our opportunistic idea on short-duration US high yield (HY) bond, to deliver good risk-adjusted returns. Investors should consider adding to high-quality technology equities on pullbacks. The US HY bond market offers greater transparency, better liquidity, and diversification. Although the yield premium for US HY bonds is on the tighter end of the range, all-in yields remain attractive, especially when the Fed is likely to continue with interest rate cuts.

We remain cautious on US financial sector equities, though, and prefer to focus on the higher quality technology sector. The US technology sector is showing the strongest 2026 earnings growth projection, due to significant AI investments.
Bearish GBP/USD – Slowing inflation, growth to lead to faster BoE rate cuts.
Reduce long-dated US government bonds as the 10-year government bond yield approaches the lower bound of our 3-month range of 4.0%–4.25%.
Add US inflation-protected bonds as inflation pressures are building on renewed tariff headlines.
USD strength constrained by stagflation risk; the USD index (DXY) faces significant resistance at the 200-day moving average (DMA) of 101.2.
China equities remain attractively valued. We expect Beijing to provide ample policy support to counter downside economic risks.
Recommend turning more aggressive on US technology on an additional 5-10% correction.
Risk-off sentiment will likely sustain gold prices to stay 'higher for longer'. Strong momentum could drive gold towards USD 4,100/oz.
Add US equities in tranches, with a tilt towards defensive growth in US healthcare.
Add China equities in tranches, with a tilt towards high dividend non-bank H-shares.
The USD is expected to weaken over the next 6-12 months due to elevated valuations, potential lower rate differentials, and uncertain US trade policy.
The EUR is expected to be a key winner from the weakening USD.
The JPY is expected to be a key winner from the weakening USD.
The GBP is expected to show resilience against the weakening USD.
The CHF is expected to stay range-bound as low domestic rates balance against a weaker USD.
The SGD is expected to weaken.
Global equities are overweight due to policy easing worldwide, strong chances of a US soft landing, and a weaker USD.
Asia ex-Japan equities are upgraded to Overweight, benefiting from strengthening currencies, de-escalating trade tensions, and reasonable valuations.
Emerging Market local currency government bonds are upgraded to Overweight due to benign local inflation, strong fiscal positions, and high real yields.
Developed Market Investment Grade corporate bonds are downgraded to Underweight due to tight valuations and risks of widening yield premia.
US Treasury Inflation-Protected Securities (TIPS) are seen as opportunistically bullish.
Periods of USD weakness are positive for global equity market returns, with non-US equities usually outperforming US equities.
Europe equities remain attractive due to cheap valuations and fiscal spending supporting earnings growth.
US equities are downgraded to a core holding due to expensive valuations and the 'de-dollarisation' narrative potentially leading to outflows.
Gold is seen as a core allocation and a vital hedge against 'de-dollarisation' and market volatility, with central bank demand expected to drive prices higher.
We retain a core holding in US equities, suggesting trimming excessive overconcentration and increasing exposure after a market consolidation.
We have an Overweight view on Asia ex-Japan equities, with a preference for China and Korea equities due to favourable policy support and compelling valuations.
Equities offer more attractive prospects among risky assets, with greater room for upside in a base scenario of an economic soft-landing.
The US 10-year bond yield is expected to remain rangebound, with any rise towards 4.5-4.6% presenting an opportunity to add to exposure.
EM local currency bonds remain an attractive source of diversified returns, with a focus on mid-maturity profiles.
We are bullish on short-dated US High Yield bonds, which offer attractive absolute yields and low expected default rates.
Japan equities are a core holding, with continual improvements in shareholder returns and an economic recovery being supportive factors.
Europe ex-UK equities are a core holding, with rising fiscal spending plans offset by a negative earnings revision index.
Global equity markets benefit from a robust earnings season and an improved macroeconomic backdrop, with reduced trade uncertainty.
US stocks are expected to benefit from Federal Reserve rate cuts amid a slowing economy without recession, with tech stocks outperforming on the AI theme.
We turn neutral on long-term U.S. Treasuries as yields could fall further near term, despite structural pressures driving them up.
US equities are overweight as a softer labor market and slowing growth pave the way for the Fed to cut rates, benefiting stocks.
We are neutral on global inflation-linked bonds, expecting higher medium-term inflation but cooling inflation and growth near term.
We are neutral on China due to trade policy uncertainty and limited policy stimulus, with structural challenges to growth.
We are neutral on short-term U.S. Treasuries, viewing them as akin to cash in tactical views.
We are neutral on emerging markets due to supportive valuations and domestic policy, but geopolitical tensions and global growth concerns keep us cautious.
We are overweight on Japan due to the return of inflation and shareholder-friendly corporate reforms, preferring unhedged exposures.
The AI theme continues to drive US equity performance, with tech sector accounting for over 40% of total return and earnings growth.
We are overweight on U.S. agency MBS, finding income compelling and preferring them to U.S. Treasuries for high-quality fixed income exposure.

AI investments remain a significant tailwind for US macro and earnings growth outlook. Big Tech companies like Alphabet, Microsoft, and Amazon will be investing a combined USD250bn in 2025 on AI-related infrastructure. Recent earnings guidance from Nvidia has allayed concerns on the trajectory of AI investments.
The Middle East will be investing approximately USD100bn in AI-driven investments within this decade.

The strength of the technology sector, highlighted by DeepSeek’s success, bodes well for the outlook and sentiment on capex commitment. AI adoption in key industries is expected to drive efficiency gains, enhancing overall profitability.

European equities continue to offer comparatively higher dividend yields than their US counterparts, reflecting a market culture that prioritises shareholder returns through regular cash distributions. This yield advantage, combined with the market’s defensive profile, positions Europe as a compelling allocation within a diversified global equity portfolio.

IG Credit's absolute yield level is attractive, even with narrow credit spreads. A duration barbell approach with 7-10Y IG credit remains sensible. Investors should time opportunities when extending duration, picking entry points when 10Y UST goes beyond 4.5%.

Ultra-long duration TIPS look attractive. The TIPS curve is very steep, and investors are adequately compensated for going long. Given the level of indebtedness in the US, it makes little sense for debt sustainability if real yields remained positive for the very long term.
Gold remains well bid, with a target price of USD3,765/oz. by 4Q25. The tailwinds underpinning gold’s upward trajectory include US fiscal deficit, de-dollarisation, and geopolitical uncertainties.
Favourable risk-reward remains in gold from central bank buying. Add hedge funds, private secondaries, credit, and private infrastructure for additional sources of alpha returns.
Japan’s ongoing domestic transformation, driven by corporate governance reforms, is likely to support market strength in 2H25, alongside gradual policy shifts from BOJ.
Heightened geopolitical tensions and increasing global defence budgets are driving robust growth in the defence sector, positioning it as a compelling investment narrative.
Technology is transforming the defence industry, unlocking attractive opportunities for investors in cutting-edge defence tech firms.
Valuations in the global defence sector now rival those of tech, with Europe’s defence industry primed for superior earnings growth amid a multi-year rearmament cycle.
Global defence sector offers a compelling investment theme, predicated on structural growth and tactical upside amid an increasingly uncertain geopolitical environment.
Defence companies are favoured for their combination of traditional industrial resilience and growth potential driven by advanced technologies.
Europe’s defence tech contractors, including SMEs, present significant upside potential driven by an urgent need for technological modernisation and integration.

Europe is undergoing a multi-year rearmament cycle, with defence budgets rising sharply and fiscal rules easing to support sustained investment, evidenced by the EU’s EUR800bn 'Rearm Europe' initiative.
Gold stands to benefit from the shifting global order, with short-term demand driven by uncertainty, while de-dollarisation and fiat debasement serve as structural tailwinds over the longer term.

Gold is an ideal portfolio hedge in the current environment, addressing key risks such as US policy uncertainty, tariff-induced recession/stagflation risk, a widening US fiscal deficit, and heightened geopolitical tensions globally.
China is diversifying its foreign exchange reserves through gold-buying, driven by strained US-China relations and Trump's tariff policies.

Humanoid robots and industrial automation are essential for economic resilience and sovereignty, driven by rising labor costs, persistent labor shortages, and stagnant productivity growth, especially in manufacturing, healthcare, and logistics.
Russia's GPS jamming has increased demand for artillery and 'dumb' munitions, benefiting companies specializing in these areas due to their resistance to interference.
The global geopolitical landscape is shifting as the US under President Trump abandons traditional multilateralism, leading to higher NATO spending amid doubts over the credibility of Article 5.
Countries are creating 'Strategic Uranium Reserves' for future nuclear power plans, highlighting uranium's importance as a high EROI, non-fossil fuel alternative.
Focus on securing stable uranium supply primarily serving nuclear power plants in China.
Development of the Honeymoon Uranium Project in South Australia is underway.
A US-based uranium mining and exploration company has ISR projects in Texas and development assets in Wyoming, Arizona, and Paraguay.
Acquired ISR project Rio Tinto in Wyoming in 2024 for USD175mn.
An Australian-based uranium producer operates the Langer Heinrich Mine in Namibia.
The world's largest uranium mines are not confined to Kazakhstan, with significant production in Canada and Namibia.
The emergence of small modular reactors (SMRs) offers access to nuclear energy at lower startup costs, with potential to follow successful innovation S-curves.
Opportunities span uranium, miners, utilities, and manufacturers, with greatest potential in early-stage private firms innovating Generation IV reactors and SMRs.
The US is reasserting leadership in nuclear energy by investing in advanced reactors, strengthening supply chains, and reducing reliance on rivals.
Uranium demand is expected to rise by 28% by 2030 and 98% by 2040, mirroring nuclear energy demand.
Nuclear reactor manufacturers are leading the equity bull run of 2023-2024, with potential for strong future value creation in reactor construction capabilities.
There is a plethora of opportunities in private equity, especially with companies working on Generation IV reactor designs and SMR development.
The US is expected to witness a significant rise in electricity demand over the next decade, with nuclear energy potentially growing to cater for it.

Rising US deficit and debt burden will benefit gold as investors seek the relative safety of bullion amid rising US fiscal profligacy. Gold is expected to be a long-term beneficiary of the OBBB, with prices positively correlated with US indebtedness.
The OBBB will reduce confidence in the sustainability of US debt and should undermine the USD in the long-term due to enlarged fiscal deficits and increased government debt.

The OBBB provides a moderate fiscal boost with the extension of tax cuts, benefiting consumer spending and corporate earnings. However, the eventual impact on equity markets will be muted as most positives are already priced in.
The OBBB's USD3.3tn debt impact steepens the yield curve and precipitates disproportionate risks in ultra-long bonds. Shorter duration bonds can better withstand such dual headwinds.
US energy policy is expected to become more fossil-fuel friendly while the clean energy agenda takes a backseat, posing downside risk for oil prices as supply looks set to grow.

The OBBB delivers a substantial blow to the renewable industry with the phasing out of tax credits on utility-scale wind and solar projects, EV purchases, and residential clean energy upgrades, increasing US reliance on fossil fuels.
Prefer US Tech over broad-base S&P 500 for optimal risk-reward.
Prefer EM equities over DM; EM has outperformed DM by approximately 7.7 percentage points YTD, with more room to rally due to a 32% valuation discount.
Prefer IG credit over HY for optimal risk-reward.
Prefer gold mining equities over gold for optimal risk-reward.
Advocate adding exposure to EM equities, especially in EM Europe and North Asia, which have outperformed EMEA and ASEAN peers, respectively.
High-quality corporate credit in the A/BBB segment offers a compelling risk-reward profile. Adopt a Liquid+ strategy focusing on 2-3Y duration while selectively extending into 7–10Y segment.
Concerns over rising deficits and delayed monetary policy normalization could put pressure on JGBs and JPY if Takaichi is elected as Japan's Prime Minister.
Market participants are pricing in closer to three Fed rate cuts by year-end, reflecting an increased expectation for aggressive Fed easing.
Gold's recent surge past USD3,600/oz. represents a significant milestone with a nearly 40% YTD gain, driven by persistent uncertainty and ETF flows below their peaks.

Past market selloffs on geopolitical shocks in the Middle East tend to be short-lived, with global equities falling c.0.8% in the first two weeks before rebounding c.4.1% on average after three months.
Global equities surged 11% three months after the Red Sea Crisis and Gaza war in 2023.
Maintain exposure to consumer staples due to their inelastic demand, which is underpinned by elevated oil prices.
Maintain exposure to healthcare due to its inelastic demand, which is underpinned by elevated oil prices.
Maintain exposure to the defence industry, which benefits from rising defence spending.
Focus on high quality bonds and steer away from ultra-long duration bonds, given geopolitical uncertainties.
There remains a strong investment case for gold as a portfolio risk diversifier amid geopolitical uncertainty.
Investment-grade (IG) credit has resisted drawdowns in 13 instances of oil and geopolitical volatility shocks over the last 14 years and has proven to be a strong tail-risk hedge in a portfolio.
Gold is a key beneficiary of the emerging world order; heightened uncertainty will drive demand in the short-term while de-dollarisation and fiat currency debasement bolster its long-term appeal.

Humanoids are a long-term panacea for the cost and labour-related challenges from the reshoring movement driven by Trump's 'America First' stance. The global humanoid market is projected to grow from USD2bn in 2024 to USD28.1bn by 2033, potentially replacing over 62.7mn workers by 2050.
The shift towards economic nationalism and 'America First' policies bode well for gold, humanoids, and defence.

As humanoids become increasingly advanced, their practical applications in real-world settings grow, creating compelling investment opportunities across their value chain. The global robotics and automation actuators market is projected to grow at a 10.1% CAGR to USD97.9bn by 2034.

Rising geopolitical tensions and the cessation of US security guarantees are pushing nations to rethink defence and increase spending to bolster their military capabilities. NATO countries (excluding the US) increased military spending at a 13% CAGR from 2022 to 2024.
Big Tech companies like Alphabet, Microsoft, and Amazon will be investing a combined USD250bn in 2025 on AI-related infrastructure, marking significant tailwinds for US equities.
The Middle East will be investing approximately USD100bn in AI-driven investments within this decade.
Global fund managers are currently underweight on US equities amid policy uncertainties, de-dollarisation, and fiscal sustainability concerns.
Investors are positioning themselves more conservatively as the Trump 2.0 agenda takes hold, with defensive positioning expected until clarity emerges on the tariff front.
The high octane rebound in US equities since early-April suggests swift pricing-in of tariff de-escalation and a 'no recession' scenario for the US economy.
Fed policy easing mitigates the underweight call on a 3M basis, with expectations of policy easing and two Fed Fund rate cuts by end-2025.
Fund managers are most underweight on consumer discretionary, downgraded in 2Q25 due to new immigration policies, aggressive job cuts by DOGE, sticky inflation, and weak affordability.
Fund managers are overweight on communication services, healthcare, and financials, which aligns with the view of overweight positioning in these sectors.
President Lee's win ends political gridlock and kickstarts pro-growth reform, propelling the KOSPI up 35% YTD and attracting foreign investors.
Despite the strong rally, Korea equities still trade at a discount; we maintain a neutral stance amid policy driven volatility risk.

AI-related sectors in South Korea are set to benefit from surging global AI chip demand, with government initiatives to become one of the top three AI powerhouses, including a KRW100tn fund to boost AI infrastructure.
Defence system exporters in South Korea are well-positioned to capture rising global demand for military equipment, with exports projected to exceed USD20bn in 2025.
Resilient K-pop and culture sector amid tariff uncertainty supports growth in tourism, with visa-free entry to Chinese group visitors unlocking further growth.
The steel sector in South Korea remains under pressure with its punitive 50% sectorial tariffs left unchanged.
Korean automakers face intensified competition in the US from Japanese and European rivals, eroding their previous price advantage under the US-Korea Free Trade Agreement.
Positive developments in Korea reinforce our conviction in Asia ex-Japan, further strengthening our constructive view on the region.
Global passenger traffic grew 4.0% y/y in July, with industry-wide passenger load factors reaching 85.5%, one of the highest levels on record for the month.
European airlines are expected to sustain stronger earnings momentum into 2026, underpinned by greater pricing power and more favourable supply-demand dynamics.
US airlines restored full-year guidance, signaling improved confidence in the outlook, but a more supportive domestic market backdrop is likely to take time to materialise.
APAC carriers underdelivered on pricing pressures, with yield pressures persisting amid intense competition for Cathay Pacific and major Chinese airlines.
We favour European airlines over US and APAC carriers, as favourable supply-demand dynamics in the region are expected to sustain greater pricing power and stronger earnings momentum.

International Consolidated Airlines Group (IAG) is favoured for its superior margins and promising earnings outlook, underpinned by its dominant position in the premium segment and on the lucrative North and South Atlantic routes.
US airlines, including United, Delta, and American, delivered better-than-expected results in 2Q25, supported by resilient international travel and stronger premium cabin performance.

European legacy carriers, including IAG, Lufthansa, and Air France-KLM, delivered better-than-expected results in 2Q25, supported by resilient international travel and stronger premium cabin performance.
Cathay Pacific reported sharper-than-expected yield erosion, while the three Chinese state-owned carriers continued to underperform due to fierce competition.
Singapore Airlines' operating profit was in line, but its bottom line missed sharply due to Air India losses.
Qantas Airways is favoured for its dominant position in its home market and emphasis on shareholder returns.
CRM and creative software suites are facing disruption from AI-native challengers, leading to erosion of pricing power and commoditisation risks.
IT services firms relying on scale and labour arbitrage are expected to undergo structural margin compression due to AI automation.
Investors should focus on firms that own proprietary data, provide mission-critical infrastructure, and embed AI at the platform level.
Standalone software as a service tools with narrow use-cases are likely to be subsumed into larger platforms.
Microsoft and Meta are highlighted as leaders in AI adoption, with Microsoft providing mission-critical infrastructure and Meta planning to build large AI computer clusters.
Global equities have shown a YTD return of 16.1% and a 1-year return of 18.1%, with a forward P/E of 21.0x.
US equities have a YTD return of 12.7% and a 1-year return of 18.2%, with a forward P/E of 25.1x.
European equities have a YTD return of 9.6% and a 1-year return of 7.7%, with a forward P/E of 15.9x.
Asia ex-Japan equities have a YTD return of 23.9% and a 1-year return of 25.8%, with a forward P/E of 16.4x.
Japanese equities have a YTD return of 11.9% and a 1-year return of 21.9%, with a forward P/E of 17.6x.
The Communication Services sector has a YTD return of 30.1% and a 1-year return of 43.9%, with a forward P/E of 21.5x.
The Consumer Discretionary sector has a YTD return of 9.2% and a 1-year return of 22.4%, with a forward P/E of 25.8x.
The Consumer Staples sector has a YTD return of 7.1% and a 1-year return of -0.7%, with a forward P/E of 20.6x.
The Energy sector has a YTD return of 7.1% and a 1-year return of 4.6%, with a forward P/E of 14.1x.
The Financial Services sector has a YTD return of 20.3% and a 1-year return of 26.6%, with a forward P/E of 14.1x.
The Healthcare sector has a YTD return of 2.2% and a 1-year return of -10.9%, with a forward P/E of 17.9x.

European banks are beneficiaries of a steepening yield curve, with the Europe financial sector delivering strong 12% y/y earnings growth in 2Q25, driving a 30% YTD rally in the STOXX 600 Europe Financials Index.
INFY has significantly expanded its global market share in IT services from 0.8% in 2012 to ~3.5% in 2023, with expectations of continued growth due to effective execution and cost management.
Microsoft is expected to deliver a revenue CAGR of 22.5% over FY26F-28F, with cloud contributing 41% to FY26F group revenue, and an operating margin for cloud at 42% in FY25.
A substantial fiscal stimulus could push the 10Y yield above 3%, further widening the spread and reinforcing profitability for European banks, with credit growth demonstrating resilience.
ASML boasts impressive returns on invested capital with a projected return of about 40%, maintaining high ROIC levels through investments in new lithography technologies.
Trump's Liberation Day tariffs resulted in a weaker dollar, yield spikes, and increased stagflation risks, leading to an aggressive flight from US assets and a rapid selloff in UST yields.
Investors should consider stagflation-resistant bonds such as TIPS, which are government-backed securities that excel under conditions of lower growth and higher inflation.
Investors in high yield (HY) should exercise caution and remain up in quality in the BB bucket to mitigate risks of credit events and defaults.
Bank capital securities are expected to remain resilient due to the steepening of yield curves under tariffs, which implies lower costs of bank liabilities compared to returns on bank assets.
A duration barbell approach with 2-3Y and 7-10Y investment-grade (IG) credit is recommended, with a focus on staying nimble to capture opportunities in an uncertain rates and inflation outlook.
TIPS have outperformed treasuries as inflation surprises on the upside, making them attractive under current conditions.
Investors are advised to consider 'government+' allocations like MBS, which provide a spread cushion over treasuries and diversification over traditional nominal treasury bonds.
Debt levels across DM are rising along with interest rates; concerns over US and Japan’s debt load have resulted in higher long to ultra-long yields.
US spending on interest has reached an annualized 3.2% of GDP as of Apr 2025, with 30Y US yields briefly poking above 5%.
Japan's debt load is over 200% of GDP, causing a relentless shift higher in ultra-long end JGB yields.
Germany has a benign government debt load at 60% of GDP.
Rate cuts expected across much of Asia, thanks to steady exchange rates.
CGB yields expected to stay steady after promising trade talks; an additional 20 bps cut in the 1Y LPR and a 50 bps reduction in the RRR are expected in 2H.
SGD rates are likely to maintain a sizable discount to USD rates with USD weakness being a more important driver.
Rising global risks from escalating trade tensions are negative for Malaysia’s export-oriented sectors, and the economy is set to miss its current official 2025 growth projection of 4.5-5.5%.
The KTB curve steepened on the back of monetary easing and expectations of increased long-end KTB supply post elections.

Markets are pricing five Fed cuts, but without a clear deterioration in jobs, front-end yields may struggle to move lower. The market is pricing in five cuts (123 bps) out to 2026, an addition of almost 40 bps of easing compared to mid-May.
Asian and SGD credit markets remained resilient, with firm demand and tightening spreads despite geopolitical tensions.

Current pricing is appropriate for a modest weakening in the labour market and risks feel broadly balanced after the bounce in yields last night. JOLT job openings jumped to 7.8mn in May against expectations of a small decline.
Asian USD credit markets started the week quietly following the US bombing of Iran, but sentiment rebounded quickly after a ceasefire was announced.
Global bond fund flows turned negative after a sustained inflow streak, but underlying demand remained strong in US and Asian markets, while Europe saw moderating yet positive momentum.
The SGD credit space started the week quietly, but overall sentiment remained positive despite escalating tensions in the Middle East. New issuance activity kept the SGD market busy.
There is a healthy Asian USD pipeline shaping up for another robust week of supply from a slew of Korean issuers if the broader market conditions stay stable.
Strong demand for U.S. bond funds, which attracted USD8.8bn, their second-highest weekly intake of the quarter.
Asia ex-Japan funds drew USD4.5bn—their fourth straight week above USD3bn—driven primarily by China-focused mandates (USD3.9bn) following fresh policy easing.
In the high-yield space, the Vedanta complex rallied after Vedanta secured a c.USD600mn USD loan from various banks to refinance higher-cost debt.

Overall, Asian secondary IG indices tightened by c.5bps, with the Asia iTraxx closing at 75bps (also c.5bps tighter w/w). Asian secondary HY indices tightened by c.23bps, with the Barclays Asia HY (yield) reaching 8.63% (c.2bps w/w).
A strategic combination of private assets and hedge funds can cushion against drawdowns related to rate shocks.
The endowment-styled hybrid model constructed using a fund of open-ended funds approach is more capable of hedging against drawdowns and lifting returns compared to a traditional 60/40 portfolio.
Private income generators such as private credit, infrastructure, and real estate displayed greater resilience over bonds under inflationary regimes.
Private credit's floating rate structure should continue to keep yields high at approximately 10.5% as it adjusts with monetary policy and rises in tandem with inflation.
Private infrastructure assets carry long-term contracted cash flows and inflation-linked revenue structures, making them capable of generating inflation-protected distributions for investors.
Hedge funds can cushion volatility-driven drawdowns, supporting the hybrid portfolio approach.
Private credit displayed low default rates despite rate stress, aided by low leverage ratios amongst borrowers.
Infrastructure vintages amid inflation shock tend to outperform vintages after shock events, highlighting the phenomenon of a vintage-year premium.

Gold is expected to reach USD3,765/oz. by 4Q25, driven by strong central bank and investor demand amid macroeconomic and geopolitical uncertainty, recession/stagflation risk, and ongoing monetary debasement concerns.
Central bank and investor demand are key to gold's continued rise, providing steady structural demand and maintaining a price floor during times of broad de-risking.
A linear regression analysis shows that approximately 600 tonnes of quarterly demand can produce a 6.4% quarterly increase in gold prices, supporting the revised target price of USD3,765/oz. by 4Q25.
Gold has been in a consistent bull market for the past three years, with geopolitical uncertainty, a widening US fiscal deficit, dedollarisation, and fiat currency debasement as key tailwinds.
Continued central bank reserve diversification and robust investor demand are expected to buoy gold in a new era of heightened risk and uncertainty.
Tariffs are driving macroeconomic weakness and prospects of Fed rate cuts, adding to gold's appeal.
US fiscal worries, a softer dollar, and elevated geopolitical risk have contributed to a sharp YTD rebound in gold ETF flows.
Gold is considered one of the best hedges against recession/stagflation risk, fiat currency debasement, de-dollarisation, and other US policy-related risks.
The US recession probability remains at a substantial 30.5% as of April 2025, supporting increased investment demand for gold.
Gold as a percentage of international reserves remains at roughly 21%, well below the historical 54-year average of 29%, indicating room for reserve diversification.
Gold trading volumes boomed in April by 48% on a m/m basis for both OTC (LMBA) and exchange-traded (COMEX and Shanghai Futures Exchange) activities.

Bitcoin is described as having 'digital scarcity', with a supply cap of 21 million units and a declining rate of production hard-coded in its protocol, simulating finite supply similar to commodity-based money like gold.
Bitcoin's high energy usage is a means of securing the network, making it peerless in terms of scale and track record.
Bitcoin offers 'digital scarcity' in a world where money printing has become ordinary policy, making digital monetary scarcity increasingly invaluable.

The US signed the GENIUS Act into law, establishing the first federal regulatory framework for stablecoins, which mandates tokens be backed by high-quality liquid assets and excludes stablecoins from securities law.
Stablecoins are expected to disrupt payments by enabling low-cost transactions and instantaneous settlement worldwide, challenging traditional payment systems.
The GENIUS Act could expand demand for US Treasuries as stablecoin issuers are required to hold reserves in high-quality liquid assets, indirectly making them buyers of US debt.
The development of stablecoin regulations cements the bridge between cryptocurrency and traditional finance, supporting Bitcoin and other cryptocurrencies by facilitating liquidity flow.
The stablecoin ecosystem is projected to grow from over USD200bn today to USD1-2tn by 2030, reinforcing the global status of the dollar.
Traditional payment platforms face challenges from blockchain efficiency, as on-chain dollars will compete for settlement volumes, requiring adaptation to maintain market share.

Private credit has emerged as a natural choice amid structural shifts, offering flexible and bespoke financing solutions as banks face mounting constraints. It is gaining traction as borrowers seek flexible financing and investors pursue high yields with floating-rate protection.
A looming liquidity squeeze from Treasury's TGA rebuild and Basel III reforms will tighten bank lending capacity, with reserves at risk of falling below USD3tn by the end of September.
Special opportunities strategy stands out for its ability to capture excess returns during rate shocks, demonstrating strong outperformance potential and low loss probability.

Private credit strategies rebound sharper and faster from volatility shocks compared to public markets, with current yields averaging c.10–11% and stable spreads of c.200 bps across different rate cycles.
Downside price risk for industrial metals is expected when front-loaded demand tapers off and demand destruction sets in.

Despite a bullish demand outlook for corn, uncertainty over tariffs and expectations for a record year for US corn production are expected to put downward pressure on corn prices in the second half of 2025.
Copper prices face headwinds as US imports are expected to curb, redirecting supply back to Asia and easing regional tightness.
Gold is buoyed by safe haven demand and de-dollarisation tailwinds, significantly outperforming with a YTD performance of +22.2%.
Cocoa market is expected to enter a surplus for the first time since 2021, with demand destruction settling in as cocoa prices have tripled since 2023.
Aluminium markets face downside risks due to declining premiums in Europe and Asia, and falling alumina prices reducing production costs.
Cocoa grindings are expected to fall for a second consecutive year in 2024/2025, indicating consumer reluctance to chase higher prices.
The Fed is anticipated to resume rate cuts next week despite higher August headline inflation as weak labour market data takes precedence.
