ECB left deposit facility rates unchanged at 2%, aligning with expectations, given well-contained inflation around its 2% medium-term target.
Vietnamese authorities have maintained their policy interest rates since mid-2023 and appear to be in no rush to adjust them despite US tariff volatility.
Electronics exports remained robust, continuing to benefit from temporary US tariff exemptions.
Textiles, garments & footwear and wood & wooden products contracted in August despite slower export growth.
Updated forecast sees headline inflation slightly rising to 2.1% in 2025 and 1.7% y/y in 2026, while 2027 inflation is lowered to 1.9% y/y, below the ECB’s target.

The FOMC is heading towards cutting the policy rate due to political pressure and signs of a weakening labor market, leading to expectations of a series of rate cuts in the next 12 months, resulting in much lower short-term US rates a year from now.

Ishiba’s stimulus and wage-growth plans should keep alive the expectations for a BOJ hike at the October meeting, potentially re-establishing monetary policy divergence with the expected Fed cut in the FOMC’s 17 Sep meeting.
Bank Indonesia (BI) lowered rates by a cumulative 100 bps this year, with a further 25 bps cut penciled into the baseline forecast, subject to rupiah volatility.

India's GST rationalization is expected to be demand-accretive, positive for 2HFY26 and FY27 growth, with fiscal impact expected to be modest. Lower GST rates will be positive for growth in the second half of the year and FY27, improving operational efficiency and expanding the size of the formal economy.
The ECB's rate decision will be held on 11 Sep, following the Eurozone’s headline inflation reaching 2.1% y/y in August, within the ECB's target range.

August's US labour report is a key determinant for the Fed's September rate cut, with expectations of nonfarm payrolls staying below 100k for a fourth straight month and the unemployment rate rising to 4.3% from July's 4.2%.
The central bank's commentary ahead of the October/December rate reviews could open the door for an additional -50 bps worth of rate cuts.

A steep US 50% tariff imposition on Indian goods is forcing immediate, broad-based mitigation from authorities, with key segments such as pharma, semiconductors, electronics, and other sectors under Section 232 currently outside the tariff umbrella.
Assuming the 50% tariff rate applies for FY26 and FY27, the impact is likely to necessitate a 50-60 bps reduction in growth forecasts, split between 2H FY26 and FY27 growth.
The Bank of Korea (BOK) left its base rate unchanged at 2.50% for a third consecutive time, focusing on maintaining financial stability amid a buoyant property market and high household debt.

South Korea's real GDP growth rebounded by 0.6% q/q sa in 2Q25 after a 0.2% contraction in the previous quarter, with exports climbing by 5.9% y/y for a second straight month in July, backed by solid semiconductor and auto shipments.

French political uncertainty rose after Prime Minister Francois Bayou's call for a confidence vote on 8 Sep for his unpopular austerity package for 2026, with potential implications for the Eurozone economic outlook.

Most Fed officials now fear tariff-driven inflation more than job market weakness; all eyes are on Powell's Jackson Hole speech for the next move. The minutes suggest that most Fed officials will rally behind Powell’s cautious, data-dependent approach in lowering rates.

July’s data prints signalled an excess supply driven slowdown in 2025; firms are expected to scale back production amid 'anti-volution' campaign. Industrial production growth slowed slightly from 6.4% y/y in 1H25 to 6.3% y/y in 7M25. Emerging sectors such as NEVs, robotics, and tech hardware lost momentum in July.
US transhipment tariffs will hinder China's trade performance, risking prolonged overcapacity and disinflation. Producer Price Index saw the 34th contraction of 3.6% y/y in July accordingly.

We foresee the still-dovish Bank of Thailand cutting its policy rate by another 25 bps to 1.25% by end-2025. There is still room to support any negative growth shocks amid the lack of inflation despite limited policy space.

Bank Indonesia (BI) has cut the benchmark rate by 25 bps to 5%, in line with our off-consensus call. With high frequency activity indicators pointing to a softer growth momentum in 2H25 and a difficult global trade environment, the BI demonstrated a growth supportive stance with a back-to-back rate cut.

Excess supply is particularly apparent in the real estate sector with investment falling (12.1% y/y YTD, compared with -11.2% y/y in June). Developers continue to prioritise completing unfinished projects, while new residential starts remain in double-digit decline.
GE HealthCare is a global market leader in large medical equipment, including CT, MRI, X-Rays, PET, and ultrasound systems, with a strong pipeline supported by increased R&D and AI investments.
DBS has a BUY rating on GE HealthCare with a target price of USD90, based on an 18.5x 25F PE, 0.3 SD above its 5-year average, expecting benefits from AI trends and contrast medium innovations.
GE HealthCare's 2Q25 results beat expectations with EPS growing 13% y/y to USD1.06, and revenue growing 3% y/y to USD5.0bn, led by strength in US imaging and orders across all business segments.
GE HealthCare's service revenue rose 7% y/y while product revenue rose 2%, with the backlog jumping USD2.2bn y/y to a record USD21.3bn, indicating strong forward demand.
Despite cost headwinds from tariffs and FX, GE HealthCare's gross margin remained resilient near 42%, though adjusted EBIT margin dipped 0.7ppts to 14.6%.
Chinese peers may manufacture similar products at lower cost, posing a risk to GE HealthCare's China business as its products are priced at a premium.
Management raised full-year revenue growth guidance to 3% from 2%–3% and lifted adjusted EPS guidance to USD4.43–USD4.63, reflecting improved clarity on tariff headwinds.
FX volatility, geopolitical demand rhythms, notably in China, and persistent margin pressure from tariffs remain risks for GE HealthCare.

The advance unadjusted insured unemployment rate was 1.1 percent during the week ending September 6, a decrease of 0.1 percentage point from the prior week. The advance seasonally adjusted insured unemployment rate was 1.3 percent for the week ending September 6, unchanged from the previous week's unrevised rate.
The advance number for seasonally adjusted insured unemployment during the week ending September 6 was 1,920,000, a decrease of 7,000 from the previous week's revised level.
The 4-week moving average was 1,932,500, a decrease of 10,250 from the previous week's revised average.
In the week ending September 13, the advance figure for seasonally adjusted initial claims was 231,000, a decrease of 33,000 from the previous week's revised level.
Growth investing crosses multiple asset classes and strategies, including venture funds, private equity funds, and hedge funds building crossover funds.
The asymmetry achievable in growth investing is unique, particularly in special asset classes.
There are investible themes in core SaaS and fintech, with a focus on digital transformation in alternatives.
Healthcare technology is experiencing fast innovation curves, with a significant transformation post-COVID.
When the Fed is cutting into a cyclical upswing, typically the outcomes are favorable, and markets tend to go up, especially when the Fed is adding stimulus.

AI has captivated the market's imagination for the past almost three years, with tech stocks performing better, and the biggest and best companies generating and reinvesting capital at unmatched levels.
Japan offers exposure to AI, semiconductors, and defense, making it attractive to stock operators, with a potential political catalyst and shareholder reform story.
Europe's market moment is fleeting, with short cycle rallies requiring precise timing, making it less favorable compared to other regions.
When the Fed is cutting into a cyclical upswing, typically the outcomes are favorable, and markets tend to go up in the absence of recession.
The Fed is expected to cut rates five times over the next couple of years, with three cuts this year, one next year, and one in 2027, which is consistent with the GS view.
AI has captivated the market's imagination for almost three years, and tech stocks, including small-caps, are performing better.
The US is considered the best game in town for investments, with Europe having fleeting moments of short cycle rallies.
Japan offers exposure to AI, semiconductors, and defense, and is seen as a favorable investment due to shareholder reform and potential political catalysts.
Tech optimism remains very high, particularly around AI, with trends in advertising, e-commerce, and public cloud growth accelerating over the summer.
Investors feel that tech trends are broadly sustainable into the final third of the year, with a focus on AI's integration into consumer applications and changing go-to-market strategies.
Investor sentiment is bullish on tech, with elevated valuations but not extreme, and a focus on adoption, monetization, and growth opportunities in AI and consumer apps.

The US equity market faces structural risks due to active retail investor demand and disappointing payroll reports, with underemployment rates and negative revisions, particularly in June, contributing to a downside risk for growth.
The Fed is expected to implement a 25-basis point cut in September, with the possibility of sequential cuts rather than a single 50-basis point cut, depending on CPI data.
There is a strong demand for gold across the franchise, benefiting from a weaker dollar and Fed accommodation.
Emerging markets are seen as structural winners in the current environment, benefiting from a lower dollar and Fed accommodation, with a focus on quality and defensive characteristics.
Western investors have not fully participated in the AI market, which has recently begun to underperform, presenting potential opportunities in the tech sector.
August's 4.3% unemployment rate is the highest since the pandemic, indicating a slowdown in hiring.
Consumer sentiment fell to 55.4, reflecting concerns about the economic outlook.
The U.S. economy added just 22k jobs last month, well below expectations of 75k, with 27k jobs removed from the past two months.
Core inflation is at 3.1%, well above the Fed's 2% target, which could spark concerns about inflation.
The FOMC meeting is upcoming, with markets weighing economic data on the Fed's balance of risks.
The Fed's decision to cut rates could initially cheer stock and bond markets, but longer-term implications are unclear.
Real assets like infrastructure could help investors build portfolios resilient to both a growth slowdown and an inflation speedup.

The FOMC decided to lower the target range for the Fed funds rate by 25bps to 4.00-4.25%, with expectations of additional 50bps of cuts for the rest of this year and one 25bp cut in 2026, bringing the target range to 3.25-3.50%.

The Bank of Canada delivered an expected 25bp rate cut, with market expectations for additional rate cuts this year pared, and pricing for a follow-up cut at the October meeting having fallen to around 50%.
The BoE is widely expected to keep its Bank Rate unchanged at 4.00%, with gilts trading within ranges ahead of the BoE decision.

IndoGBs rallied upon BI decision to cut the policy BI Rate by 25bps, with a pro-growth, pro-liquidity stance and expectations of additional 50bps of cuts bringing the policy rate to 4.25% by end-2025.

Our bullish view on USTs up to 10Y tenor panned out well. We expect 2Y UST yield to trade in a range of 3.55-3.65%, while maintaining our year-end forecast of 3.60%. We continue to see 10Y yield in the range of 4.00-4.20% as fair, and we maintain our year-end forecast of 10Y UST yield at 4.10%.

FOMC decided to lower the target range for the Fed funds rate by 25bps to 4.00-4.25%, in line with expectations. We continue to expect one 25bp Fed funds rate cut each at the October and at the December meeting this year, followed by one 25bp cut in Q1-2026, which will then bring the target range for the Fed funds rate to 3.25-3.50%.

Fed funds futures last priced additional 44bps of cuts for the rest of the year, and 72bps of cuts for 2026. The latest dot-plot points to additional 50bps of cuts for the rest of this year, and one 25bp cut in 2026.

SEP economic forecasts revised GDP forecasts upward for 2025, 2026, and 2027. Unemployment rate forecast stays unchanged for 2025 but has been revised down by 0.1 percentage point each for 2026 and 2027. Core PCE inflation forecast stays unchanged at 3.1% for this year but has been revised up to 2.6% for 2026 from 2.4% prior.

UST yields were lower by around 20bps month-on-month at most tenors, in line with a mild downward bias. The fall in the 10Y yield was mostly driven by lower real yield. Near-term range for 10Y yield is at 4.20-4.34% while year-end expectation stays at 4.10%.

A 25bp cut at September FOMC is seen as the more likely outcome by the market. The median dot on the June dot-plot pointed to two 25bp cuts this year. Up to 75bps of cuts are expected before year end, followed by one 25bp cut in Q1-2026, totaling four 25bp cuts.

Four members voting for a hold was more hawkish than expected. BoE’s assessment on inflation and the labour market remains consistent with a gradual and careful approach. One 25bp Bank Rate cut is expected in Q4-2025, and another 25bp cut in Q1-2026. The central bank is expected to slow QT pace for the next 12-month period.
The RBA’s assumption of OCR for their forecasting exercise is based on market implied rate. One additional 25bp cut is expected in Q4, which will bring the OCR to 3.35% by year end.
SGD liquidity may stay flush as S$NEER stays near the top end of the band. Instead of chasing short-end SGD OIS lower, the 2Y bond/swap spread provides relative value.
HIBORs have turned more responsive to additional liquidity drainage. Investors appear more cautious as reflected by spot USD/HKD not recovering back to near 7.8500 level.

USD is expected to trade softer as the Fed potentially resumes easing and US exceptionalism fades. The USD has room to fall as long as broader risk-on sentiment stays intact and growth conditions outside the US remain supported.
30-day Fed funds futures have fully priced in a 25 bp rate cut at the September FOMC meeting, with a total of 2.5 cuts expected this year.

Markets remain concerned about tariff-driven inflation, and any unexpected rise could unsettle USD bears. Conversely, if inflation figures come in cooler than expected, speculation about a larger or more aggressive Fed rate cut path may increase, potentially putting further downward pressure on the USD.

Key risks impacting SGD include sectoral tariff developments, broad USD trend, and fluctuation in RMB. Economic fundamentals in China appear soft, but domestic equities and RMB fixing have been strong, which can have spillover effects on SGD.

The interplay of RBA still cutting rates, tariff uncertainty, and a softer USD trend are factors affecting AUD. Bias remains for AUD to trend gradually higher as USD softness returns and markets refocus on potential Fed cuts.
USDJPY is expected to trend lower due to a softer USD and Fed-BoJ policy divergence, with key resistance levels at 147.66, 148.70, and 149.40.
UST yields fell for a second day, with the 2Y UST yield at 3.5% and the 10Y yield at 4.00-4.15% considered fair.
The US Dollar weakened with the DXY falling 0.69% despite stronger-than-expected US economic data.
Fed funds futures are pricing in a total of 155bps of additional cuts in the cycle.
The 2025 median dot is expected to stay unchanged at 3.000%, with a potential 50bp cut discussion or vote split seen as dovish.
SOFR hit 4.51%, above the SRF rate of 4.50%, with bank reserves likely to stay above USD3trn.
There is two-way risk in terms of potential FX intervention, although operations at either side do not look imminent.
3M HIBOR is expected to settle around 3% level, with inflows into HKD assets preventing liquidity from loosening materially.
UST yields edged lower overnight in the absence of major catalysts, with the 10Y UST yield at 4.00-4.15% appearing fair.
The bar appears high for a surprise at the FOMC meeting that is dovish enough to lead to another leg of rally at short-end USTs.
Bank reserves stood at USD3.16trn and reverse repos at USD383bn as of 10 September, with expectations that bank reserves are likely to stay above the USD3trn mark.
The Fed’s Standing Repo Facility (SRF) was tapped at USD1.5bn, the highest since its establishment, indicating a focus on funding rates as bank reserves have started to fall.
US Treasury has been rebuilding its cash positions since early July, with the TGA balance at USD708bn as of 12 September, USD142bn away from the target of USD850bn.
Downside to CNH rates is limited as onshore short-end repo-IRS remain floored at 1.50%, with no yield premium in CNH rates over CNY rates.
SGD rates underperformed USD rates by falling less, resulting in mildly less negative SGD-USD rates spreads, with 2Y bond/swap spread (OIS – SGS yield) at below -20bps level providing relative value.

A 25bp rate cut is fully priced in, and if the 2025 median dot points to one additional rate cut for the rest of the year, yields may correct higher, but market expectation for a third cut this year remains.

If the 2025 median dot points to two additional cuts, it will reinforce current market expectations but may not lead to a further rally in USTs, given the market is pricing a terminal rate of around 3%.
Bank of England is expected to keep its Bank Rate unchanged at 4.00% this week, with focus on forward guidance and whether the 'gradual and careful approach' wording will be maintained.
The Bank of Canada is expected to cut its policy rate by 25bps to 2.50%, with a 25bp cut being 86% priced by CAD markets.
Bank of Japan is expected to keep BoJ Target Rate unchanged at 0.50%, with a 34% chance of a 25bp hike by the October meeting.

UST yields initially dipped upon CPI and jobless claims data, with the 10Y yield dipping below the 4% mark briefly, last at 4.028%. The 2Y UST is likely to consolidate around the yield level of 3.50-3.60%, while the range for the 10Y is seen at 4.00-4.15% as investors await the FOMC decision next week.

Demand at this week’s coupon bond auctions was solid, with the 30Y coupon bond auction garnering a bid/cover ratio of 2.38x versus 2.27x prior, and indirect accepted slightly higher at 62.0% versus 59.5% prior.
Fed funds futures continued to price 28bps of cut at the September FOMC meeting, and a total of 72bps of cuts for this year, reinforcing market expectation for the Fed to resume rate cuts next week.

Relative value in EUR remains attractive against the dollar, especially under views that the USD is likely to trade softer in the remainder of the year. Resistance for the pair is at 1.1750, 1.1830 levels; support sits at 1.1650/60 levels and 1.1570.

Bunds appear to be lacking impetus to rally, especially when OATS have stabilized of late. In terms of asset swap, pick-up was last at around SOFR+30bps at 10Y Bunds, at around SOFR+108bps at both 10Y OATS and 10Y BTP. ASW pick-up at 5Y OATS at around SOFR+73bps is wider than that at 5Y BTP.
ECB kept the three key ECB interest rates unchanged as widely expected. The central bank revised upward GDP growth and inflation forecasts for 2025 and 2026.

Fed funds futures pricings were little changed as a slew of rate cuts have already been in the price. A print of 0.4%MoM or 3.2%YoY CPI may trigger some correction in 2Y UST and the expected fed funds rate trajectory, but not enough to dent September rate cut expectation.

The August CPI outcome is unlikely to put a near-term rate cut back onto the table. CPI fell by 0.4% YoY in August, due to decline in food prices and the high base a year ago. PPI fell by 2.9% YoY in August, indicating easing deflationary pressure at production front.
Short-end repo-IRS may remain floored at 1.5% level. Further downside to offshore CNH rates may be limited, especially given that there is no yield premium in offshore rates.

PBoC is expected to stay supportive of liquidity, amid heavy NCD maturity, with CNY300bn of outright reverse repos and CNY 300bn of MLF maturing later in the month. 12M AAA NCD rate was last at 1.68%, versus 12M implied CNY rate at 1.55%, not providing much pick-up for foreign investors.
The ECB is seen at or nearing the end of the easing cycle. EUR OIS priced a 26% chance of a 25bp cut before year end. Bunds appear to be lacking impetus to rally while OATS stabilised of late.
A softer-than-expected US PPI reinforced market expectations that the Fed will resume cutting rates next week, with 27bp of cuts priced for next week.
10Y yield rose back to trade near year-end expectation of 4.10%; near-term range is at 4.00-4.20%.
DXY bears await inflation prints; USD rebounded post-BLS with DXY last at 97.70 levels, showing a mild bearish bias.
UST yields rebounded from intra-day lows to end 3-7bps higher in a flattening manner, as investors looked past labor market statistics.
Demand at the 3Y coupon bond auction was solid, stopping through at 3.485% despite recent richening, with a bid/cover ratio of 2.73x.
Markets have fully priced in a 25bp cut for Sep FOMC and nearly 3 cuts for 2025; focus shifts to PPI and CPI releases.
USDJPY fell to a low of 146.31 amid BoJ policy divergence; sell rallies strategy suggested.
SNB President Schlegel noted the high bar for reintroducing negative interest rates, suggesting policy easing is not on the table for the upcoming meeting.
Conventional bond auction garnered IDR79.55trn in bids, with IDR24.45trn awarded versus an indicative target of IDR27trn.
The valuation of 2Y UST with yield at 3.49% appears stretched and is likely prone to upside surprises in inflation with PPI and CPI to be released.
The 10Y yield broke below the year-end expectation of 4.10%; near-term range is now seen at 4.00-4.20%.
Prospects of Fed cutting rates soon and a softer USD are driving gold prices towards 3600 levels, with strong official-sector demand led by China and other EM reserve managers.
DXY was last at 97.40 levels with daily momentum showing a mild bearish bias while RSI fell.
Markets are pricing in nearly 3 Fed cuts for 2025, with a focus on PPI and CPI data this week.

Gold's appeal is enhanced by the Fed's rate cut cycle, broader portfolio demand as a store of value, and hedge against inflation and geopolitical risks. XAU was last at 3647 levels with bullish momentum.
USDSGD continued its momentum to trade softer, with support at 1.2810/30 levels and resistance at 1.2920, 1.2950 levels.
The fall in the 10Y UST yield was driven by lower real yield, rendering the curve little changed on the day. The 10Y yield is now at the year-end target with a near-term range of 4.06-4.20%.
Market prices a total of 146bps of cuts between now and end-2026, with the 2Y yield at 3.52% roughly in line with such pricings. The 2Y UST is prone to upside surprises in inflation prints.

Fed funds futures more than fully price a 25bp cut at the September FOMC meeting, and price a total of 69bps of cuts for this year. The base-case remains for a total of 75bps of cuts this year, with a 25bp cut at each of the remaining FOMC meetings.

USDSGD traded lower post-NFP as USD fell. The pair was last at 1.2848 with a slight bias to the downside but likely still caught in the recent range. Support at 1.2810/30 levels and resistance at 1.2920, 1.2950 levels.
DXY was last at 97.90 levels. Daily momentum is not showing a clear bias while RSI fell. Risk skewed to the downside.

USDJPY gapped higher with political uncertainties in Japan potentially hindering BoJ from normalising policy. JPY weakness due to politics should reverse when uncertainty fades. Fed cutting rate should help bring USDJPY lower amid Fed-BoJ policy divergence.

Fed funds futures fully price a 25bp cut at September FOMC meeting, and a total of 60bps of cuts this year; between now and end-2026, 140bps of cuts are priced. 2Y UST yield at 3.58% level reflects these Fed funds rate pricings which is on the dovish side; further downside to short-end yields appears limited.

10Y UST yield has fallen by a cumulative 10bps over the past two days, mainly driven by lower real yield as market reacted to labour market data. Year-end expectation for 10Y UST yield remains at 4.10% and remains for the 2s10s segment to settle at around 50bps.

DXY slipped, alongside softer UST yields, last at 98.20 levels. A much softer-than-expected data print will be needed to alter the rate cut narrative and weigh on USD. Conversely, if the print comes in much stronger than expected, then the USD may see another spike.

USTs are probably more prone to upside surprises in payrolls than the September Fed funds futures contract is. It likely requires material upside to payroll to dent market expectation for a September cut.

ADP employment disappointed at 54k (vs. 68k expected), jobless claims rose and ISM services employment remains in contractionary territory. Consensus looks for a 75k print (below 6m average of 81k) for NFP.
Japan wages continue to rise (4.1% y/y vs. 3% expected). The rise in wages remains consistent with Governor Ueda’s comments and this keeps hopes for policy normalisation alive.
Fed funds futures fully price a 25bp cut at the September FOMC meeting, indicating softness in the US labor market.
July JOLTS job openings fell to 7.181 million, the lowest in 10 months, while layoffs rose to 1.81 million, indicating a softening US labor market.
The Fed Beige Book noted that seven Districts reported firms hesitant to hire due to weaker demand or uncertainty, with two Districts reporting increased layoffs.
The 10-year yield fell to 4.213%, nearing the lower end of the recent range of 4.20-4.33%, reflecting concerns over the US labor market and inflation.
DXY last at 98.40 levels with daily momentum turning mild bullish, but the rise in RSI moderated, indicating 2-way risks with resistance at 98.70 and 99.60, and support at 98.00/20 and 97.50.
USDJPY rose sharply to 149.14 before easing to 148 levels, with daily momentum and RSI indicators not showing a clear bias, indicating 2-way risks ahead.

US yields retraced from session highs to end the day 3-4bps higher. 2Y UST yield at 3.65% is in line with market pricings of Fed funds rate, although such pricings are on the dovish side, bond valuation does not appear overly stretched. 10Y UST yield has moved higher away from the lower end of the 4.20-4.33% range.
USD rose overnight but remains within range. Markets are awaiting US data releases that may frame expectations for Fed easing trajectory.
The gilt curve bearish steepened, but the sales of GBP14bn of 10Y gilt attracted solid demand of GBP141.2bn, indicating support for the bond with a bond/swap spread at below -50bps.
USDCNY fix was set higher for a 3rd consecutive session, with the pair last at 7.1425. Bearish momentum on daily chart shows tentative signs of moderation while RSI rose from oversold conditions.

CNY rates focus on medium-term liquidity maturities. PBoC is expected to turn supportive of liquidity again after this week. Short-end repo-IRS remain floored at 1.5% level before the next outright interest rate cut.
Markets are pricing in an 87% chance of a 25bp cut at the September FOMC and a total of about 55bps cut this year.
USD continued to trade near recent lows as markets brace for more US data this week, in the lead up to FOMC (17 Sep).
USD has room to fall as long as broader risk-on sentiment stays intact and growth conditions outside US remain supported.
Softer-than-expected data print may potentially change the rate cut narrative and weigh on USD.
Fed's Waller sees potential for a jumbo 50bp cut if the labour market weakens further, currently backing a 25bp cut.
USDJPY traded lower but still caught in a subdued range, with focus on US data for implications on UST yields and USD.
China's RatingDog PMI manufacturing swung into expansionary territory (50.5 for Aug), pointing to a still-solid global growth.
US exceptionalism fades, and our house view looks for 3 Fed cuts for 2025.
USD decline is not a linear extrapolation and likely to be bumpy, driven by data surprises, market expectations of Fed cut, and tariff risks.
Bias remains for AUD to trend gradually higher as USD softness returns and markets re-focus on potential Fed cut in the months ahead.
If USD weakness can extend deeper, then USDSGD may even be exposed to further downside risks.

Gold pushed above 3500 briefly, with bullish momentum on the daily chart intact and RSI in overbought conditions. Immediate resistance is at 3500/10 levels, with potential upside towards 3750, 3890 levels. Support is at 3380 (21 DMA), 3355 (50 DMA).
USD is a touch firmer, but softer data prints this week may weigh on USD. DXY last at 97.80 levels with mild bearish momentum on the daily chart intact.
USDSGD firmed, tracking mild USD upticks. 2-way risks likely as markets await US data releases that may frame expectations for Fed easing cycle.
USDCNH shows tentative signs of moderation with RSI rising from oversold conditions. Inverted hammer observed may point to a short-term bullish reversal.

HIBORs have mostly adjusted upward, but HKD liquidity will stay tight amid dividend payments and potential equity inflows. HKMA Discount Window was tapped at HKD1.4bn, with o/n HIBOR fixed 64bps higher at 4.65%.
2Y UST yield at 3.62% reflects Fed funds rates expectation, with limited downside to the yield.
10Y UST yield is near the lower end of the trading range of 4.20-4.33%.
USD stays backfooted as core PCE came in lower, with DXY last at 97.70 levels showing mild bearish momentum.
Fed funds futures last priced an 87% chance of a 25bp cut at September FOMC meeting; a total of 142bps of rate cuts are priced by end 2026, which is on the dovish side.
USDJPY continued to trade modestly softer, with bearish momentum on the daily chart remaining intact.
BoJ member Nakagawa's comments were considered hawkish, suggesting the mechanism by which wages and prices rise moderately will be maintained.

UST yields slid and market pricings added to rate cut expectations upon the payroll release. Fed funds futures more than fully price a 25bp cut at the September FOMC meeting, and price a total of 70bps of cuts for this year. Our base-case remains for a total of 75bps of cuts this year and one 25bp cut in Q1-2026.

At 10Y UST, in the downward move since the recent high on 18 August, a lower real (TIPS) yield explained around 95% of the move. This underlines the view that the subdued growth outlook will probably constrain the steepening momentum across the 2s10s.

US Treasury has been rebuilding its cash positions. TGA balance was last at USD669bn as of 4 September, USD181bn away from quarter-end and year-end target of USD850bn. The increase in TGA balance has been matched with decreases in reverse repos and in bank reserves.
Bank reserves will likely stay at above USD3trn when US Treasury replenishes cash to target. Reserve repos stood at USD369bn and bank reserves at USD3.18trn as of 3 September.

SOFR has been grinding higher gradually, and was last fixed at 4.41% on Thursday, compared to IORB at 4.40%. While SOFR had been fixed higher than IORB occasionally, it happened mostly at month-end/quarter-end.

Enthusiasm surrounding the ongoing artificial intelligence (AI) boom, supported by Oracle’s announcement of a substantial guidance increase amid several large new AI deals, helped lift major US stock indexes.

Most major U.S. stock indexes finished the week higher ahead of the Federal Reserve’s September 16–17 monetary policy meeting, at which the central bank is widely expected to lower short-term interest rates.
U.S. investment-grade corporate bonds outperformed Treasuries, and primary market activity was generally well received, according to T. Rowe Price traders.
High yield bonds posted gains, advancing amid the increasing likelihood of an upcoming interest rate cut.
The CSI 300 Index recorded its biggest one-day advance since March, driven by domestic tech companies that are perceived to be major beneficiaries of Beijing’s push for homegrown technology.

Mainland Chinese stock markets rose as bullish sentiment among retail investors persisted. The onshore benchmark CSI 300 Index rose 1.38% and the Shanghai Composite Index advanced 1.52% in local currency terms.
Ample domestic liquidity has fueled a rally in China’s stock markets since April.
U.S. Treasuries generated positive returns during the week, with long-term yields generally decreasing.
Revised figures for Japan’s GDP growth over the second quarter of 2025 showed that the economy expanded more than indicated by the initial reading, with GDP growing 2.2% on an annualized basis.
The S&P 500 experienced its largest one-day fall since April due to renewed trade tensions between the US and China, interrupting a rally that had taken the index's year-to-date rise to over 15%.
Gold climbed to over USD 4,000 an ounce for the first time, lifting its gains in 2025 above 50% amid geopolitical tensions.
China accounts for around 70% of the world's global supply of rare earths, giving it a strong position in trade negotiations with the US.
Political turmoil in France has widened the French-German bond spread to its widest so far in 2025, with an elevated risk premium on French bonds likely to persist.
Japanese equities are trading at a 29% discount to the S&P 500, with the Topix at 15.9 times forward price-to-earnings, supported by a sizable economic support package and dovish monetary policy.
China's tech sector is favored due to still-attractive valuations and robust medium-term prospects.
The post-pandemic inflation shock and rate-hiking cycle produced a generational reset higher in bond yields, supporting a strong multiyear outlook for global fixed income.
U.S. Treasuries have provided a hedging role for portfolios in every recession dating back to World War II, given the historical inverse correlation between stocks and bonds.
The Trump 2.0 fiscal package is likely to widen U.S. deficits and debt beyond prior policy projections, with overall fiscal space remaining constrained.
Central banks have more space to cut rates than in the decade before the pandemic, with the Fed expected to cut rates to around neutral, roughly 3%.
Valuations point to a lower probability of equity outperformance over fixed income, partly because the outlook for high quality fixed income is as good as it has been in a long time.
Emerging markets are building upon their demonstrated resilience, with global diversification offering superior volatility-adjusted returns to single country portfolios.
Credit markets offer abundant opportunities but also specific risks, demanding careful sector and asset selection and a value-driven investment approach.
Active management can enhance bonds’ role as a hedge through yield curve positioning, with a core PIMCO thesis that yield curves will re-steepen over the secular horizon.
Investors are paid to build resilient portfolios in fixed income, advocating seizing the yield advantage in high quality bonds rather than chasing equities at elevated valuations.
The June 2023 Economics Spotlight examines investment in commercial real estate and other nonresidential structures in the US.
The economic outlook for Japan remains mixed, with inflation being the biggest challenge it faces on the road to economic recovery.
Defaults rise, the value of the securities falls, leading to a general decline in asset values and higher risk spreads in the US.
Equity prices have soared, boosting the wealth of relatively upscale households in the US.
The personal consumption expenditure deflator was up 2.7% in August, the fastest rate of growth since February, indicating inflationary pressures in the US.
China dominates the shipping industry, with 29% of container ships on the water made in China and 70% of ships on order to be made in China.
The delinquency rate on credit card debt has risen sharply in the past two years, indicating potential systemic problems in the US consumer finance market.
Personal income in the US increased by $95.7 billion (0.4 percent at a monthly rate) in August 2025, according to estimates released by the U.S. Bureau of Economic Analysis.
Disposable personal income in the US increased by $86.1 billion (0.4 percent) in August 2025.
Personal consumption expenditures in the US increased by $129.2 billion (0.6 percent) in August 2025.
The personal saving rate in the US was 4.6 percent in August 2025.
The US Treasury yield curve steepened amid the federal government shutdown and market reactions to new threats from Trump.
The US dollar fell versus major currencies following new threats from Trump and the ongoing government shutdown.
The S&P 500 fell by 2.7%, its steepest one-day drop since early April, due to new threats from Trump.
Fed policymakers signalled a greater focus on the risks from a slowing labour market than from rising inflation, with expectations of inflation running at 3% by year-end.
We expect gradual key rate cuts from Fed policymakers to around 2.5-2.75% by mid-2027, with inflation expected to remain above 3% in 2026.
On 8 October, the price of gold rose above $4,000 a troy ounce for the first time, extending a rally.

Investing in emerging markets is likely to be subject to higher-than-average volatility due to a high degree of concentration, greater uncertainty, less liquidity, and greater sensitivity to changes in market conditions.
The US Treasury yield curve steepened, indicating a positive sentiment towards U.S. Treasuries.

The prospect of weeks of political upheaval and the potential for a shift in the power balance of Japanese politics is likely to weigh on Japanese stock markets.
European stocks and US futures rose on 13 October after Donald Trump appeared to take a more conciliatory tone towards China.
The US Federal Reserve's rate-setters will factor in the delayed consumer price index (CPI) report, scheduled for release on 24 October, into their policy meeting on 28-29 October.

Small caps are expected to outpace large caps in 4Q and through 2026, with small caps trading ~30% below large caps (0.72x P/E vs. 0.99x historical avg.) and implying ~8% annualized returns over the next decade versus <1% for the Russell 1000. Mid caps are also historically cheap relative to mega caps.
Within small caps, Value looks especially well-positioned as Fed cuts rates, signaling a shift into 'Recovery' in the U.S.
Earnings growth is broadening beyond mega caps and is now extending into small caps.

Our EMFX carry sentiment indicator, Chief Investment Strategist Michael Hartnett’s cash rule, and the Asia equity team’s Risk-Love Sentiment indicator suggest a pullback is likely.

Baupost Group manages around $22 billion on behalf of individual and institutional clients, investing in a wide range of asset classes including publicly and privately traded debt, equity securities, real estate, and private equity.
Baupost's investment process is bottom-up, situation by situation, focusing on finding bargains even in expensive markets.
Baupost emphasizes the importance of psychology in their investment process, focusing on downside protection and avoiding panic during market downturns.
Baupost constructs portfolios with a focus on downside protection, catalysts for value realization, and diversification across asset classes, countries, and industries.
Private credit seems vulnerable as it has not been tested with rising rates and unusual bond market behavior, suggesting the US may have reached a peak in debt capacity.
Baupost's portfolio is balanced with private investments at 22-24%, credit in the 20% range, equities in the low 20s, real estate in the mid-teens, and cash in the low teens.
Baupost uses hedges and holds some cash to provide buying power during market downturns, focusing on senior debt instruments for downside protection.

The new markets for AI data are emerging, indicating growth opportunities in AI-related sectors.
The Autonomous Vehicle Market is forecast to grow and boost ridesharing presence, driven by advancements in AI technology.

In the US, spending on the construction of data center infrastructure has tripled over the last three years, with occupancy rates near record highs for third-party leased data-centers across most US markets.
Goldman Sachs Research forecasts global power demand from data centers to rise 165% by 2030 from 2023 levels.

Goldman Sachs Research forecasts data center demand to grow by about 50% to 92 GW by 2027, with a compound annual growth rate of 17% between 2025 and 2028. In a bullish scenario, the growth rate could reach 20%.
Ashok Varadhan believes the US is the place to be, with underlying fundamentals and a new rate cutting cycle likely to continue, normalizing policy rates around 3%.
Investors are diversifying away from fiat into assets like gold and Bitcoin, driven by concerns over monetary debasement.
Ashok Varadhan suggests staying invested but using low volatility to protect with convexity, such as buying index puts on equities and calls on the dollar.
Ashok Varadhan is comfortable staying invested in the AI trade, viewing the investment in new technology as a long-term trend beyond Q4 2025.

Goldman Sachs Research raised its forecast for the MSCI EM index to reach 1,480 over the next 12 months, up from 1,373 as of October 9, 2025. EM equities have rallied for nine straight months and are forecast to rise through the end of 2025.
EM currencies have strengthened against the US dollar and are forecast to keep outperforming, driven by strong performance of EM stocks and a weakening US dollar.
Goldman Sachs Research sees investment opportunities in Korean equities, with 70% of stocks trading below book value. Ongoing reforms to company governance could drive up equity prices.
South African stocks are expected to gain as rising gold prices help mining companies, and inexpensive domestic sectors could benefit from potential growth recovery and lower borrowing costs.
Indian equities have lagged other emerging markets due to high valuations, higher-than-expected tariffs, and challenges for the software sector from increased US H1B visa prices.

The German government plans to increase infrastructure spending by €500 billion over the next 12 years, which is forecast to boost economic growth above its potential and above the prevailing consensus among economists, according to Goldman Sachs Research.

Goldman Sachs Research expects German GDP growth to rise from 0.3% this year to 1.4% in 2026 and 1.8% in 2027, significantly above the 0.8% potential rate of growth and the consensus among economists surveyed by Bloomberg.
German defense spending is expected to rise from 2% of GDP in 2024 to 3.5% in 2029, with overall public spending anticipated to rise by 2.2% of GDP by 2027.
The German government's increased spending on infrastructure and defense is forecast to boost economic growth above its potential and above the prevailing consensus among economists.
Goldman Sachs Research economists Niklas Garnadt and Jari Stehn have turned notably more optimistic on Germany’s economic outlook after years of economic underperformance.
If the US government shutdown lasts for a few weeks, the market expects another rate cut at the next Fed meeting, as it is the path of least resistance.
A prolonged US government shutdown could lead to a negative quarter in Q4 due to the impact on federal and possibly private activity, affecting the Fed's ability to make informed decisions.
Without additional data, the Fed is still likely to cut rates again, which aligns with current market expectations.

Goldman Sachs leaders at the Communacopia + Technology conference highlighted that AI's impact on the business landscape is expected to widen significantly, with hundreds of use cases as verifiable as software development, suggesting a positive outlook for AI-driven technology investments.

Goldman Sachs Research Chief Economist Jan Hatzius stated that replacing low- and mid-value-added white-collar tasks with AI should eventually boost annual productivity growth by 1.5pp per year, indicating a positive sentiment towards AI's impact on productivity.

Jan Hatzius mentioned that over the decade, 6-7% of total employment might be displaced by AI, but the impact on unemployment is expected to be small as people will be absorbed into other industries, assuming economic growth continues.
The S&P 500 is up 35% off the lows in April with a realized volatility of ten, resulting in a dirty Sharpe ratio of 3.5, which is extremely high historically.
The average stock in the S&P and NASDAQ has been 3.5 times more volatile than the index itself, while the index has remained relatively calm.
The market has been more volatile to the upside than the downside over the last month, with the average rally on the S&P being about 50 basis points and the average selloff about 30 basis points.
The year-end 5% out-of-the-money put in S&P costs 1.2%, and with a look-back function, it costs 1.7%, adding 50 basis points to guarantee the highest close between now and the end of the year.
The absolute level of index volatility is extremely low, with clients who are underweight the index buying calls to protect their business.

Retail option buying has affected the volatility surface, and fundamental investors with large single stock positions can use the move in call skew to their advantage by buying the December 105% call and selling the 115% call.
Over half of the names in the S&P top 100 have inverted call skew, which is rare as usually implied volatility is lower further out from at-the-money calls.
Historically, October has had two extremely volatile periods in 1987 and the great financial crisis, but when these are removed, October is less of an outlier in terms of calendar volatility.
The concentration in the S&P is high, with the top ten names, mostly mega-cap tech, making up almost 40% of the index, and several AI catalysts are expected throughout October.
Goldman Sachs Research predicts gold prices to rise to $4,000 per troy ounce by the middle of next year, driven by strong structural demand from central banks and easing from the US Federal Reserve.
95% of surveyed central banks expect global gold holdings to increase in the next 12 months, with none anticipating a decrease.

Gold is more likely to exceed Goldman Sachs analysts’ forecast rather than undershoot, with speculative positioning in derivatives markets by large investors like hedge funds significantly bullish on gold.
Emerging market central banks remain significantly underweight gold compared to developed market counterparts and are gradually increasing allocations as part of a broader diversification strategy.
Goldman Sachs Research expects central banks to continue accumulating gold for another three years, with emerging market central banks having significant demand for gold.
European equities have seen significant outperformance, especially on a dollar basis, led by small-caps and value stocks.
The US equity market has been led by large-caps and growth stocks.
European corporate earnings season saw stocks move almost four times their average daily move.
There have been significant upgrades to European GDP estimates for this year and next, while US GDP estimates have been cut.
There is a contrarian opportunity to be long on the German domestic economy and fiscal spend beneficiaries, with a decent pick up in real incomes and household disposable income.
Investing in China AI presents a great opportunity as both the stocks and the investment cycle are in a much earlier period of their life cycle.

Global investment is flowing into nuclear technology companies and the broader nuclear supply chain, with countries mastering advanced nuclear technologies gaining energy security and commercial relationships.
Japan has restarted 14 reactors since Fukushima and committed to increasing the share of nuclear energy in the country’s energy mix.
The nuclear energy renaissance is underway, driven by generational technological breakthroughs, geopolitical competition, and the need for clean, dense, reliable power.
President Trump’s promise to quadruple nuclear power generation by 2050 may reassert American leadership in nuclear power, despite competition from countries like China and Russia.
The US has the world’s strongest private fusion sector, with 25 of the world’s 45 private fusion companies and around 80% of the over $6 billion in equity investments into private fusion companies.
Investor interest in SMRs is growing, driven by the conviction that nuclear energy will be crucial to powering ambitions in AI.
Goldman Sachs Research suggests diversifying portfolios with gold and other commodities to protect against unexpected tail risks in financial markets.
Commodities can protect portfolios against trade volatility and are likely to have a more strategic role going forward, with government control fluctuating.
China controls more than 90% of the refining capacity for rare earth minerals, which are essential in developing artificial intelligence.
Energy commodities meet the criteria for hedging portfolios as they are part of critical supply disruptions and have a direct weight in the inflation basket.
Gold surged as investors sought value outside the system during periods of reduced central bank credibility and pronounced government spending.
Consumer sentiment fell to 55.0 in October.

The Tokyo Stock Exchange announced that companies with P/B ratios below 1x must disclose and implement plans to improve capital efficiency or face potential delisting. Share buybacks soared 90% y/y in FY2024, and M&A activity hit a record $232 billion in the first half of 2025.
J.P. Morgan Investment Research projects the TOPIX P/E ratio could rise to 17–18x (from 16x currently) and ROE could reach 11% (up from 9%) by 2028.

Korea launched the Corporate Value-Up program in early 2024, with buybacks and shareholder proposals ramping up under the new market-friendly administration. Executed buybacks YTD have already exceeded total 2024 levels at $11 billion, contributing to MSCI Korea’s 65% rebound YTD.
The U.S. dollar's depreciation this year is tied to expected Fed rate cuts and fiscal concerns, not evidence its reserve status is under threat.
We stay overweight U.S. stocks, supported by lower rates and the AI theme.
In Europe, we have favored Spanish equities, up nearly 60% this year in U.S. dollar terms, according to MSCI data.
In emerging markets, we prefer local currency debt, such as 10-year Brazilian government bonds that offer a yield of nearly 14%, according to Bloomberg data.
We are neutral on short-term U.S. Treasuries, viewing them as akin to cash in our tactical views.
We are neutral on long-term U.S. Treasuries as yields could fall further with a softening labor market giving the Fed space to cut rates.
We are neutral on global inflation-linked bonds, seeing higher medium-term inflation but cooling inflation and growth may matter more near term.

Bitcoin is seen as a potential diversifier of risk and return alongside gold.
A softening labor market gives the Fed space to cut rates, supporting U.S. stocks and the AI theme.

We remain bullish on Chinese equities due to a positive Q2 25 earnings season, further extension of the US-China trade truce, and relaxation of US curbs on semiconductor exports to China.
We remain Overweight on Asia ex-Japan, with a relative preference for China and Korea equities, and expect Asia ex-Japan equities to outperform global equities amid fading tariff headwinds.

Japan equities are a core holding, but any overexposure should be allocated to other Asia markets as tariffs hurt Japan’s earnings growth.
Europe ex-UK equities are a core holding as rising fiscal spending plans are offset by a negative earnings revision index.

We remain bullish on equities over the next 6-12 months, supported by fundamentals and quantitative models, but remain vigilant about seasonality, policy, and investor positioning risks in the near term.
We have an Overweight view on EM local currency government bonds, expecting high real yields due to benign EM inflation and strong fiscal positions, with a weak USD providing a tailwind.
We are bullish on short-dated US High Yield bonds, which offer attractive absolute yields and low expected default rates.
We expect the US 10-year bond yield to trade within the 4.00-4.25% range in the next 6-12 months, with 5-7-year bond maturities offering the best risk-adjusted returns.
Dovish comments on the Fed policy trajectory are likely to push the USD lower.
Caution around tariff-driven inflation could sustain the USD rebound.

USD/CNH likely rangebound, with bearish bias, ahead of producer inflation data.
Gold rally faces test as geopolitical tensions ease; potential consolidation towards USD 3,950/oz level.

Risk-off sentiment will likely sustain gold prices to stay 'higher for longer', with strong momentum potentially driving gold towards USD 4,100/oz.
US technology sector is recommended for more aggressive investment on an additional 5-10% correction.
China equities remain attractively valued, with expectations of ample policy support from Beijing to counter downside economic risks.
Adding US inflation-protected bonds is recommended as a hedge against potential long-term inflation risks amid rising protectionism.

CNH downside is expected on policy expectations amid renewed trade tensions.

Medium-term investors under-allocated to gold should consider adding exposure on any pullback below USD 3,900.

US technology sector's 2026 earnings growth forecast has been revised up to 21.9% from 18.7%.
The Fed is expected to cut rates by a cumulative 100bps over the next 12 months to support a US soft landing.
USD weakness is expected to extend towards 95 over a 6-12-month horizon.
We favor global equities and gold over bonds and cash, supported by policy easing in most major economies.
Gold prices are expected to surpass USD 4,000/oz over the next 12 months, supported by Fed rate cuts, seasonal demand, and geopolitical concerns.
We are Overweight Asia ex-Japan equities, expecting benefits from earnings growth and a weak USD.
We maintain an Overweight in EM local currency government bonds, driven by a benign local inflation and rate cut outlook, improvement in fiscal positions, and a weak USD.
US equities are raised to Overweight, supported by resilient earnings growth and Fed rate cuts.
We are adding to our gold allocation, expecting gains to extend due to central bank reserve diversification demand and a weak USD.

The EUR and JPY are expected to be key winners from a weaker USD, with the GBP also showing resilience.
In Asia, the SGD is expected to weaken.
We are Overweight global equities due to policy easing worldwide, strong chances of a US soft landing, and a weaker USD supporting risky assets.
Asia ex-Japan equities are upgraded to Overweight, benefiting from strengthening currencies, de-escalating trade tensions, and reasonable valuations.

Gold is seen as a core allocation due to expected central bank demand and its role as a portfolio diversifier.
US equities are a core allocation, supported by a soft landing of the US economy and a weaker USD, with a preference for cyclical financial, technology, and communication services sectors.

We remain bullish on Chinese equities due to a positive Q2 earnings season, further extension of the US-China trade truce, and relaxation of US curbs on semiconductor exports to China.
Asia ex-Japan equities are expected to outperform global equities amid fading tariff headwinds, with a preference for markets with favorable policy support, including China and Korea equities.
US equity market valuations are close to a decade high, limiting near-term upside.
Global equity markets benefit from a robust earnings season and an improved macroeconomic backdrop, with reduced trade uncertainty.

Gold and silver benefited from heightened policy uncertainty, with gold also supported by healthy central bank buying and robust ETF flows.
Despite tariff headwinds, US technology companies have reported strong earnings and robust forward guidance, underlining their resilience.
Asia ex-Japan equities are expected to benefit from fund inflows from richer markets like the US, trading at a near-30% valuation discount.
Fed rate cuts have commenced amid political pressure and labor market softening, but strong economic activity and tariff-driven inflation risks remain.
Investment-grade credit remains attractive amid rate cut prospects, with opportunities in short-duration (2-3Y) and high-quality (A/BBB) bonds.
Hedge funds play an important role in diversification, outperforming during volatility and providing non-market-directional returns.
Oil price outlook is muted amid fears of a supply glut.
Global growth is expected to slow due to tariff policy uncertainties, but Fed's rate cuts, Trump's fiscal stimulus policies, and AI-related capex will stave off recession in the US.
Asia ex-Japan equities are positioned for a turning point, with compelling investment propositions driven by structural tailwinds and domestic policy buoyancy.
The S&P 500, on average, gained 2.3% one month after the start of a shutdown and 6.8% over a three-month period.
Global IG bonds gained 1.2% on average one month after the start of a shutdown and 1.8% over a three-month period.
Gold gained 0.5% on average one month after the start of a shutdown and 0.6% over a three-month period. Given lingering fiscal concerns in the US, gold prices are expected to be well supported.
On a one-month basis, oil prices fell on four occasions during the last six episodes of government shutdowns.
The impact on the US Dollar (DXY) is muted, with the index registering a slight average decline of 0.3% one month after the start of a shutdown and an average gain of 0.4% over a three-month period.

Gold is a key beneficiary of the emerging world order; heightened uncertainty will drive demand in the short-term while de-dollarisation and fiat currency debasement bolster its long-term appeal. Central bank gold purchases skyrocketed to over 1,000 tonnes each year for 2022, 2023, and 2024.

Companies specialising in artillery and 'dumb' munition production stand to benefit as militaries expand jam-resistant weapon systems. The critical role of space assets points to promising prospects for satellite communication companies, while the drone revolution benefits both drone manufacturers along with air defence system producers.

Investors should prioritise building resilience in their portfolios by holding gold, which addresses key risks under the new world order: US policy uncertainty, tariff-induced recession/stagflation risk, a widening US fiscal deficit, and heightened geopolitical tensions globally.

Humanoids and industrial automation are essential to make reshoring viable, serving as a linchpin for economic resilience and sovereignty in the next era of industrial policy. The global humanoid market is projected to grow from USD2bn in 2024 to USD28.1bn by 2033.

The US fiscal deficit is expected to grow under Trump, with gold correlated with US indebtedness, which is expected to rise. The US debt problem is becoming a global issue, with the potential for a rapid weakening of the dollar and spiking bond yields as the haven status of Treasuries is questioned.
Countries are creating 'Strategic Uranium Reserves' for future nuclear power plans, highlighting uranium's importance as a high EROI, non-fossil fuel alternative.
Focuses on securing stable uranium supply primarily serving nuclear power plants in China.
Focuses on the development of the Honeymoon Uranium Project in South Australia.
US-based uranium mining and exploration company with ISR projects in Texas and development assets in Wyoming, Arizona, and Paraguay.
Acquired ISR project Rio Tinto in Wyoming in 2024 for USD175mn.
Australian-based uranium producer operating the Langer Heinrich Mine in Namibia.
World's largest uranium mines are not confined to Kazakhstan, with significant production in Canada and Namibia.
Technological breakthrough with SMRs offers access to nuclear energy at lower startup costs, with potential to follow S-curves of past innovations like mobile phones and electric vehicles.
Opportunities span uranium, miners, utilities, and manufacturers, with greatest potential in early-stage private firms innovating Generation IV reactors and SMRs.
The US is reasserting leadership in nuclear energy by investing in advanced reactors, strengthening supply chains, and reducing reliance on rivals.
Uranium demand is expected to mirror nuclear energy demand, with a 28% rise by 2030 and 98% by 2040.
Nuclear reactor manufacturers are leading the equity bull run of 2023-2024, with markets attributing strong future value creation to reactor construction capabilities.
Industrials recorded the highest inflows this quarter due to re-shoring, increased infrastructure, and defense spending, along with structural tailwinds from energy transition and automation.
Financials experienced significant inflows, supported by high investment visibility, robust dividend policies, and regulatory support for decarbonization and energy security.
Tech sector experienced significant inflows, with AI driving tangible revenue impact in gaming and enterprise software, and semiconductor growth underpinned by AI and node transitions.
Utilities sector outlook remains constructive with favorable grid and renewable proxies like E.ON, Enel, and Iberdrola performing well, and potential growth for Veolia and ENGIE.
Healthcare reported the highest earnings surprises in 2Q earnings, with forward P/E now below the 10Y mean.
Real estate forward P/E is now below the 10Y mean.
Aerospace & Defence offer earnings visibility through capital discipline, dividend support, and structural demand, positioning them as key defensive growth plays amid macro uncertainty.

The semiconductor foundry market is set to maintain its growth trajectory, with revenue expected to reach USD160.3bn in 2025, marking a 17% y/y increase, driven by strong demand for advanced node wafers and AI-related packaging.
Fabless chipmakers are expected to register revenue/earnings growths of 31.4%/39.2% over the next 12 months, driven by their focus and exposure to AI.

Oil majors mostly beat expectations in 2Q as street estimates were conservative given the lower commodity price environment, with shareholder returns remaining a priority through healthy dividends and share buybacks.
Ping An offers the highest dividend yield among Chinese insurance space at >5% with strong VNB momentum from its bancassurance channel, supporting superior profitability.

Gold emerged as a beneficiary of renewed tariff fears and debasement fears, surging 1.03% on Friday and closing the week at USD4,017.79/oz. It has been in a consistent bull market since the beginning of 2024, driven by rising uncertainty and spiraling US debt.

Despite US tariffs, FDI inflows to ASEAN have been stronger than expected, showing the region as a key destination for supply chain reconfiguration. Vietnam remains the top performer with major commitments such as the USD1bn CTP.

With market concentration at unprecedented levels, diversification through global equity portfolios offers the illusion of diversification as exposure is skewed towards concentrated mega caps. A multi-asset portfolio with exposure to global equities, global bonds, and alternatives is recommended.
A 50% allocation to equities is recommended, with overweight exposure to US Tech and Asia ex-Japan (AxJ). The US Tech rally is underpinned by strong earnings and rising AI capex.

Investors should stay up in quality with A/BBB credit, given better relative value in IG absolute yields vs high yield. Portfolios with government bond allocation should consider 'government+' securities such as TIPS and MBS to add alpha.
Select hedge fund strategies have historically outperformed broad equity markets, preserved capital, and cushioned drawdowns during periods of policy uncertainty and sharp interest rate repricing.
Given strong AI-related capex in the current market, today's environment mirrors that of 1995, which augurs well for the resilience of risk assets, particularly US Tech equities.

Historically, a Fed easing cycle usually preceded major recessions with the S&P 500 registering average declines of 3% in subsequent 12 months. However, the Fed easing cycle in 1995 was an exception, with the S&P 500 rallying c.13.9% in subsequent 12 months amid the arrival of the Internet.
Hedge policy uncertainties with alternatives like gold, hedge funds, and private assets.
Hedge policy uncertainties with alternatives like gold, hedge funds, and private assets.
