Adopt a two-pronged approach in portfolio construction: (a) ride the Fed policy easing wave with US Tech and North Asia equities, (b) hedge policy uncertainties with alternatives like gold, hedge funds, and private assets.

Adopt a two-pronged approach in portfolio construction: (a) ride the Fed policy easing wave with US Tech and North Asia equities, (b) hedge policy uncertainties with alternatives like gold, hedge funds, and private assets.

Rising US deficit and debt burden will benefit gold as investors seek the relative safety of bullion amid rising US fiscal profligacy. Trump's 'One Big Beautiful Bill' (OBBB) will reinforce de-dollarisation and fiat currency debasement tailwinds for gold.
The OBBB's enlarged fiscal deficits and increased government debt reduce confidence in the sustainability of US debt, undermining the USD in the long-term.
The fiscal boost from OBBB benefits consumer spending and corporate earnings, but the impact on equity markets will be muted as most positives are already priced in.

The OBBB's USD3.3tn debt impact steepens the yield curve and precipitates disproportionate risks in ultra-long bonds. A barbell strategy is recommended, overweighting 2-3Y and 7-10Y duration segments.
US energy policy under OBBB becomes more fossil-fuel friendly, with downside risk for oil prices as supply looks set to grow.

The OBBB delivers a substantial blow to the renewable industry with the phasing out of tax credits on utility-scale wind and solar projects, EV purchases, and residential clean energy upgrades, increasing US reliance on fossil fuels.

The high octane rebound in US equities since early-April suggests swift pricing-in of tariff de-escalation and a 'no recession' scenario for the US economy. Expect binary outcomes for the negotiation between US and China, with 'favourable' trade deals leading to indiscriminate rally in risk assets and conversely, a re-escalation translating to acute market selloffs.

The US cyclicals vs defensive ratio suggests that investors are positioning themselves more conservatively as the Trump 2.0 agenda takes hold. Expect this trend to persist until clarity emerges on the tariff front. The failure to reach a 'beautiful trade deal' with China will mean that the 'no recession' scenario is off the table and until then, portfolios are expected to be defensively positioned.

For the coming quarter, a cautious stance is maintained on the S&P 500 amid policy uncertainties and ongoing paring down of US exposure as de-dollarisation and fiscal sustainability concerns take hold. Global fund managers are currently underweight on US equities, likely to persist given concerns on Section 899 of Trump’s budget bill.

Downside risks to US earnings forecast; defensive portfolio tilt amid uncertainties. Valuation for the S&P 500 has rebounded to 23x and above its five-year average, based on forward earnings growth of 11%, which is considered unrealistic.

Investment focus on AI-related infrastructure by Big Tech and the Middle East mark significant tailwinds for US equities. Big Tech companies like Alphabet, Microsoft, and Amazon will be investing a combined USD250bn in 2025 on AI-related infrastructure.
Fed policy easing is expected, with the central bank likely to cut the Fed Fund rate twice by end-2025, providing a tailwind for US equities, particularly growth plays.
Fund managers are most underweight on consumer discretionary, downgraded in 2Q25 amid concerns around new immigration policies, aggressive job cuts by DOGE, sticky inflation, and weak affordability.
Stay overweight on technology, financials, and communication services, and underweight on consumer discretionary.

The US has threatened to impose additional tariffs of up to 100% in retaliation to China’s decision to tighten export controls on rare earths, leading to a negative market reaction with the S&P 500 and NASDAQ falling 2.7% and 3.6% respectively.

Despite recent market corrections, there is a constructive view on global technology due to strong secular trends in AI adoption, cloud migration, digital transformation, and automation, with technology trading at a forward PE/G of 2.3x.

US semiconductor giants like Nvidia, AMD, TI, Qualcomm, Broadcom, and TSMC have reduced their revenue exposure to China from nearly 40% in 2018 to approximately 22% in 2024, diversifying their operations and revenue mix.
The M&A environment remains dynamic with deals like AMD acquiring Xilinx and Broadcom acquiring VMWare, providing an additional boost to the technology sector's outlook.

The 'sovereign AI' trend is gaining traction as governments expedite AI deployment to strengthen self-sufficiency, focusing on leading-edge technology, semiconductor capacity, AI infrastructure, cloud networks, application innovation, cybersecurity, and uninterrupted power generation.
FY25 adjusted constant currency earnings growth guidance remains intact though YTD progress remains mixed for major packaged F&B players.

Mondelez and Kraft Heinz are guiding for negative earnings growth of -10% and -15% respectively due to challenges like limited ability to pass through cocoa cost increases and volume attrition in a soft consumer environment.

Mondelez and PepsiCo are tracking behind guidance YTD, but management expects stronger momentum in 2H25 with Mondelez planning price increases and cost control, and PepsiCo planning to rightsize its North America snacks business.
Kraft Heinz and PepsiCo possess enduring brands and are more likely to see a valuation re-rating should appropriate corporate actions materialize.
Keurig Dr Pepper's acquisition of JDE Peet's and Kraft Heinz's plan to split into two listed entities were perceived negatively by investors due to high leverage and shareholder disappointment.
Coca-Cola is exploring a sale of its underperforming Costa Coffee business, which is expected to refocus the business on higher-growth core brands and free capital for more value-accretive uses.
PepsiCo faces short-term US headwinds, but its valuation is near all-time lows, and strong brands offer clear value-unlock potential.
Kraft Heinz fundamentals remain weak, but downside risk looks limited given the 6% yield and potential post-split valuation re-rating.

China has been strategically orienting its economic structure since the onset of the US-China trade tensions, with a substantial decline in exports to the US, now constituting merely 10% of total exports in 3Q25, down from approximately 20% prior to 2019.
China's gradual decoupling from the US on exports and tech since the start of tariffs limits the actual impact of recent US threats, reinforcing a constructive outlook on the Chinese market.

Investors should resist extrapolating political noise into investment outcomes as the rhetoric on tariffs or export controls does not alter the secular trajectory of the region’s fundamentals and ecosystems, with the technology supply chain firmly anchored at the heart of the global AI roadmap.

Policy stimulus in sight as added macro uncertainties from trade salvos could prompt Beijing to unleash fiscal policy measures, with Chinese regulators conserving fiscal 'dry powder' for such contingencies.

Advocating a barbell approach, overweighting high-quality growth names in technology, platform firms, new energy, advanced manufacturing, and beneficiaries of policy pivot such as new retail; and resilient income in Singapore REITs and large China state banks with attractive dividend yields.
Gold prices have been sustainably above USD3,000/oz., supporting the profitability of most gold miners.
Gold miners have improved fundamentals by deleveraging, avoiding non-earnings-accretive M&A, reducing geopolitical risk exposure, and growing free cash flow.
Gold miners are considered a compelling growth play due to their leveraged play on gold prices and have gained 129% YTD as of 8 October 2025, according to the NYSE ARCA Gold Miners Index.
Trump's Liberation Day tariffs resulted in a weaker dollar, yield spikes, and increased stagflation risks, leading to an aggressive flight from US assets and a rapid selloff in UST yields.
Investors should consider stagflation-resistant bonds such as TIPS, which protect against inflationary headwinds and excel under conditions of lower growth and higher inflation.
Investors in high yield (HY) should exercise caution and remain up in quality in the BB bucket to mitigate risks of credit events and defaults.
Fixed income investors should stay up in quality with A/BBB credit and make selective picks in the better quality HY BB segment in the 1–3Y duration segment.
Ultra-long duration TIPS look attractive due to the steep TIPS curve, providing adequate compensation for going long, and the inability of the US to 'inflate away' this debt instrument.
A duration barbell approach with 2-3Y and 7-10Y IG credit is recommended to capture opportunities while navigating an uncertain rates and inflation outlook.
Investors are advised to consider 'government+' allocations like MBS, which provide a spread cushion over treasuries and diversification over traditional nominal treasury bonds.
Debt levels across Developed Markets are rising along with interest rates, causing concerns over US and Japan's debt load, resulting in higher long to ultra-long yields.
US spending on interest has reached an annualized 3.2% of GDP as of April 2025, with worries about the debt load exceeding 100% of GDP.
Japan's debt load exceeds 200% of GDP, causing a relentless shift higher in ultra-long end JGB yields.
Germany has a benign government debt load at 60% of GDP, with Bund yields buoyant due to a more optimistic economic outlook.
Rate cuts are expected across much of Asia due to steady exchange rates, with further easing warranted.
CGB yields are expected to stay steady after promising trade talks, with an additional 20 bps cut in the 1Y LPR and a 50 bps reduction in the RRR expected in 2H.
KRW rates are expected to see rate cuts and ongoing fiscal spending to cushion bond market volatility.
IDR rates are expected to see rate cuts and fiscal developments, with IndoGB yield differential against USTs likely to compress further.
SGD rates are likely to maintain a sizable discount to USD rates, driven by USD weakness rather than the slope of the SGD NEER.
The Fed is expected to cut rates by 50 bps in 2H, with the market likely to demand more in 2026.
The ECB has been steadily cutting rates, with the policy rate already at 2% (at neutral), and may be close to done for the time being.
The BOJ remains on a slow tightening path, with a decent chance that US yields would shift lower in the coming months as market participants mull a US economic slowdown.

Recent high-profile episodes of bankruptcies and restructuring are masked by an otherwise sanguine credit spread environment in HY bonds. With spreads at all-time tights, and risks on the horizon, the years of HY outperformance may be reaching its limits.

The historical regression of current spreads against 12M forward excess returns paints a daunting picture, potentially producing no excess returns in the coming one-year period, meaning investors would likely see little difference between investing in HY credit and risk-free treasuries.

There is a coming maturity wall requiring approximately USD870bn in refinancing over the next three years, and although absolute levels of leverage loan defaults remain low, including Liability Management Exercises reveals a higher level of distressed activity.
We see benefits in including diversified strategies in private markets such as distressed debt or opportunistic credit strategies that have the toolkit to capitalize on dislocations.

For public credit, we continue to favour an up in quality stance with IG credit in the A/BBB bucket. We like 'government+' allocations like agency MBS (for additional spread premium) and TIPS (for inflation protection) over nominal treasuries.

For private credit, we turn more neutral on direct lending strategies, preferring to add when spread valuations offer better premiums. Investors should remain with the best-in-class managers who have financial flexibility to navigate more opaque lending strategies.

Federal Reserve officials signalled readiness for further rate cuts this year but expressed caution due to inflation risks. Most participants supported easing, projecting two additional 25 bps cuts by year-end. Investors are pricing in c.100 bps of cuts by end-2026, implying a terminal rate near 3%.
US markets have largely embraced the Federal Reserve's tilt towards rate cuts, with equities continuing to climb despite the ongoing government shutdown.
Gold's sharp rally reflects hedging against USD risks.
Asia credit held firm amid higher treasury yields, with selective buying, M&A-driven flows, and mixed performance across IG and HY segments.
Bond fund flows were mixed globally, with strong inflows into Asia and Europe offset by a sharp dip in US inflows and outflows from Japan and Emerging Europe.
A strategic combination of private assets and hedge funds can cushion against drawdowns related to rate shocks.
The endowment-styled hybrid model constructed using a fund of open-ended funds approach is more capable of hedging against drawdowns and lifting returns compared to a traditional 60/40 portfolio.
Private credit's floating rate structure should continue to keep yields high at approximately 10.5% as it adjusts with monetary policy and rises in tandem with inflation.
Private infrastructure assets carry long-term contracted cash flows and inflation-linked revenue structures, making them capable of generating inflation-protected distributions for investors.
Private income generators such as private credit, infrastructure, and real estate displayed greater resilience over bonds under inflationary regimes.
Private credit displayed low default rates despite rate stress, aided by low leverage ratios amongst borrowers.

A hybrid portfolio constructed using fund of open-ended funds can outperform both a pure equity play and the conventional 60/40 portfolio over a 10-year horizon, delivering diversification benefits that outlast the latter.
Infrastructure is a balm for stagflation, with contracted cash flows and inflation-linked revenue structures.

Gold is expected to reach USD3,765/oz. by 4Q25, driven by strong central bank and investor demand amid macroeconomic and geopolitical uncertainty, recession/stagflation risk, and ongoing monetary debasement concerns.
Central bank and investor demand are key to gold's continued rise, providing steady structural demand and maintaining a price floor during times of broad de-risking.

A linear regression analysis indicates that approximately 600 tonnes of quarterly demand can produce a 6.4% quarterly increase in gold prices, supporting the revised target price of USD3,765/oz. by 4Q25.
Gold has been in a consistent bull market for the past three years, with tailwinds including geopolitical uncertainty, a widening US fiscal deficit, dedollarisation, and fiat currency debasement.
Continued central bank reserve diversification and robust investor demand are expected to buoy gold in a new era of heightened risk and uncertainty.
Tariffs are driving macroeconomic weakness and prospects of Fed rate cuts, adding to gold's appeal.
US fiscal worries, a softer dollar, and elevated geopolitical risk have contributed to a sharp YTD rebound in gold ETF flows.
Gold is considered one of the best hedges against recession/stagflation risk, fiat currency debasement, de-dollarisation, and other US policy-related risks.
Gold as a percentage of international reserves remains at roughly 21%, well below the historical 54-year average of 29%, indicating room for reserve diversification.
The macroeconomic backdrop has weakened due to tariffs and the US-China trade war, justifying increased investment demand for gold.
Labour market weakness in the US has revived rate cuts as a catalyst for gold, with futures markets predicting a total of three cuts this year.
Fears of 'fiscal dominance' to exacerbate de-dollarisation and monetary debasement risks, adding to gold’s appeal.
Geopolitical and macroeconomic uncertainty continues to drive investment demand for gold (both physical and ETF).
Record gold prices have slowed central bank buying, but buying intention remains strong as fluid geopolitics encourage continued reserve diversification.

Gold broke out of its USD3,500/oz. range to reach a new record high of USD3,858 at the end of September, trading at USD3,960/oz. on 7 Oct, driven by anticipation for further rate cuts by the Federal Reserve.
Raise 1H26TP from USD4,000/oz. to USD4,450/oz.
95% of central bank survey respondents believe that official global gold reserves will increase over the next 12 months.
Gold has gained over 50% YTD, with investment demand likely to remain robust against a backdrop of persistent geopolitical and macroeconomic uncertainty.
US fiscal concerns are expected to worsen, benefiting hard assets such as gold.
Central banks have been accumulating gold as a means of reserve diversification since the Russia-Ukraine conflict of 2022.
Signs of labour market weakness and stable inflation in the US saw the Fed implement a 25 bps rate cut in September, contributing to gold's price breakout.

Private credit has emerged as a natural choice amid structural shifts, offering flexible and bespoke financing solutions as banks face mounting constraints. It is gaining traction as borrowers seek flexible financing and investors pursue high yields with floating-rate protection.

Special opportunities funds stand out for their ability to capture excess returns during rate shocks, demonstrating strong outperformance potential and low loss probability. They thrive in complex, time-sensitive situations, often stepping in where traditional lenders are constrained.

Private credit strategies rebound faster and sharper from volatility shocks compared to public markets, offering high illiquidity and complexity premia with current yields averaging 10-11% and stable spreads of 200 bps across different rate cycles.

A looming liquidity squeeze from Treasury's TGA rebuild and Basel III reforms will tighten bank lending capacity, with reserves at risk of falling below USD3tn by the end of September, leading to a structural contraction in the supply of bank loans.

Bitcoin is described as having 'digital scarcity' with a supply cap of 21 million units and a declining rate of production hard-coded in its protocol, simulating finite supply similar to commodity-based money like gold.
Bitcoin's high energy usage secures the network, making it peerless in terms of scale and track record, accounting for approximately 98% of the total market cap of proof-of-work blockchains.
Cryptocurrency trading is highly risky and prices can be very volatile. All investments come with risks and you can lose your entire investment.
Downside price risk for industrial metals is expected when front-loaded demand tapers off and demand destruction sets in.

Despite a bullish demand outlook for corn, uncertainty over tariffs and expectations for a record year for US corn production are expected to put downward pressure on corn prices in the second half of the year.
Gold has significantly outperformed with a YTD performance of +22.2%, buoyed by safe haven demand and de-dollarisation tailwinds.
Cocoa market is expected to enter a surplus for the first time since 2021, with demand destruction settling in as cocoa prices have tripled since the start of 2023.
Aluminium markets face significant downside risk later in the year due to front-loaded demand, with a forecasted -1.7% decrease in full year 2025 automobile production.
Commodities are expected to face challenges due to tariff-related growth risks and general policy uncertainty, keeping sentiment and fund flows cautious.

The US economy presents mixed signals with robust retail sales growing at high single-digit annualized rates and strong consumer and business expenditures, with total imports up 11% y/y through July. PMI surveys indicate modest expansion, although manufacturing lags services.
The US economy could grow 1.5-2% in the coming years, driven by private sector capex, despite potential consumer scaling back amid federal-level job losses.
Takaichi’s victory in the LDP leadership race positions her as the frontrunner as Japan’s next Prime Minister; her policy platform should revive Abenomics-style fiscal expansion and monetary easing.
Vietnam’s economy appears robust, achieving 8.2% y/y GDP growth in 3Q25; consequently, the SBV is expected to hold its policy rate unchanged.

Prime Minister Lecornu’s resignation has deepened France’s political deadlock, with the government likely to miss the extended 13 Oct deadline for the 2026 budget, potentially requiring emergency measures to prevent a government shutdown in January.
Weak ADP employment data raised market expectations for the Fed’s October rate cut.
Markets view a Koizumi win in the LDP election as JPY-positive due to his pragmatic fiscal policy and support for closer coordination with the BOJ.
The RBI Monetary Policy Committee kept the repo rate unchanged at 5.5%, with a moderately dovish policy guidance suggesting a data-dependent path ahead.
Indonesia's trade surplus widened to a three-year high of USD5.5bn in August, with palm oil exports jumping 51% y/y.
The resilience in Indonesia's goods trade balance, which has grown by 50% y/y in 8M25, bodes well for current account health and the IDR.
The US government has imposed a USD100,000 fee on new H-1B visa petitions, signaling a shift in policy that affects skilled foreign workers.
India is responding to US policy changes, including work visa restrictions, by bolstering domestic demand and accelerating non-US partnerships.
The Bank of Japan (BOJ) maintained its policy rate and announced a gradual divestment of ETFs and J-REITs, selling ETFs at JPY330bn per year and J-REITs at JPY5bn per year.
Indonesia concluded a free trade agreement with the EU, which will lower tariffs to nil on over 90% of its product lines, providing economic uplift.
US Treasuries sold off across the curve after the Fed's 25 bps rate cut to 4.25%, failing to out-dove the dovish market pricing.
The Fed resumed its rate cut cycle with a 25 bps move, but growing inflation risks suggest the easing path may stall after 100 bps despite market hopes for deeper cuts.
Given the challenging 2H25 outlook, the PBOC is likely to maintain an accommodative stance with an anticipated 10 bps reduction in the 1-year loan prime rate (LPR) in 2H25.
China's August data shows weakening domestic and external demand, with export growth slowing and FDI plunging 15.4%, extending 26 months of contraction.
India's export front-loading is expected to ease in August while broader trade diversification towards ex-US gradually plays out; US trade talks hint at thawing relations.

Bangkok Dusit Medical Services (BDMS) is the largest private hospital in Thailand with a well-diversified revenue and profitability. It is favored for its sustainable earnings growth, scalable model, well-diversified portfolio, push into digital healthcare services, and prime position in medical tourism recovery.
BDMS faces challenges including a slowdown in medical tourism, higher-than-expected losses at its wellness centre, and a shortage of physicians.
BDMS's long-term growth outlook remains intact with expected earnings led by solid revenue growth through higher volumes and pricing, driven by Thai, insurance, and international patients.
DBS has a BUY rating for BDMS with a 12-month target price of USD 33.00, a market cap of USD 9.96 billion, and a dividend yield of 3.7%.
Charoen Pokphand Foods' earnings are now past peak with weaker quarters ahead as of 14 October 2025.
Core earnings for Charoen Pokphand Foods are expected to drop in FY26F due to normalised meat price levels in key markets.

Charoen Pokphand Foods is expected to deliver exceptional growth in 2025F, with core profit projected to jump 52% y/y, supported by stronger swine prices, cost efficiencies, and easing prices of key raw materials.
Meat prices in Thailand and other key international markets like Vietnam and China have started to normalise, with a slight rebound in domestic prices possible.
Key risks for Charoen Pokphand Foods include infections or diseases affecting animals and higher trade barriers.

Krung Thai Bank's 3Q25F performance was solid, driven by strong non-NII. The bank's asset quality improved with an NPL ratio of 2.94% at end-2Q25, down from 2.97% at end-1Q25, and a high coverage ratio of 194% at end-2Q25, up from 188% at end-1Q25. The bank benefits from a unique exposure to the government sector, aiding loan portfolio expansion at lower credit costs. Krung Thai Bank has a strong position in the digital banking arena, supported by its 'Paotang' mobile application, and offers a dividend yield of 6.2%, a forward P/E of 7.4x, and a P/Book of 0.8x with an ROE of 10.7%.

BP's strategic reset pivots back to fossil fuels, focusing on reducing and reallocating capex, lowering costs, and improving the balance sheet to support resilient distributions. The company aims to grow adjusted free cash flow by more than 20% annually from 2024 to 2027, driven by improvements in downstream performance and growth in the upstream sector. BP plans to distribute 30-40% of operating cash flows via dividends and buybacks.

BP has a BUY call with a target price of GBP4.60, based on a 1.5x forward P/BV multiple. The pivot back to hydrocarbons is expected to lead to a valuation rebound, contingent on successful execution of the strategy.

BP plans to focus on high return upstream oil and gas business, with overall capex guidance lowered to USD13-15bn, but oil & gas capex guidance increased. BP will spend 75% of capex on upstream and 20% on downstream over the next 3 years.

BP targets USD4–5bn of structural cost reductions by end 2027 and plans up to USD20bn of divestments by end of 2027, reviewing the Castrol lubes business for sale and BP Lightsource renewable energy platform in Europe for partial divestment.

BP is exposed to significant macroeconomic risks, including price and demand for crude oil and natural gas, forex risk, and regulatory risks like windfall taxes on oil profits. Operational risks persist, with the Deepwater Horizon oil spill leaving a permanent scar.

TotalEnergies SE is among the largest oil and gas companies in the world, with a focus on decarbonisation and a multi-energy strategy for sustainable growth. In 2024, Total produced 1.3mmbpd of oil, 1.1mmboepd of natural gas and liquids, 1.5mmbpd of refined fuels, and had a 21.5GW net installed power capacity (70% renewables).

TotalEnergies SE expects a 5% increase in overall energy production for 2025, combining hydrocarbon and electricity production. The company took FID of four major oil projects in Suriname, Brazil, Angola, and the Marsa LNG FID in Oman, expected to anchor c.3% production growth to 2030.

TotalEnergies SE is the #2 private player in the LNG market globally and aims to boost its LNG sales by 2x from 2019 to 2030. The company is well-positioned to benefit from its spot LNG exposure and oil-indexed contracts due to high spot LNG prices as the EU transitions away from Russian gas.

TotalEnergies SE plans to spend around one-third of its capex in low carbon businesses, particularly capacity expansion in the renewable segment, with a goal to produce more than 100TWh/year by 2030 (2024: 26TWh), and rank among the top five global renewable players.

Price fluctuations in oil and gas prices remain the biggest risk for TotalEnergies SE's earnings performance and dividend payout. The company also faces risks from exposure to Russian assets, leading to around USD15bn writedowns in 2022, and potential production losses from minority interests in upstream assets in Russia.
TotalEnergies SE has exposure to India’s controversial Adani Group, leading to delays in its investments in India.
US tariffs will adversely impact the manufacturing sector through its export exposure to the US market and a slowdown in global end-markets including Eurozone and China.
Vietnam is assessed to be the most exposed to US protectionism with a large share of exports to the US (~30% of total exports) and a high reciprocal tariff rate of 46%.
Silver has historically served as an inflation hedge, and any dovish turn in central bank interest rate policy could support silver prices by making non-yielding assets more attractive.
Greater inter-regional cooperation holds crucial benefits in terms of greater trade, investment, and tourism diversification against an increasingly protectionist global trade backdrop.
ASEAN must leverage its centrality in regional trade frameworks like RCEP to maintain open supply chains, stay united, diversify partnerships, and reinforce economic resilience.
The S&P 500 story was one of mega-cap tech stocks, comprising AI, cloud computing amongst others, during a turbulent period in the first half of 2025.
Fiscal concerns in the US appear to have been partly compensated for by the high UST yields against its credit rating.
More than 24k workers in Indonesia have been laid off as of May 2025, with the hardest-hit sectors including manufacturing, wholesale and retail trade, and services.
Despite mounting concerns about a potential recession, the risk of a downturn over the next two years remains low, with the U.S. household sector not facing structural imbalances.
The ASEAN region recorded net trade deficits with the GCC over the past decade, with the deficit being volatile reflecting movements in global oil prices and economic downturns.
Corporates' reluctance to invest amid heightened uncertainty may weigh on growth, although the U.S. household sector is not facing structural imbalances.
The S$NEER is largely steady around 1.4% above the model-implied policy band, with potential to remain near its current level or decline moderately. MAS aims for only a mild appreciation.
USDSGD will take cues from broader moves in USD, with implications from MAS policy being only one aspect. Other factors include Fed policy, RMB moves, growth-inflation dynamics, and risk sentiments.
SGD rates traded on the firm side with 1Y OIS being paid up by 2-3bps. Upward normalization in SGD OIS is expected towards the 1.35-1.50% area for short-end rates on a multi-month horizon.
MAS Core Inflation is forecast to trough in the near term and rise gradually thereafter. The output gap will remain positive in 2025 and come in around 0% next year.
Crude oil benchmarks rebounded with WTI and Brent rising by 1.0% and 0.9%, respectively, driven by President Trump's softened tone regarding US-China trade tensions.
Major US indexes closed 1.3%-2.2% higher, led by chipmakers and AI-related tech stocks, following a broad-based relief rally.
The dollar steadied and ended the day mildly higher.
Spot gold climbed above USD4,100/oz for the first time.
Silver surged to an all-time high amid short squeezes.
OPEC maintained its outlook for the oil market, projecting global oil demand growth forecasts of 1.3mbpd and 1.4mbpd in 2025 and 2026, respectively.
Singapore’s 3Q GDP growth slowed to 2.9% YoY, beating the consensus at 2.0%.

The Fed is expected to cut the Fed funds rate by 25bp each at the October and December meetings this year, followed by one 25bp cut in Q1-2026, bringing the target range to 3.25-3.50%. Further cuts will likely require inflation to move nearer the 2% target.
The BoJ is expected to implement a 25bp hike before year-end, with another 25bp hike in Q1-2026, bringing the BoJ Target rate to 1.00%.
The RBA kept the Cash Rate unchanged at 3.60% at the September meeting, with market expectations for rate cuts reduced to an additional 32bps by mid-2026.
The RBNZ delivered a 50bp cut on 8 October, bringing the OCR to 2.50%. The RBNZ remains open to further reductions, with one additional 25bp cut pencilled in for Q1-2026 as an insurance cut.
The ECB is likely nearing the end of the easing cycle, with no immediate rate cuts expected in the near term.
US shutdown is another supportive factor for USTs. We continue to see 10Y UST yield in the range of 4.00-4.20% as fair.
Government bonds across developed markets, including USTs, gilts, Bunds, OATs, rallied on Friday benefiting from safe-haven flows.
US policy unpredictability and concerns about the rising trajectory of US debt and deficits in the medium term should continue to underpin the broad decline in the USD.
China countered swiftly by reopening antitrust probes into major U.S. tech firms such as Qualcomm.

Southeast Asia stands to benefit from relocation of manufacturing and investment as firms seek neutral ground. Vietnam, Malaysia, and Indonesia are positioning as alternative nodes in the global value chain.

Licensing restrictions or slowed customs clearance at ports can choke production of rare earths and advanced materials, which are critical for clean energy, electric vehicles, and defense technologies.
2Y UST yield is expected to trade in a range of 3.55-3.70%, with a year-end forecast of 3.60%. A material rally in the 2Y bond is not expected as rate cuts are already priced in.
10Y UST yield is expected to be in the range of 4.00-4.20%, with a year-end forecast of 4.10%. The market impact of government shutdowns has been modest historically.
Fed funds futures last priced additional 46bps of cuts for the rest of this year, and 64bps of cuts for 2026. The FOMC remains split over the outlook for the Fed funds rate.
Despite recent cheapening, the preference is to be neutral on MGS at current bond/swap spread levels. Q4 gross supply of MGS+MGII is expected at MYR31-34bn.
IndoGB-UST yield differentials need to widen for bond inflows to make a strong comeback. Upsized auctions in Q3-2025 and international transactions will provide a buffer to funding positions.
SGD rates have shown some decoupling from USD rates. Investors may focus on bond/swap and asset swap pick-up. YTD gross SGS issuances are at the low end of the expected range.

Recent twist in US-China tensions further add to support for gold prices, underscoring gold’s unique role as both a hedge against geopolitical stress and a store of value in times of policy and institutional uncertainty.
China's RMB remains resilient despite recent US-China developments, which have become more fluid and can worsen before improving.
The tariff impact on regional, Singapore growth is expected to be largely manageable, with no sharp recession anticipated.

Risk-sensitive FX to growth and sentiments including AUD, NZD, MYR, RMB may be more sensitive to swings, while safe haven proxy FX such as gold, JPY and CHF could remain better bid if uncertainty heightens.
China started an antitrust investigation into Qualcomm Inc. as part of its response to US actions.

Our base-case remains for a total of 75bps of Fed funds rate cuts before year end, with one 25bp cut in Q325 and two 25bp cuts in Q425. This base-case represents a no-recession scenario. Continued cooling in the labour market will justify rates at less restrictive levels as long as there is no strong rebound in inflation.

Key risk to our base-case emanates from inflation pressure – with tariff/trade policies and geopolitics being the main swing factors. Should inflation quicken more than expected, room for additional rate cuts would be smaller.

Market last priced around 64bps of cuts this year. We had a mild downward bias to short-end UST yields as market pricings were slightly less dovish than our base-case; and as rate cuts materialise, the lower level of front-end rates will be factored more into the valuation of short-end bonds.

As market has recently added to rate cut expectation, the room for the 2Y yield to fall from here has become more limited. The 2Y yield is likely to settle at a level that is a tad above the policy rate when the easing cycle is seen as concluded. Given our current base-case for the Fed funds rate (upper) to be cut to 3.50%, we expect 2Y UST yield to settle at around 3.60% level.

US fiscal position remains a concern for foreign investors likely leading to continued, gradual diversification away from USD assets. For domestic investors, USTs are local currency assets and remain as safe havens.

According to US TIC data, foreign holdings of US Treasury securities have been falling as a percentage share of total outstanding to 24.9% as of end April 2025, from 34.6% at end-2014. Meanwhile, foreign holding amounts have largely been on an uptrend.

Gold's ~30% rally in 2025 has been driven by a powerful mix of macroeconomic, geopolitical and structural forces. Persistent geopolitical tensions have boosted gold's appeal as a safe-haven asset. Global central banks easing monetary policies is also supportive of gold prices.

ECB is ahead of most DM central banks in the rate-cutting cycle, having cut policy rates by cumulative 200bps, with the key policy Deposit Facility Rate at 2.00%, which is seen as a neutral level. We still have one more 25bp cut in our forecast profile, expecting the deposit rate to be cut to 1.75% by year-end.
Crude oil benchmarks fell on Friday, with WTI and Brent declining more than 3.8% to USD58.9/bbl and USD62.7/bbl, respectively, amid concerns over the impact of tariffs on global trade.
The S&P 500 closed down 2.71% in its worst session since 10 April, reflecting a risk-off sentiment.
The 10-year UST bond yield fell 11bps to 4.03% on flight to quality.
Gold prices increased as the USD slid, reflecting a flight to safety.
US earnings season gets underway with JPMorgan, Wells Fargo, Citigroup, Goldman Sachs tomorrow, followed by Bank of America and Morgan Stanley on Wednesday.
China's September trade data is a focus, with exports YoY expected at 6.60% and imports YoY at 1.80%.
Singapore's advance 3Q25 GDP growth estimates are likely to decelerate to 2.1% YoY (0.7% QoQ sa), compared to 4.4% YoY (1.4% QoQ sa) in 2Q25.
Indonesia’s waste-to-energy programme will require about IDR91trn in funding to build projects across 33 locations.
Malaysia set a narrower fiscal deficit target of 3.5% of GDP in 2026 from 3.8% in 2025, with revenue projected to grow 2.7% YoY to MYR343.1bn.
Market attention will shift to the Q3 earnings season, with major financial institutions reporting.
Investors will closely monitor the tariff-affected consumer and retail sectors for signs of market direction.
Investors will closely monitor the technology sector for signs of market direction.
Silver prices climbed to new highs amid renewed demand for precious metals.
Federal Reserve Governor Michael Barr opined that the Fed should proceed cautiously with further rate cuts, warning that inflation risks have not yet fully subsided.
BSP Governor Remolona stated that the domestic economic outlook 'has weakened,' partly due to the impact of governance concerns over public infrastructure spending on business confidence.

BSP notes that the inflation outlook is 'benign and well within the target range,' with inflation expectations remaining well-anchored. Governor Remolona signaled that one more rate cut is possible before the end of the year.
Japan's PPI inflation stayed at 2.7% YoY in September, the same as in August, although coming in stronger than consensus expectations of 2.5%.

The US Federal Reserve minutes from the 16-17 September meeting discussed quantitative tightening, noting that if balance sheet runoff were to continue at the current pace, the SOMA portfolio was expected to decline to just over USD6trn by the end of March.
US equities gained led by tech-heavy NASDAQ (+1.1%) and to a lesser extent S&P (+0.6%) while the Dow was flat.

The Federal Reserve noted growth at a gradual pace, with the TGA fluctuating around current levels, and usage of the overnight reverse repurchase agreement (ON RRP) facility remaining very low except on quarter-end dates.

BoT lowered its headline inflation forecast to 0.0% and 0.5% for 2025 and 2026, with core inflation expected to remain at 0.9%. The dovishness of the official statement suggests room for further easing, with a forecast for an additional 25bp rate cut from BoT in 2025.
Public Utilities Board priced a SGD500mn 30Y Fixed Bond at 2.486% and Emirates NBD Bank PJSC priced a SGD160mn 2Y Fixed Bond at 1.75%.
Malaysia is cutting red tape through the Invest Malaysia Facilitation Centre-Johor and AI-driven systems to improve investment approvals.
BSP is expected to pause in the rate cutting cycle, but there is still room for another 25bp rate cut for the rest of the year.
WTI crude oil price is at $61.73 per barrel with a 0.06% change, and Brent crude oil price is at $65.45 per barrel with a -0.03% change.
Gold price increased by 0.6% to $3985.
Silver price decreased by 1.4% to $47.83.
Copper price increased by 1.0% to $10761.
Palladium price increased by 2.1% to $1349.
FTSE Russell upgraded Vietnam from frontier to Secondary Emerging market status, effective 21 September 2026.
The World Bank raised its 2025 growth forecast for China to 4.8%.
The World Bank upgraded its projection for the broader East Asia and Pacific region to 4.4% for 2025, up 0.2 percentage points from the prior forecast.
Markets continued to price in a rate cut at the October FOMC meeting.
Wall Street pulled back from record highs due to political uncertainty and the U.S. government shutdown entering its eighth day.
US treasury yields retraced higher, on the back of the global political sagas.
Dollar rebounded, most notably against the Japanese yen.
Nikkei gapped higher at opening and refreshed new highs.
The yen and long-dated Japanese government bonds came under considerable pressure.
AMD’s stock prices jumped upon news of signing a multi-billion chip supply deal with OpenAI, which sent the broader S&P 500 and Nasdaq to a fresh closing high.
French government bonds saw a modest selloff and are now yielding more than their counterparts in Italy and Greece.
The spread between French and German debt rose to almost 90bps.
WTI increased by 1.33% to $61.69 per barrel, and Brent increased by 1.46% to $65.47 per barrel.
Natural Gas increased by 0.99% to $3.36 per MMBtu.
The S&P500 gained 1.1% to a fresh weekly record high, aided by healthcare stocks.
The S&P500 gained 1.1% to a fresh weekly record high, aided by utilities stocks.
The S&P500 gained 1.1% to a fresh weekly record high, aided by tech stocks.
UST bonds were generally lower with the 10-year yield up 4bps to 4.12% despite market expectations for another 25bps rate cut at the upcoming October FOMC.
OPEC+ is close to an agreement to modestly raise output in November by 137,000 barrels a day.
The S&P Global Singapore PMI surged from 51.2 in August to 56.4 in September, marking its eighth month of expansion above the 50 handle.
Vietnam's retail sales YoY in September were 10.60%.
US equities closed at record highs overnight, led by a strong rally in tech, as investors largely looked past concerns over the ongoing US government shutdown.
The futures market is pricing in two more Fed rate cuts by year-end.
With the release of weekly jobless claims and September non-farm payrolls delayed, markets have been turning to alternative data for signals on labour market conditions.
The Chicago Fed estimated the September unemployment rate at 4.3%, unchanged from August.
Challenger, Gray & Christmas reported that announced layoffs fell in September, but hiring plans so far this year—at 204,939—are the lowest since 2009.
Bloomberg Asia USD Investment Grade spreads tightened by 1bps to 61bps and Bloomberg Asia USD High Yield spreads tightened by 2bps to 330bps.
WTI and Brent crude oil prices fell by 2.10% and 1.90% respectively.
Natural Gas prices decreased by 0.98%.
Corn and soybean prices increased by 1.3% and 1.1% respectively.
Wheat and rubber prices increased by 1.1% and 2.8% respectively.
The 10Y UST yield moved lower and was last seen around 4.08%.
Brent crude fell to ~USD65.5/bbl.
Wall Street ended modestly higher overnight, despite renewed political uncertainty.
Indonesia plans to issue IDR50tn of 'Patriot' bonds, with 80% of funds to be invested in the domestic market.
USD-JPY decreased by 0.56%.
Natural Gas prices increased by 5.24%.
The ADP report for September showed a 32k drop in private payrolls, well below expectations of a 51k gain.
Bloomberg Asia USD High Yield spreads widened by 11bps to 332bps.
Wall Street closed September on a firmer note, marking the S&P 500’s fifth straight monthly gain.
The 10Y UST yield held broadly steady at ~4.15% despite rising political risks, including a looming US government shutdown.
The Conference Board Consumer Confidence Index fell more than expected to 94.2 in September from 97.8 in August.
The expectations index dropped to 73.4, below the recession-watch threshold.
Consumers’ average 12-month inflation expectations inched down to 5.8% YoY in September from 6.1% in August.
The JOLTS report showed 7.23mn job openings in August, but hiring slowed to 5.1mn and the quits rate edged down to 2.2%.
Nonfarm payrolls for September, if released on schedule, are expected to show +52k jobs (vs. +22k prior), with unemployment steady at 4.3% and wage growth at 3.7% YoY.
The Reserve Bank of India is widely expected to keep its repurchase rate unchanged at 5.50%.
Inflation figures for the euro area will be published.
Bloomberg Asia USD Investment Grade spreads traded flat at 60bps and Bloomberg Asia USD High Yield spreads widened by 2bps to 321bps respectively.
WTI (per barrel) decreased by 1.70% to 62.37, and Brent (per barrel) decreased by 1.40% to 67.02.
Corn (per bushel) decreased by 1.4% to 4.155, Soybean (per bushel) decreased by 0.9% to 10.018, and Wheat (per bushel) decreased by 2.2% to 5.080.
Natural Gas (per MMBtu) increased by 1.10% to 3.30, and Rubber (JPY/KG) increased by 2.8% to 309.500.

Silver is in a sweet spot within the commodities complex due to tight supply, solid industrial usage, and macro tailwinds. The recent surge above USD 51 reflects structural tightness, macro tailwinds, and technical breakout momentum. The medium-term outlook remains supported by ongoing supply deficits, Fed easing cycle, and sustained industrial consumption trends.

Silver's rally past USD 51/oz has surpassed its previous high of near $50 in 2011, with a strong rally up 78% YTD. The surge underscores a convergence of structural supply tightness, momentum buying, and a conducive macro environment. Silver benefits from dual characteristics of precious and industrial demand, supported by global growth and Fed easing expectations.

Silver's physical supply stresses are severe, with lease rates surging to around 33%, reflecting scarcity and heightened competition for physical supply. Spot-futures spreads have flipped into steep backwardation, and London vault inventories continue to draw down, compounded by refinery bottlenecks.

Investor interest in silver has picked up due to heightened geopolitical risk, renewed fiscal uncertainty in the U.S., and sticky inflation. The clean break above USD 50 drew in momentum traders and systematic buying, with ETF inflows turning positive and speculative longs climbing.

The risk of a slowdown in the pace of Fed easing or a rebound in real yields may temper enthusiasm for non-yielding assets like silver. Additionally, if industrial demand slows alongside weaker global growth, silver's cyclical component could become a drag, limiting upside momentum.

The 10bps fall in 10Y UST yield represented a 7bp fall in real yield and 3bp fall in breakeven. The 10Y UST yield is seen in the range of 4.00-4.20% as fair; further downside likely requires real yield to fall while breakeven is trading at the low end of the range.
Fed funds futures last priced 47bps of cuts for the rest of the year, and 68bps of cuts for 2026.
USTs rallied by 9-11bps on Friday benefiting from safe-haven flows, as Trump announced 100% tariff on China and exports control on critical software starting 1 November.

Risk-sensitive FX to growth and sentiments including AUD, NZD, MYR, RMB may be more sensitive to swings, safe-haven proxy FX such as gold, JPY and CHF could remain better bid if uncertainty heightens while trade policy unpredictability may restrain USD bulls.
A prolonged USD short squeeze may have a spillover effect onto USDSGD in the near term.
Range for 2Y UST yield remains at 3.50-3.65%, and for 10Y UST at 4.10-4.20%.
The 5Y JGB auction was well received with a bid/cover ratio of 3.695x, similar to the prior 3.696x. The next test will be the 20Y JGB auction next week.
6M T-bills cut off at 1.44%, the same as previously.

USTs traded in ranges overnight, with yields retracing from session highs to end the day 1-2bps higher. The 30Y coupon auction was well received, with a bid/cover ratio of 2.38x, while indirect accepted was a tad higher at 64.5% versus 62.0% prior.
JPY OIS last priced 6bps of a hike at October meeting, and a total of 16bps of a hike before year end. Base case remains for a 25bp hike before year end.
September PPI came in at 2.7%YoY or 0.3%MoM, beating market expectations. September CPI is released before 30 October meeting.
SGD rates within expected range of 1.42-1.46%, as front-end SGD rates have turned stable after earlier upward adjustments.

NZD fell sharply after RBNZ surprised with a 50bp cut. The Committee remains open to further reductions in the OCR as required, with economic activity through the middle of 2025 being weak due to domestic constraints and global economic policy uncertainty.
DM government bonds mostly stabilised overnight, with the impact of global economic policy uncertainty.
Gold's recent rally underscores its unique role as both a hedge against geopolitical stress and a store of value in times of policy and institutional uncertainty.

The 30Y JGB auction garnered a bid/cover ratio of 3.411x versus 3.308x prior, indicating stabilization in long-end JGBs. However, fiscal uncertainty in Japan may keep the risk premium on the high side.
IndoGBs extended rally as the conventional bond auction saw a fresh intra-day high of 4006. The bond sale was upsized to IDR28trn versus an indicative target of IDR23trn, suggesting strong demand.
USTs outperforming at the margin with gains maintained after a solid 3Y coupon auction. The 3Y note sales stopped through at 3.576%.
JPY has come off by about 3% post-LDP vote over the weekend. Markets have pushed out rate hike expectations, only fully pricing in a 25bp hike in Mar next year.
MAS is likely to maintain policy status quo with a slight appreciating bias for SGD, though the door for easing remains open if growth-inflation dynamics worsen.
USDSGD is projected to have a mild downside for the remainder of the year, based on a moderately softer USD trend, resilient RMB, and manageable tariff impact on regional growth.
The S$NEER may see little to modest strengthening if MAS holds policy, while USDSGD may trade slightly softer post-decision, assuming a nuanced broader USD trend.
MAS Core Inflation and CPI-All Items inflation are forecast to average 0.5–1.5% in 2025, with inflation outlook subject to both upside and downside risks.
42% of respondents in the MAS survey of professional forecasters anticipated MAS to ease policy in Oct, an increase from 17% in the Jun survey.
The UST curve bearish steepened overnight, with potential upsizing to 34.5trn, including the reopening of various bonds and bills.

The IndoGB curve has steepened materially over the past months, with 2Y IndoGB-UST yield differential narrow at the low-end of the two-year range. 2Y IndoGB is likely to stay supported given the favorable monetary policy backdrop.
30Y JGB yield broke above the previous high, with fiscal uncertainty potentially keeping the risk premium high. The 30Y bond/swap spread at -71bps may start to look supportive of the bond.

OAT yields retraced mildly lower from session highs, ending 1-7bps higher in a steepening manner. Swap spreads (OIS – OAT yields) fell, with 10Y last at -105bps and 30Y at -156bps, reflecting the risk premium required by investors.
Long-end JGBs are viable alternatives for portfolio diversification, which might explain the spillover onto the UST market in terms of the steepening move.
EUR slipped due to political developments, including PM Lecornu's resignation and upcoming Netherlands General Elections, posing downward risk in the near term.
Softer core CPI print for Singapore at 0.3% y/y for Aug likely added to expectations that MAS may ease policy at its upcoming MPC in Oct, but subdued price pressure is within expectations.
USDJPY may still trade with a bid tone unless USD falls significantly or if the BoJ signals a rate hike earlier. MoF rhetoric is a key consideration regarding USDJPY volatility and level.

JPY OIS last priced 11bps of hike by year end, down from 21bps. The 30Y bond/swap spread (JPY OIS – JGB yield) fell to -72bps, starting to look supportive of the bond. BoJ reduced purchase sizes of JGBs for tenors >1Y to 25Y but maintained purchase size of JGBs of tenor beyond 25Y. Any support from this schedule to long-end JGBs is seen as marginal.

USTs cheapened as safe-haven flows ebbed. September ISM services index dipped to 50-point versus 52-point prior. UST yields remained in expected ranges, with Fed funds futures pricing a high chance (91%) of two 25bp cuts before year end. Range for 2Y UST yield is seen at 3.5-3.65% and for 10Y UST yield at 4.05-4.25%.
USD should remain on a moderately soft path due to Fed’s easing bias, weak labor market, and political stand-off. DXY last seen at 98 levels.

There are USD58bn of 3Y, USD39bn of 10Y, and USD22bn of 30Y coupon bond auctions this week. In the absence of key data, investors may adopt a cautious approach in positioning, and USTs are likely to consolidate.

Filename: FX Rates Focus - Market implications of Japan LDP election results.pdf
Summary: USDJPY movements are influenced by USD, UST yields, and carry trade dynamics. USDJPY may trade with a bid tone unless USD falls significantly or BoJ signals an earlier rate hike. MoF rhetoric is a key consideration for USDJPY volatility and level.

Filename: FX Rates Focus - Market implications of Japan LDP election results.pdf
Summary: JPY OIS pared back rate hike expectation. Base-case is for a 25bp hike before year-end and another 25bp hike in H1-2026, bringing BoJ Target rate to 1.00%. JGB curve steepened, with long-end bond/swap spreads going deeper into negative.

Filename: FX Rates Focus - Market implications of Japan LDP election results.pdf
Summary: 30Y bond/swap spread (JPY OIS – JGB yield) fell to -70bps, compared to one-year average of -59bps. Fiscal uncertainty likely to keep the risk premium high, despite Takaichi's assurance of responsible fiscal policy.

Filename: FX Rates Focus - Market implications of Japan LDP election results.pdf
Summary: BoJ opined the impact of previous hikes on Japan’s economy has been extremely limited. September Tokyo CPI printed softer than expected at 2.5%. Continued policy normalisation remains on the agenda, but the next rate hike may be delayed.

Filename: FX Rates Focus - Market implications of Japan LDP election results.pdf
Summary: BoJ maintained that if economic activity and prices improve, it will continue to raise the policy interest rate. However, high uncertainties on trade policy and US monetary policy outlook hinder a rate hike.

Gold has surged to fresh record highs near $3,900, breaking out of its multi-month consolidation range of $3,200 to $3,500. The rally is driven by gold's role as a hedge against geopolitical stress and a store of value in times of policy and institutional uncertainty. The strongest YTD performance in 25 years is noted, with the Fed embarking on a rate cut cycle and broader portfolio demand for gold as a reliable store of value and hedge against both inflation and geopolitical risks.

The World Gold Council’s Central Bank Reserves Survey (June 2025) reported that 95% of respondents believe that official gold reserves will continue to increase, up from 81% last year. Broader portfolio demand for gold as a reliable store of value and hedge against both inflation and geopolitical risks should help underpin the constructive outlook.

Market positioning yet to signal extreme overbought conditions with a 25-week z-score at 1.5 sd. There may still be room for upside, but caution is advised against excessive complacency in the near term.

Strong official-sector demand, led by China and other EM reserve managers, is likely to continue. China has been buying gold for 10 consecutive months, with holdings over 2,300 tonnes as of August 2025. Poland is the largest net buyer of gold in 2025 with over 67 tonnes YTD, while Azerbaijan, Kazakhstan, and Turkey remain consistent buyers.
During the last US government shutdown in December 2018, the 2Y UST yield and 10Y yield both fell by a cumulative 14bps, but past reactions have not been regular.
During the last US government shutdown, the USD broadly traded softer, with DXY down over 1%.
During the last US government shutdown, gold was up nearly 4%.

The USD rates market is already dovish, with Fed funds futures pricing in additional 115bps of cuts for the rest of the cycle. The 2Y UST yield is at 3.53%, consistent with such Fed funds rates expectation.
T-bills auctions were well received, especially the 8W bills sales which garnered a bid/cover ratio of 3.01x versus 2.65x, as investors tried to lock in the yield in view of the expected rate cuts.
SGD OIS were stable at open this morning, after falling by 3-5bps across on Thursday. Our rates forecasts have assumed some upward normalisation in SGD rates.
Foreign investors reduced holdings of IndoGBs by IDR45.8trn in September, but demand from domestic investors more than made up for the slack.
Investors were seen lightening positions ahead of next week’s conventional bond auction, with an indicative target of IDR23trn and potential upsizing to IDR34.5trn.

Fed funds futures added back to rate cut expectation, pricing 47bps of cuts for the rest of the year, and 67bps of cuts for 2026. 2Y UST yield fell to 3.53%, reflecting the latest expected Fed funds rate trajectory.
DXY last seen at 97.66. Mild bullish momentum on daily chart shows signs of it fading while RSI fell. Consolidation likely with risks somewhat skewed to the downside.
Near-term range for 2Y UST yield is at 3.50-3.65% and for 10Y UST yield at 4.0-4.2%.
Fed-BoJ policy divergence should underpin USDJPY's broader direction of movement to the downside.
The broader fundamental outlook remains supportive of the euro, suggesting a buy-on-dips approach.
Lagarde said the inflation risks are quite contained in both directions. Our house view believes that ECB rate cut cycle is nearing its end.
Overnight’s 4M bill auction garnered solid demand, with the bid/cover ratio higher at 3.32x versus 2.93x prior, as investors locked in the yield ahead of expected rate cuts down the road.

During previous incidents of government shutdown, market impact was modest in the form of safe-haven flows, and reaction usually did not last. At the 10Y tenor, breakeven is seen in the 2.3-2.4% range and real yield in the 1.7-1.8% range.

Gold extended its run higher, hitting an intra-day high of 3875 levels, before backing off. Risk of US government shutdown raises concerns of economic slowdown. XAU last seen at 3865 levels. Underlying momentum remains bullish but RSI remains in overbought conditions. Resistance at 3,890 (138.2% fibo extension), 4,006 levels (150% fibo ext). Support at 3,750, 3,657 (21 DMA) and 3,500.
Softer print is likely to weigh on USD. Proxy play may likely include long gold, JPY; short USD if the shutdown persists for longer, in turn affecting risk appetite or even economic activities.

RBA kept OCR unchanged at 3.60% as widely expected. Bank bills futures fell (implied rates higher) as the statement and Bullock’s comments were seen as hawkish. The statement fell short of giving any hint of further easing and instead indicated that 'inflation may be persistent in some areas'.

The RBA is nearing the end of the easing cycle. There is likely only one final 25bp cut in the cycle. Market has pared back rate cut expectation to the latest additional 30bps of cuts (by mid-2026). Expected cut in Q4-2025.
The range for 2Y UST yield remains at 3.50-3.65%, and for 10Y UST at 4.10-4.20%.

FOMC minutes carried both dovish and hawkish elements, reflecting a split Committee amid economic and trade policy uncertainties. The current fed funds rate is at 4.00-4.25%, above the long-run median dot of 3.00%.
The Fed expects money market rates to continue to increase over time relative to administered rates and to eventually pull the effective federal funds rate higher.
USDCNY fix was set at 7.1102, +47pips as China reopens.

Recent Fed commentaries point to an increased tolerance of transient upticks in front-end funding rates. QT is unlikely to last beyond Q1-2026, with the decision to stop QT potentially being made earlier.
The FOMC minutes noted that if balance sheet runoff were to continue at the current pace, bank reserves were expected to be close to the USD2.8trn range by the end of Q1-2026.
The FOMC minutes cited a shift in the balance of risks as the reason for the rate cut decision at the September meeting.

Our house view has inflation forecast skewed higher towards 1% for 2026 while growth still holds up overall. The door for MAS to ease remains open should growth-inflation dynamics worsen more than expected.

Hong Kong stocks are upgraded to mildly overweight due to attractive valuations, liquidity inflow, and increased local IPO activity. The stabilisation in residential housing and a positive wealth effect boost the outlook for consumption.
Asia ex-Japan ROE remains on a steady uptrend, while corporate governance reforms continue to improve shareholder returns.
US utility stocks are upgraded to mildly overweight as rapidly rising electricity demand could create a bottleneck.
High yield (HY) is reduced to a mild underweight due to tight spreads and rising volatility.
EM local currency bonds are upgraded to mildly overweight for their weaker correlation to risk assets and attractive fundamentals.

We are neutral on hedge funds but retain a substantial core allocation. Private equity fundraising and deal flow have softened, but leading GPs continue to generate decent returns in resilient sectors such as technology, healthcare, and services.
Infrastructure helps provide defensive exposure and steady and inflation-hedged cash flows.
We have cut our preferred duration exposure to 5-7 years across Treasuries and US IG following the recent rally, as we only expect two more Fed cuts.

Filename: Zooming In – October 2025 – Sector Outlook - Consumer Discretionary and Staples.pdf
Summary: We maintain a relative preference for the consumer discretionary sector over the consumer staples sector due to structural trends like ageing demographics and higher purchasing power of silver spenders.

Filename: Zooming In – October 2025 – Sector Outlook - Consumer Discretionary and Staples.pdf
Summary: We maintain a mildly underweight view for both US and global consumer staples sector due to higher labour costs and higher import costs.

Filename: Zooming In – October 2025 – Sector Outlook - Consumer Discretionary and Staples.pdf
Summary: Within the consumer discretionary sector, we prefer to invest in companies that offer a strong value proposition whilst delivering elevated brand quality.

Filename: Zooming In – October 2025 – Sector Outlook - Consumer Discretionary and Staples.pdf
Summary: Subsectors like high-end hotels, cruise liners, and online travel agents are supported by long-term structural trends and enjoy higher pricing power.

Filename: Zooming In – October 2025 – Sector Outlook - Consumer Discretionary and Staples.pdf
Summary: Quick-service restaurants should continue to face negative traffic trends and headwinds from higher labour costs and higher import costs.
Developed Markets Investment Grade, proxied by the Bloomberg US Corporate Bond Index, delivered a total USD return of +6.9% YTD as of 29 Sep, supported by a Fed rate cut and credit spread recovery.
We stay Underweight on DM USD HY as risk-reward remains asymmetric, with credit spread widening posing a huge downside risk.
We stay Overweight on Emerging Markets (EM) which offers both stability and diversification, supported by a broad investor base, a stable credit environment and favourable EM trends.
We remain Overweight on US equities. While we continue to favor quality AI/growth stocks, investors should diversify some exposure into the 'Next20' after Mag7 within S&P 500.

We stay Neutral on European equities against a backdrop of tepid growth outlook. Investors should remain focused on selected opportunities in banks, industrials and defence stocks amid expectations for incremental monetary and fiscal policy loosening.
We remain Neutral on Japan’s equities. We reiterate our preference for quality companies with strong IP/brands, selected tech stocks as well as corporate-reform beneficiaries.
We remain Overweight on Emerging Asia equities. A weaker US dollar and Fed easing may drive more foreign inflows into EM Asia against a backdrop of relatively undemanding valuations.
We continue to prefer resilient Chinese dividend stocks as well as quality AI-related names.
We upgrade Equities to Overweight from Neutral; position for favorable seasonality effects in the next six months and use dips to accumulate quality stocks.
We remain Overweight on Alternatives as less correlated assets offer diversification benefits.
We stay Neutral on Fixed Income given asymmetric risk-reward with immensely tight credit spreads and recommend an average duration of 4-5 years.
Gold remains essential, though its near-term reward to risk may be less favourable with higher speculative behaviour.
The Fed’s rate cutting path is expected to be shallow, but fraught with increasing uncertainty due to the US government shutdown and its impact on the job market.
The tech earnings season has reinforced the view that momentum behind AI continues to build, with top companies reporting rising capital spending supported largely by cash flows rather than debt.
Amazon's shares surged nearly 10% after a 20% increase in revenue from its web services division amid fast-rising demand for computing power for AI.
Cloud revenues at Microsoft and Alphabet rose by 40% and 34% year-over-year, respectively.
NVIDIA became the first company ever to reach a market cap of USD 5 trillion.

The Federal Reserve delivered a widely expected 25-basis-point rate cut, but the accompanying press conference was surprisingly hawkish, with Chair Jerome Powell stating that more easing in December is far from a foregone conclusion.
We maintain our Attractive view on US equities, forecasting the S&P 500 to reach 7,300 by June 2026.
The agreement to extend a temporary trade truce for another year is expected to benefit the tech and AI sectors in China.
The post-pandemic inflation shock and rate-hiking cycle produced a generational reset higher in bond yields, supporting a strong multiyear outlook for global fixed income.
U.S. Treasuries remain the cleanest dirty shirt in the sovereign closet over our secular timeline, underpinned by the dollar’s reserve currency status.
The Trump 2.0 fiscal package is likely to widen U.S. deficits and debt beyond prior policy projections, with overall fiscal space remaining constrained.
A correction in inflated U.S. equity valuations could trigger broader risk asset repricing amid limited fiscal space.

The question of whether new risks emanating from the U.S. automatically translate into higher risk premia for the rest of the world underscores the tight historical link between DM policy rates and EM.

Given attractive starting valuations in fixed income, along with expected weaker growth and stabilizing conditions, bond investors can benefit from the combination of attractive bond yields and a challenged economic outlook.

The 2025 US tariffs introduced a 10% duty on most goods, with rates as high as 145% on some imports from China and up to 50% for several other countries, leading to significant price increases in imported goods.
Goods imported from China, subject to higher tariffs, experienced larger and more sustained price increases, indicating a significant impact from the 2025 US tariffs.
The 2025 US tariffs led to a 5.4% increase in imported goods prices and a 3% rise in domestic goods prices, reflecting a significant impact on consumer prices.
The 2025 US tariffs contributed about 0.7 percentage points to the all-items Consumer Price Index within six months, indicating a notable inflationary effect.
Personal income in the US increased by $95.7 billion (0.4 percent at a monthly rate) in August 2025, according to the U.S. Bureau of Economic Analysis.
Disposable personal income in the US increased by $86.1 billion (0.4 percent) in August 2025.
Personal consumption expenditures in the US increased by $129.2 billion (0.6 percent) in August 2025.
The increase in current-dollar personal income in August 2025 primarily reflected increases in compensation and personal current transfer receipts.
Personal outlays in the US increased by $132.9 billion in August 2025.
The personal saving rate in the US was 4.6 percent in August 2025.
As the ASEAN region becomes more affluent, there are greater opportunities to develop an internal market, reducing dependence on external powers.
The future path of the US economy hinges largely on how tariffs and immigration play out, with each shaping growth, prices, and investment in different ways.
The economic outlook for Japan remains mixed, with inflation being the biggest challenge it faces on the road to economic recovery.
When the United States proposed historically steep tariffs on Southeast Asian countries, it became clear that countries in the region could not depend on easy access to the US market.
In September, 54,064 US jobs were eliminated; of these, 13,622 were cut due to businesses or facilities closing; 8,930 were cut due to market or economic conditions; and 7,000 were cut due to AI.

Technology companies in the US have announced 107,878 job cuts through September 2025, a decline from 116,856 during the same period last year. Technological updates, including automation and AI implementation, have led to 20,219 job cuts in 2025, with 17,375 explicitly attributed to AI.

The US Government sector has announced 299,755 planned job cuts in 2025, with 289,363 Federal workers impacted by DOGE actions. DOGE actions remain the leading reason for job cut announcements, cited in 293,753 planned layoffs.

In the third quarter of 2025, planned layoffs by US employers totaled 202,118, the highest Q3 total since 2020. Closings of stores, units, or plants have led to 144,652 layoffs so far this year, up from 97,590 during the same period last year.

Market and economic conditions are the second-most cited reason for workforce reductions in 2025, responsible for 208,227 cuts year to date, reflecting employers' response to economic uncertainty, inflation, tariffs, and shifting demand.
Job cut plans in the US are likely to surpass a million for the first time since 2020, driven by economic conditions and technological changes.
US stocks dropped by more than 2% on 10 October after US President Donald Trump threatened to impose an additional 100% tariff on Chinese exports to the US, increasing the risk of stagflation.
Renewed risk of faltering growth in China could hamper the Chinese stock market's recovery and put more pressure on Beijing to take more aggressive support measures.
US earnings results for the third quarter have so far beaten high expectations.
European companies have undershot high expectations in the third quarter earnings results.
The US tariff policy is creating uncertainty, spilling over to global markets, with tariff-induced inflation partially offset by Asia.
Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell argued that further interest rate cuts in the US should not be taken for granted, with the FOMC split over the future path for rates.
China is experiencing persistent deflation, with prices falling for 10 consecutive quarters, and nominal GDP growth at 3.7% YoY in the third quarter.
The latest purchasing managers’ indices (PMIs) for the eurozone presented an upside surprise, with the main gauge at 52.2.
China and the US reached another trade war détente, temporarily reducing the geopolitical risk premium on global assets.
Latest US labour market data showed continued deceleration, with real labour income falling since early this year, posing a downside risk to overall growth.

The current situation appears to favour the rate-cut narrative, with inflation being less of a problem than a slowing economy for the Fed, thanks to Asian exporters absorbing some of the import tariff impact on US prices.
US tech earnings are up by nearly 26% in the third quarter, driving overall earnings growth.
European tech earnings have increased by 19% in the third quarter, contributing to earnings growth.
US earnings have risen by 10% compared to the same quarter a year ago, exceeding expectations by over 7%.
European earnings have declined by 1.3% compared to the same quarter a year ago, with results only 1.2% better than forecast.
US banks are benefiting from deregulation and increased merger and acquisition activity.
The impact of US tariffs and a strong euro are negatively affecting European companies' results.
The US manufacturing sector has a purchasing managers' index reading above 50, indicating expansion.
European purchasing managers' indices and survey data point to better days ahead, with stable or improved readings compared to September.
China's third-quarter GDP growth data shows a decline from 6.1% to 4.5% compared to the third quarter of 2024, with increased contribution from net exports and steady consumption.
Small caps, Discretionary, Healthcare, and Industrials lead sector performance in the US.

Utilities lag in sector performance in the US.
Bonds tend to firm with the 2s10s flattening ~5 bps and long yields in the US drifting lower.

Commodities see metals firm modestly.

The S&P 500 is delivering a 6% beat, powered by Tech heavyweights and reinforced by the strongest breadth of earnings beats since 2021.
Consumer trends have not been encouraging, with Discretionary earnings on pace to fall 2% year over year in 3Q, while Staples are tracking -1%.

November historically brings tailwinds for stocks and bonds, with equities rising and yields easing. Across global indices, nine of ten typically finish the month higher, led by the Russell 2000 (+2.6%) and Nasdaq 100 (+2.5%).
November historically brings tailwinds for stocks and bonds, with equities rising and yields easing.

The clocks may fall back, but earnings momentum hasn't, with one of the strongest 3Q seasons in recent memory and positive seasonal trends ahead.

AI could displace 6-7% of the US workforce if widely adopted, with occupations like computer programmers and customer service representatives at higher risk.
Executives in technology and finance sectors report efficiency gains from generative AI, leading to slowed hiring, especially in operational and back-office roles.

Goldman Sachs leaders at the Communacopia + Technology conference stated that AI's impact on the business landscape is expected to widen significantly in the years ahead, with hundreds of use cases as verifiable as software development.
Goldman Sachs Research Chief Economist Jan Hatzius predicts that AI could boost annual productivity growth by 1.5 percentage points per year by replacing low- and mid-value-added white-collar tasks.

Jan Hatzius from Goldman Sachs suggests that over the decade, 6-7% of total employment might be displaced by AI, but the impact on unemployment will be smaller as people are absorbed into other industries.
Retail investor activity is becoming a more significant driver of US equities, shaping markets and potentially opening up new opportunities.

A succession of high-profile defaults connected to bankruptcies and fraud allegations have raised questions about the health of credit markets, centered around the rapid growth of the $1.1 trillion US private credit market.
Investment grade credit markets have been even less affected—spreads have widened by single-digit basis points over the last month.
Public credit markets are not yet pricing in a lot of concern, with credit spreads trading close to all-time tights.
Our US economists continue to forecast 2% GDP growth for this year and more than 2% next year, which is very much trend GDP growth—not at all indicative of a recession.
There hasn’t been a recent increase in the amount of money banks are setting aside for loan losses, and broader consumer and small business bankruptcies are continuing to trend down.
AI is a key area of US-China competition, and if fully adopted, it could raise China's GDP by 8% over the next ten years.
Chinese companies are investing in AI, with capital markets pricing the AI story in Chinese assets, indicating a promising direction for growth.
Chinese exports have been resilient, with a projected 8% growth in export volume this year, despite US tariffs.
China is diversifying its trade destinations, with export shares rising in emerging markets, indicating a strategic shift in trade patterns.
Goldman Sachs Research expects two 25-basis-point cuts in March and June 2026 to a terminal rate of 3-3.25%.
The FOMC cut its target rate in October for the second time this year, lowering the fed funds rate by 25 basis points to 3.75-4%.
Goldman Sachs Research forecasts that the Fed will cut interest rates again in December.
Goldman Sachs Research still expects policy makers to lower their target rate again this year despite the press conference playing out differently than expected.
The FOMC’s summary of economic projections for September implied that most participants saw a December cut as the baseline.

Goldman Sachs Research sees signs that the weakness in the US job market is genuine, and deferred resignations of government employees are likely to generate a negative payrolls report in October and weigh a bit on November.
Electricity capacity for data centers in China is on course to jump 30% this year, to 30 gigawatts, indicating rapid growth in AI infrastructure.
China cloud service providers are expected to increase their capital expenditures by around 65% in 2025, supporting AI growth.
China's top internet firms are expected to invest more than $70 billion next year to support AI, which is 15 to 20% of what US hyperscalers are expected to spend.
Chinese AI players have started to generate subscription revenue from AI applications and see further opportunities for growth among foreign customers.
Chinese AI hyperscalers are taking a multi-pronged approach to developing and leveraging domestic chips for AI, indicating growth in China's AI supply chain.
Chinese AI hyperscalers plan to construct data centers across Asia, the Middle East, and Latin America, driven by anticipated international growth.
AI video generation, picture editing, and object identification are top monetizable use-cases for China AI applications, with overseas markets contributing more revenue than domestic markets.
Davidson Kempner is known for its focus on opportunistic credit and event-driven investing, adapting strategies based on market attractiveness.
Davidson Kempner employs a mixture of public equity strategies, public debt strategies, and private debt strategies, making it unique in the investment landscape.
