Overweight view on Asia ex-Japan equities, supported by de-escalating trade tensions and a weak USD, with a preference for China and Korea equities.
Bullish on Chinese equities due to a positive Q2 earnings season, US-China trade truce extension, and relaxation of US semiconductor export curbs.
Preference for Korea equities within Asia ex-Japan due to favorable policy support and compelling valuations.
India equities remain a core holding with a preference for mid-cap equities due to strong earnings trends.
Japan equities are a core holding, but overexposure should be allocated to other Asia markets as tariffs impact earnings growth.
Europe ex-UK equities are a core holding with rising fiscal spending plans offset by a negative earnings revision index.
Bullish on global equities over a 6-12 month horizon, but vigilant about short-term volatility due to US trade policy and inflation risks.
Bullish on the S&P500 index with supportive momentum indicators and low reversal risk.
Overweight view on EM local currency government bonds due to benign EM inflation, strong fiscal positions, and a weak USD.
Bullish on short-dated US High Yield bonds due to attractive absolute yields and low expected default rates.
Underweight view on DM Investment Grade corporate bonds due to tight yield premia and uncertainties around US growth.

A stock market melt-up has extended the equity rebound since President Trump’s initial tariff shock in February-April, driven by strong corporate earnings, Fed rate cuts, and the latest extension of the US-China truce.
The US technology sector is expected to see strong earnings growth, with 23.5% in 2025 and 22.8% in 2026, supported by broadening AI-related investments and increasing demand.
We favour bonds in the 5-7 years maturity bucket and are opportunistically bullish on US Treasury Inflation-Protected Securities (TIPS) as a hedge against upside risks to inflation.
GBP/USD appears technically oversold, leaving scope for a short-term corrective rebound, with significant resistance around 1.35.

We remain Overweight Chinese equities relative to Asia ex-Japan, with valuations attractive and a potential rebound in service consumption and progress towards technological self-reliance expected to drive growth.
The USD index (DXY) fell 0.5% after US companies announced 153,074 job cuts in October, the highest in 20 years, driven by the technology and warehousing sectors.

Fed Governor Goolsbee expressed unease about more rate cuts without data, while Governor Hammack noted inflation remains a bigger concern than the labour market. The DXY is seen testing its support at 98.6.
Japan services PMI rose to 53.1 in October from 52.4, highlighting a shift towards domestic consumption and services. USD/JPY is expected to test technical support at 151.

GBP/USD climbed 0.7% as the BoE held its policy rate at 4%, with five members voting to leave policy unchanged. September's inflation of 3.8% was noted as likely the peak, and markets are pricing in a 70% probability of a 25bps cut in December.
US government bonds are less attractive due to strong gains in equities and higher commodity prices, but slowing growth supports holding bonds.
Global inflation fell to 1.9% from 2%, with consensus and leading indicators pointing to a similar level in 6-12 months.
Overweight view on EM local currency government bonds due to benign local inflation, dovish monetary policy outlook, fiscal improvements, and expectation of a weak USD.
In USD-denominated bonds, short-term yields are expected to decline more than long-term yields, driven by an expected lowering of the Fed Funds rate to 3% by end 2026.
Asia ex-Japan is expected to deliver the highest earnings growth among major regions over the next 12 months, with a preference for China equities.
Underweight UK equities due to stagflation risks, US trade policy risks, and lack of exposure to technology and growth sectors.
Core allocation to Japan equities due to reasonable valuations and rising dividends/share buybacks, but offset by JPY strength and US trade policy.
Overweight Asia ex-Japan equities, supported by policy easing and a weak USD.
Remain Overweight on gold due to its portfolio hedge characteristics, central bank demand, and falling real yields.
Remain Overweight equities into year-end, preferring stocks over credit, with a focus on Asia ex-Japan and US equities.
Bullish tilt towards EUR/USD, with EUR seen as undervalued and more attractive compared to many Asian currencies.
Reduce long-dated US government bonds as the 10-year government bond yield approaches the lower bound of our 3-month range of 4.0%–4.25%.
Add US inflation-protected bonds as inflation pressures are building on renewed tariff headlines.
US equities slumped, with the S&P500 index tumbling 2.7% and the Nasdaq 100 index sinking 3.5% in the worst daily sell-off since 10 April.
We see an opportunity to add to US equities gradually at support levels of 6,250 and 5,900 in the S&P500 index.
China equities remain attractively valued. We expect Beijing to provide ample policy support to counter downside economic risks.
Risk-off sentiment will likely sustain gold prices to stay 'higher for longer', with strong momentum potentially driving gold towards USD 4,100/oz.
USD strength constrained by stagflation risk; CNH downside on policy expectations; Gold higher for longer.
The USD is expected to weaken over the next 6-12 months due to elevated valuations, potential lower rate differentials, and uncertain US trade policy.
The EUR is expected to be a key winner from the weakening USD.
The JPY is expected to be a key winner from the weakening USD.
The GBP is showing resilience and is expected to benefit from the weakening USD.
The CHF is expected to stay range-bound as low domestic rates balance against a weaker USD.
The SGD is expected to weaken.
Global equities are overweight due to policy easing worldwide, strong chances of a US soft landing, and a weaker USD.
Asia ex-Japan equities are upgraded to Overweight, benefiting from strengthening currencies, de-escalating trade tensions, and reasonable valuations.
Emerging Market local currency government bonds are upgraded to Overweight due to benign local inflation, strong fiscal positions, and high real yields.
Developed Market Investment Grade corporate bonds are downgraded to Underweight due to tight valuations and risks of widening yield premia.
US equities are a core allocation, supported by a soft landing of the US economy and a weaker USD, with a preference for cyclical financial, technology, and communication services sectors.
Gold is seen as a core allocation and a vital hedge against 'de-dollarisation' and market volatility, with central bank demand expected to drive prices higher.
Alternative strategies, including equity long-short and private credit strategies, are key to diversification, offering exposure to bullish equities and attractive yields without duration risk.

Markets have rallied sharply in recent weeks, and we maintain our risk-on exposure as we foresee further upside due to a brighter global economic backdrop and resilient cycle reflected in stronger-than-expected Q2 earnings.
We maintain our overweight on Chinese stocks as markets view policy shifts to tackle oversupply and deflation as constructive steps to improving pricing and earnings dynamics.

Technology continues to lead global equities, driven by rapid AI adoption, structural support, and regulatory clarity from measures like the US Genius act, reinforcing investor confidence in the sector.
Our US equity overweight continues to benefit from AI-related optimism, tech leadership, and US economic resilience.
US 10-year Treasury yields are well below the critical threshold of 4.7%, helping risk sentiment and keeping bond yields range-bound.
Analysts are revising forecasts higher due to positive surprises in Q2 earnings, supporting a risk-on stance with active diversification and volatility management.
Treasuries remain well supported during the shutdown, but there are limits to the bond rally after that. Preference is for 'medium' maturities across investment grade and Treasury bonds.
Hong Kong stocks upgraded to overweight due to improving sentiment from tourism measures and a positive wealth effect. Stocks have rallied partly due to IPOs but remain relatively cheap.
High yield downgraded to underweight, preferring investment grade and emerging markets bonds instead.
Infrastructure and utilities upgraded to overweight to address inflation concerns and the growing risk of a shortage in electricity supply.
Gold and partial hedging of USD exposure or FX diversification can help address the risk of USD debasement.
Asia ex-Japan ROE remains on a steady uptrend, while corporate governance reforms continue to improve shareholder returns.
Hong Kong stocks are upgraded to mild overweight due to attractive valuations, south-bound liquidity inflow, and increased local IPO activity.
Hong Kong equity markets benefit from wealth effects, improving sentiment, and strong IPO markets.
US utility stocks are upgraded to mildly overweight as rapidly rising electricity demand could create a bottleneck.
High Yield is reduced to a mild underweight due to tight spreads and rising volatility.
EM local currency bonds are upgraded to mildly overweight for their weaker correlation to risk assets and attractive fundamentals.
We are neutral on hedge funds but retain a substantial core allocation.
Leading GPs in private equity continue to generate decent returns in resilient sectors such as technology, healthcare, and services.
Infrastructure helps provide defensive exposure and steady and inflation-hedged cash flows.
Quality bonds would do well if disappointing growth were to hurt equities, or the government shut-down were to continue for a lot longer.
